DOC.HEAD: Anything But Red
DOC.TEXT: The new president is no fashion plate, but Lech Walesa knows what color he doesn't like: red. Avoiding that Communist favorite was Walesa's only request to his new clothing coordinator, designer Krystyna Wasylkowska of the Polish fashion house Moda Polska. Otherwise, Walesa - who by reporters' count had at most three suits as he led Poland out of Communism, met foreign leaders and spoke to governments worldwide - has turned his wardrobe entirely over to Ms. Wasylkowska. ``He is an easy customer. He told me he would leave everything to me,'' the designer told the Gazeta Wyborcza newspaper. Moda Polska, a state-owned clothing enterprise, was chosen to outfit the president by his staff, which rejected a German firm's offer in favor of the ``Made in Poland'' label, Ms. Wasylkowska was quoted as saying. For her part, Walesa's wife, Danuta, rarely in the spotlight during her husband's decade of activism, made a fashionable entry as First Lady at her husband's inauguration Saturday. She wore an elegant black suit and a dramatic netting-adorned pillbox hat.

DOC.HEAD: Nancy Cruzan Case: A Minister's Dilemma
DOC.TEXT: Eleven days ago, the Rev. Ted Coleman thought removing Nancy Cruzan's feeding tube was immoral and cruel. But the chaplain at the clinic where the woman lies after nearly eight years in a persistent vegetative state told his congregation Sunday that now he's not so sure her parents were wrong to fight for her right to die. ``I'm struggling like I've never had to struggle before,'' Coleman told parishioners at the First Christian Church (Disciples of Christ). Coleman, 51, doubles as chaplain at the Missouri Rehabilitation Center, where Ms. Cruzan is in a vegetative state doctors say is irreversible. The 33-year-old woman remained in deteriorating condition late Sunday. A judge on Dec. 14 gave Ms. Cruzan's parents permission to have the tube removed. Until then, Coleman said he firmly believed that ending Ms. Cruzan's life was wrong. He'd said he never met Joe and Joyce Cruzan until that day, but it didn't matter because he believed ending their daughter's life was unconscionable, even if there was no hope of her recovering. As recently as Tuesday, when 19 people were arrested for bursting into the hospital and trying to reach Ms. Cruzan's room to reconnect her feeding tube, Coleman admitted he sympathized with the anti-euthanasia demonstrators. But after getting to know the Cruzans through daily visits and giving more thought to the right-to-die issue, Coleman said he's re-evaluated his position. ``As a minister of the Gospel, I've studied and been taught that certain truths are always black or white,'' he said. ``As I deal more with this issue, I'm not sure it is black or white.'' When he kisses his two teen-age daughters good night, Coleman said, he puts himself in the Cruzans' position. ``I can't help but ask myself, `What would I do if one of them suddenly was in the same medical condition as Nancy?' Sometimes I think we are too quick to judge others, when we don't know what we would do in the same situation.'' Coleman said he now believes the round-the-clock presence of demonstrators outside the clinic does little more than further burden and irritate the Cruzans. ``They are caring people who have struggled with this issue for a long time. They deserve to have time to grieve the loss of their daughter, which they haven't had,'' Coleman said. Snow, subzero cold and legal setbacks in their attempts to force the state to resume feeding Ms. Cruzan have reduced the number of full-time demonstrators at the hospital from about 15 to just three Sunday night. But the strain on the Cruzans, which began with Nancy's car crash on Jan. 11, 1983, is becoming apparent as her death nears. On Sunday, Joe Cruzan stepped past police officers who screen visitors at the hospital entrance and went onto the lawn to tear up a banner reading ``Joe, Please Feed Nancy.'' ``I got your message, and I got your sign,'' he shouted. Coleman asked the 280 members of his congregation to pray for the Cruzan family, asking either for a miracle or a ``painless and swift'' death for Nancy. He also asked them to pray for him. ``I'm struggling mightily with this issue, and I know others are struggling too,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: South Korea Hopes Gains Are Mutual In Soviet Market
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: With exports to the United States and other parts of the world sagging, South Korea is eager to do business with the Soviet Union. Evidence of South Korean presence is visible almost as soon as a visitor steps off the plane at Sheremetyevo airport in Moscow. The 1,500 baggage carts are emblazoned with signs advertising Samsung, a Korean conglomerate. Visitors can rent Hyundai automobiles made in South Korea, buy Korean-made fur coats and see Korean-sponsored quiz shows on television. They pass billboards advertising Korean companies, placed strategically near the Kremlin. South Korea has washing machines, refrigerators, televisions, videos, sewing machines, soap, shoes, electronics and dozens of other moderately priced consumer goods the Soviets need. South Koreans hope the Soviets have the kinds of advanced technology they need and can't get elsewhere. Experts say the ultimate goal is the transfer from Moscow to Seoul of technologies that either the United States and Japan will nt provide or are too expensive in the West. Among them are core technology in lasers, space, biotechnology, nuclear fusion, electronics and composite and super-hard materials with applications that could range from a new kind of automobile brake to gene therapy. Does the Soviet Union have usable high technologies? No one seems to know. ``The Koreans are still looking at the wares, searching for nuggets,'' a Western expert said. Analyst Kim Byong-kuk said: ``The cardinal inducement for Korean-Soviet economic cooperation stems from the fact that both nations are in a position to offer what the other party needs most.'' President Roh Tae-woo visited Moscow two weeks ago, less than three months after the governments established normal relations. He said his summit talks with Mikhail S. Gorbachev heralded a new era of mutual prosperity. ``The Soviet Union has advanced science and technology we need, and we can provide consumer goods and facilities,'' Roh said. North Korea assailed the visit and indirectly criticized its Soviet allies, but with little effect. A day after Roh returned, the Science and Technology Ministry announced that 281 Soviet technologies were expected to be transferred for commercial application including those for nuclear fusion and fast breeder reactors. In return, South Korea is to provide production technology for consumer goods. The Bank of Korea said $9.1 million had been approved for investment by mid-December. In January, South Korea is expected to complete an economic cooperation and loan package said to total $3 billion. Trade between the two countries doubled in 1989 to $600 million. It is expected to exceed $1 billion in 1990 and South Korean officials have predicted levels of up to $10 billion within five years. After years of selling copycat items at low prices because of low wages, the South Koreans are trying to catch up technologically. To compete in an atmosphere of rising labor and production costs, they need to make more advanced products of higher quality. As if to emphasize the point, the last stop Roh made in the Soviet Union was the Ioffe Physicotechnical Institute in Leningrad. ``Japan is making a lot of money by dominating the world's semiconductor market,'' he was quoted as saying. ``If we combine Soviet advanced technology and South Korea's application know how, we can split the profit.'' Many South Koreans feel the Soviets are using this country as bait to lure a bigger fish, Japan, into committing billions of dollars to long-range development of Soviet natural resources. ``High technology is especially urgent for South Korea,'' said Dr. Rhee Sang-woo, a specialist in public policy, but ``for Japan, it's meaningless. They don't need Soviet high technology. South Korea is bait to fish Japan.'' Japan has held off because of a territorial dispute over a group of islands and because it views investment in the Soviet Union as risky. Observers feel development of close commercial relations between Moscow and Seoul will make Japanese businessmen uneasy and more susceptible to Soviet advances. Among the technologies South Korea wants most are those for high definition television, which displays pictures that are stunning in color and detail. The Soviet Union is said to possess the technology, but has been unable to build and market it. High definition television already is a multibillion-dollar industry in Japan and is beginning to catch on in the United States. Daewoo Corp., parent company of the giant Daewoo Group conglomerate, recently signed two joint-venture contracts with the Soviets with the aim of commercializing new Soviet technologies. The contracts are with the Ioffe institute and the Soviet Ministry of Atomic Energy and Industry. The technologies include those applicable to high definition television, new methods to cast aluminum, nuclear membranes for making work spaces germ-free and technology for treating industrial waste, Daewoo said.

DOC.HEAD: New D.C. Mayor Confronts Drugs, Deficits, Infant Mortality
DOC.TEXT: From a terrifying murder rate to appalling infant mortality, Sharon Pratt Dixon will confront problems that would daunt the nation's savviest public official when she becomes mayor of the nation's capital. But the woman who takes office Jan. 2, is the very opposite of an experienced government bureaucrat. And her response to the challenges will set the tone for life in a city anxious for an end to turbulence after outgoing Mayor Marion Barry's highly publicized drug and legal difficulties. Dixon, 46 and a former utility company executive, swept to victory in November in her first-ever political campaign. She had been the first candidate to call on Barry to give up his job, and campaigned on a pledge to root out waste and corruption in city government. Last month, a blue-ribbon panel that examined the city's deteriorating financial situation recommended that 6,000 government jobs be eliminated. So far, she isn't saying how she'll proceed when she becomes the capital city's first woman mayor. She won't have long to get going - on that problem or any other. The police force continues to grow toward a record level of 5,100 officers, yet a record 471 people have been murdered this year, many of them the result of the city's notorious drug trade. Homelessness; public school difficulties; chronic prison crowding; an infant mortality rate higher than many Third World countries: these will be Dixon's to deal with, as well. Solving these dilemmas will take money, and the nation's capital city is broke. This year's deficit of $100 million could double in the next fiscal year. Amidst the gloom are some signs of hope. The departure of Barry - who is appealing his cocaine possession conviction and six-month prison sentence - should mean a new spirit of goodwill among the city, the Congress and the Bush administration. The annual payment made to the city in lieu of taxes lost on federally-owned property has been frozen at $430.5 million for five years in a visible symbol of congressional dissatisfaction with Barry. After a meeting with Dixon last month, House Speaker Thomas Foley said the payment may soon be increased. Earlier this month, Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner praised Dixon while awarding the city $19 million in federal highway funds. Barry was nowhere to be seen. Dixon's no-frills style differs sharply from that of Barry, who made no secret of his love for limousines, police escorts and other trappings of power. Last month, the mayor-elect said she would all but eliminate the 24-member, round-the-clock police security detail that accompanied Barry to all his official and private functions. ``That's just not my style - I'm not comfortable with it,'' Dixon said. Ms. Dixon, divorced and the mother of two grown daughters, has had a career as an electric company executive. She also has served two terms as treasurer of the Democratic National Committee. But her profile in national Democratic politics aside, she has scant experience in local government affairs. The long-awaited study of the city's bureaucracy gives Dixon - who has promised to pare 2,000 workers from the city payroll - even greater momentum to make broad cuts in the 48,000 member district work force. ``It certainly underscores the need to clean out some of the mid-level bloat,'' Dixon says. ``The need for streamlining, for better accountability, it is all there.'' Eliminating police jobs could prove unpopular on Capitol Hill, where lawmakers critical of city anti-crime efforts are nonetheless anxious to see Dixon take over from Barry. Other pressing problems have so far defied solution. Among them, the city's 1989 infant mortality rate of 23.1 per 1,000 live births was higher than the rate in Malaysia, Mauritius, and Uruguay. And even before Dixon can take office, the sniping has begun. Dixon promises to ``hit the ground running,'' but so far has failed to name any key lieutenants. Current and former city officials assisting her transition are complaining that the passage is marked by a lack of direction from Dixon herself and her failure to list any top priorities for her new administration. To make matters worse, Dixon is already dealing with government infighting. City Council Chairman John Wilson has made no secret of his desire to wield more power. An advisory group he assembled to help him restructure his new job resembles, in the words of WAMU-FM political commentator Mark Plotkin, ``a 1994 mayoral exploratory committee.''

DOC.HEAD: Like Presidents Before Him, Bush Forgoes Raise
DOC.TEXT: Federal workers everywhere, from Vice President Dan Quayle to the troops in the Persian Gulf to the groundskeepers at the White House, will pocket fatter paychecks in the new year. There's one exception to the rule: President Bush. His salary stays frozen at $200,000, right where it has been for the last 22 years and five presidencies. For several million rank-and-file workers, both military and civilian, the pay raise is a flat 4.1 percent. But thousands of top federal executives are getting big raises, on the scale of $20,000 to $30,000, thanks to a 1989 law that lifted the lid on salaries. Quayle's pay will rocket from $124,000 to $160,600. Chief Justice William Rehnquist and Speaker Thomas Foley get the same 29 percent increase. Cabinet salaries swell from $107,300 to $138,900. The Constitution precludes raising - or lowering - the president's pay during his term, so Bush has no immediate prospects for a salary hike. Bush has ``no complaints,'' says White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. ``He thinks his pay is adequate. The presidency's still a pretty good job,'' quipped the press secretary. No one disputes that, but a blue-ribbon panel that reviewed government salaries two years ago did recommend boosting the president's salary in 1993 to $350,000 plus a cost-of-living adjustment. Congress ignored the recommendation. Consumer advocate Ralph Nader begs to differ. Nader, who lobbied strenuously to block the pay hikes, believes Bush should revoke the 1991 raises and cut his own pay ``as a gesture to the American people at a time of considerable sacrifice for them.'' ``At a time of deficit and recession, he should set an example,'' Nader said. Presidents have only gotten four pay increases in history. Experts agree that whatever the salary, the presidency is rich in perquisites, from a mansion staffed with servants to the limousines, helicopters and Boeing 747 jumbo jet at his beck and call. ``The president probably gets the equivalent of another $500,000 in perks,'' said lawyer Lloyd N. Cutler, who chaired the 1989 Quadrennial Pay Commission. ``The perks make up for an awful lot of salary,'' Still, Cutler said the president's salary is ``way below what it ought to be.'' If Bush were paid commensurate to corporate chiefs and top lawyers, ``I suppose you'd be over $1 million,'' said Cutler. ``With present budget constraints, this president would never ask for a raise if he were going to run again.'' The $200,000 ``was a darn good salary'' back in 1969, said Fred Hohlweg, a pay expert with the Office of Personnel Management. ``He's doing worse and worse.'' The Consumer Price Index has increased nearly fourfold since 1969. If the president's pay had kept pace, Bush would be drawing $730,000 a year. Put another way, $200,000 today barely buys what $55,000 did back in 1969. Walton R. Winder, a vice president of Towers Perrin Co. in New York, said the chief executives of the nation's 100 largest corporations averaged $1.3 million in cash compensation last year, more than five times their 1969 level. Even top university and non-profit organization jobs pay more than the presidency, Winder said. Vice presidents, on the other hand, have never had it so good. When the first Congress fixed George Washington's salary at the then kingly sum of $25,000 in 1789, the lawmakers allotted $5,000 for Vice President John Adams - 20 percent of the president's salary. When Bush became vice president, he was earning less than 40 percent of Ronald Reagan's salary. But by the time Bush turned the job over to Dan Quayle, it paid $115,000. Quayle got a $9,000 raise earlier this year and starting Jan. 1 he will be earning barely 20 percent less than Bush. Perhaps because the vice president's salary traditionally is linked to that paid the speaker of the house, Congress has shown less reluctance to vote raises for the president's stand-by than the president himself. Vice presidential salaries have been raised 18 times - and cut on four occasions in the Depression and in 1874. The first 17 presidents got the same $25,000 salary that Washington commanded. Ulysses S. Grant, the 18th president, got a $25,000 raise that doubled the salary to $50,000 in 1873 for his second term. In 1909, Congress forked over another $25,000, boosting the salary to $75,000 when William Howard Taft took office as the 27th president. There it remained for the next 40 years. In 1930, when Babe Ruth signed a stratospheric $80,000-a-year contract with the New York Yankees, scribes asked the slugger if he thought he should be paid more than President Herbert Hoover. ``Why not? I had a better year than he did,'' the Babe replied. Harry Truman, the 33rd president, became the first $100,000-a-year president in 1949. Dwight D. Eisenhower, John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson got by on the same amount, but the salary doubled to $200,000 in 1969 when Richard M. Nixon took the oath of office. ``Congress did that without any by-your-leave from either the outgoing or the incoming president, and it was done in a matter of days,'' said Sharon S. Gressle, who tracks government salaries for the Congressional Research Service. Quayle, members of Congress, judges and others at the top of the salary pyramid now are eligible for cost-of-living increases, up to 5 percent a year. If they got the maximum increase for the next five years, then on Jan. 1, 1996, the vice president would be making $205,000, or $5,000 more than the president, Gressle said.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Not a Creature Was Stirring...EEEEEEK! What Was THAT!
DOC.TEXT: 'Tis the night before Christmas, and all through the House and Senate, lots of creatures are stirring. Especially mice. The Capitol is a building alive. Although the exact number is a national secret (or it would be, if it could be determined), there is a battalion of mice living in the historic structure. Occasionally they make themselves known, including memorable sightings on the House floor and in Speaker Thomas Foley's old office. Perhaps when no one is around but the guards, they frolic openly. But beyond the squeaks of its diminutive year-round residents, the Capitol itself speaks. Sometimes, it speaks of fear. Metal detectors and x-ray machines erected at nearly every entrance tell of a decade of increasing unease about terrorism. Hidden cameras watch the corridors. A careful observer can rap steel inserts in the seatbacks of the House chamber and find a patch in the Republican leader's desk where a bullet from a Puerto Rican nationalist's gun penetrated four decades ago. On the Senate side, a beefed-up wall stands behind the Ohio Clock, which was restored after a 1983 bomb explosion shattered its delicate wooden housing. Sometimes, it speaks of vanity. For example, lawmakers since World War II have taken to naming the rooms after themselves. Historical greats such as Daniel Webster and Henry Clay command no territory beyond their statues. But Speaker Foley holds meetings in the Thomas P. O'Neill Room, named after the Massachusetts Democrat and former speaker. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, works in a suite named after his predecessor, Sen. Robert C. Byrd, D-W.Va. And Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., labors in the Howard Baker rooms, named for his predecessor. The rush for recognition in the Senate has so gobbled up real estate that some worry there may soon be no good rooms left to name. Already, a Christmas Eve visitor would find telephone booths in the Democratic cloakroom named for senior senators. Not only the elected officials have egos. Architect of the Capitol George White had his portrait added to the collection painted on the arched ceilings in the House wing. The building on the hill also speaks of power. A sign on the door tells visitors that the House Document Room is no longer adjacent to beautiful Statuary Hall. The repository of bills and reports has been moved out of the building so that Speaker Foley can add to his ever-expanding kingdom. Nameplates on doors throughout the building indicate the offices of the most powerful and senior chairman, names like Rostenkowski, Whitten, and Byrd. Doors with no names also tell tales to those who know. Many are senators' hideaways, private retreats only steps from the Senate floor where lawmakers can work undisturbed, hold secret meetings or just catch a nap during a late session. All around, the building speaks of age and decay. Scaffolds abound during the congressional recess as expert plasterers and painters repair the wounds time and nature have inflicted on the structure. And at the top of the dome, the statue Freedom is crying for its upcoming restoration after a century of rain, wind and lightning. And the Capitol speaks of hope, both whimsical and not. The shoes of the statue of Will Rogers shine from people touching them for luck. ``I do it more in election years,'' says Rep. Mike Snyder, D-Okla. Nearby, in the Rotunda, among the grandiose paintings and statuary, is a plain black and white flag with a symbol of a captive soldier and the letters ``POW-MIA.'' It always speaks. It's just easier to hear during the holidays.

DOC.HEAD: Project Would Give Voters Just The Facts On Candidates
DOC.TEXT: Richard Kimball envisions a future in which voters reject television campaign commercials and select national leaders as they would prospective employees - by reviewing their resumes. He has taken a leave from his job to try to make those resumes and more available to voters by telephone in 1992 on every candidate running for national office from every state. ``The people in Congress are the hired help,'' said Kimball. ``We're saying if you, the voter, are the employer, what do you need to know?'' Kimball, a political science teacher and former Arizona state senator, is directing the Center for National Independence in Politics, a non-profit organization whose honorary co-chairmen are former Presidents Gerald Ford and Jimmy Carter. Kimball says that by 1992, the center will offer a telephone number providing voters: -Basic personal information on each candidate. -Names of people and organizations who have contributed to the campaign. -Ratings of the candidate by special interest groups ranging from the American Conservative Union to the American Civil Liberties Union. Kimball worked briefly many years ago in the Washington offices of Sen. Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., and Rep. Morris Udall, D-Ariz. After serving in the Arizona Senate for four years and as chairman of the Arizona Corporation Commission, which regulates utilities, Kimball ran for the U.S. Senate in 1986, but lost to Sen. John McCain, a Republican. Melodee Jackson, Arizona Democratic Party executive director, said some people questioned Kimball's decision to run a longshot campaign against McCain when he had a secure and successful career with the regulatory commission. ``He probably would have been re-elected (to the commission) for as long as he wanted to run,'' she said. Kimball is passionate about politics and unconventional in that ``he doesn't hold up his finger to see which way the wind is blowing before he takes a position,'' Jackson said. Kimball said his Senate race against the well-financed McCain campaign showed him the importance of television in modern elections, but the image-making quality of TV commercials sickened him. The ads used nowadays ``are disastrous in a democracy,'' said Kimball. ``How can you possibly expect people to govern themselves if what is put before them is not a discussion of public policy? ``People cannot deal with the manipulation. They're being buried by meaningless information.'' He said campaign finance laws can be changed, but voters won't be better off if the money available is still used to build images irrelevant to issues facing the country. The idea for the telephone service came while Kimball was talking to former Sen. William Proxmire, D-Wis., who campaigned for him in 1986, and former Sen. Barry Goldwater, R-Ariz., who is a lifelong acquaintance. The three of them contacted other political figures to serve on the center's board of directors. The 35-member board is equally divided among Democrats and Republicans and includes others unaffiliated with a party. Last election, the center experimented with its concept in Nebraska and North Carolina. ``We got about 6,000 calls,'' said Kimball. Since the center did no paid advertising, the calls were generated by news stories and word of mouth after one press conference. When people called the 800-number, they got an operator with access to a computer holding the information on each candidate. Kimball said about 50 percent of the callers wanted voting record ratings and 25 percent sought campaign finance information, but operators also got calls seeking a range of biographical details. Kimball says the center needs at least $500,000 to run a nationwide telephone service using toll-free numbers, but he said a self-financing 900-number system would be used if sufficient funds aren't raised. It would cost $3 a call. Seed money for the project, which operated on a budget of $290,000 last year, came from $35 memberships obtained through direct mail solicitations and a total of about $100,000 from five foundations: Carnegie, Deer Creek Foundation, Mary Reynolds Babcock, Benton Foundation and ARCA. The center is based in Tucson, Ariz., and staffed predominantly by volunteers, including Kimball. The board members are unpaid and include Rep. Jim Leach, R-Iowa; Peggy Lampl, former president of the League of Women Voters; Kenneth Adelman, former head of the U.S. Arms Control and Disarmament Agency; 1984 Democratic vice presidential nominee Geraldine Ferraro; Sen. David Boren, D-Okla.; John Echohawk, head Native Americans Rights Fund; former Sen. George McGovern, D-S.D.; and Irene Natividad, former president of the National Women's Political Caucus.

DOC.HEAD: Cut Off Aid If Repression Occurs, Majority Leader Says
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration has banked too heavily on Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev's ability to reform his troubled nation, according to a key Senate leader and others. ``Gorbachev is, of course, an historic figure - effected change in the world more than any other person in recent years,'' Senate Majority Leader George J. Mitchell, D-Maine, said Sunday. But Mitchell said Gorbachev is not going to rule forever in a country where, he said, the central government appears to be leaning towards a crackdown on the rebellious republics. ``I think we should be supportive, we certainly should be grateful for all he has done, but I think our policy ought not to be as highly personal as it has been,'' he said on NBC-TV's ``Meet the Press.'' Of the situation in the Soviet Union, Mitchell said, ``I think the signs coming out of there are ominous in the last few days and the possibilities of that (a crackdown) occurring, I think are increasing.'' If a crackdown occurs, he said the United States should cut off any aid to the Soviet Union. ``I think we ought to have substantial aid unless and until the crackdown occurs and if it does, then ... we surely should not be providing aid at that time,'' he said. Zbigniew Brzezinski, national security adviser under former President Carter, agreed with Mitchell's pessimistic assessment of the future of the Soviet Union, at least in the near term. ``I think the coalition ... is beginning to break up,'' he said. ``The options are becoming more extreme and I am afraid there is, indeed, a drift toward the hard line with the KGB and the army now being the dominant political institutions,'' he said. Moreover, the United States has ``overly identified the future of the Soviet Union with Gorbachev,'' he said. While Gorbachev deserves the administration's support and admiration, he has proved intransigent in his opposition to collective ownership of land and has said he will never give up on the idea of a multinational state run by the Russians, Brzezinski said. ``These two things are no longer viable,'' he said. Earlier this month, President Bush outlined a varied economic aid package that included technical and medical assistance and support for the Soviets to affiliate with the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. Bush announced his plan before Eduard Shevardnadze resigned as foreign minister, contending the Soviet Union was moving towards a dictatorship. On Saturday, the head of the KGB, Vladimir Kryuchkov, warned of a possibility of bloodshed to restore order to the rebellious republics. Bush has said the United States is concerned about Shevardnadze's resignation. ``Obviously people are ... wondering about the concerns raised by Mr. Shevardnadze,'' he said. ``Life goes on,'' he added. Former Secretary of State George Shultz, appearing on ABC-TV's ``This Week With David Brinkley,'' said he had a hard time speculating what would happen in the Soviet Union. For the moment, he said the Bush administration continue to engage the Soviet Union on key points, such as reducing nuclear arms and trying to dampen regional conflicts.

DOC.HEAD: Christmas Spirit Takes True Grit in Desert Shield
DOC.TEXT: Every soldier in the U.S. Army's 1st Cavalry Division is getting a gift package for Christmas - even if it's only a pair of government-issue green socks. Services to mark the birth of Jesus and secular yuletide symbols such as Christmas trees are being hidden behind closed tent flaps so as not to offend the Moslem hosts of the Desert Shield deployment. Carols are sung in combat boots and Christmas spirit is as hard to find as reindeer in a camel herd, so troops fight to keep their minds off the thousands of miles separating them from loved ones. ``If I start thinking about it, I get lonely,'' said Army Spec. Robert Dennett, 29, of Rutherford, Texas, whose three kids will be opening Christmas gifts without him. ``My wife said she was going to save a bunch of presents 'til I got back and do Christmas all over again.'' Christmas was intentionally subdued in Saudi Arabia, where strict Islamic codes ban the worship of other religions. That means songs like ``White Christmas'' are preferred over ``Silent Night'' on the military radio stations. The only celebrity to visit is Bob Hope, the war-horse troubadour who first entertained U.S. combat troops 50 years ago. Meals and mail provided some Christmas cheer. Military cooks prepared 150,000 pounds of rolled turkey and 4,000 whole turkeys for the 280,000 U.S. service members brought to Saudi Arabia after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. The goal is to get a hot Christmas dinner to all the troops, even those closest to the Kuwaiti border. The main lifeline to home is the average of 400 tons of mail a day, hauled in on at least five planeloads. Inmates at Szabo Correctional Services at Dublin, Calif., sent boxes of cookies to officers. Josefina Ceja of Pomona, Calif., dispatched homemade tortillas to her son. Another mom sent a finger-painting set. ``Even the camels see the mail trucks coming because the troops feed them cookies,'' said Major Gen. William ``Gus'' Pagonis, head of logistics for the largest U.S. military operation since Vietnam. ``Like other creatures of the wild, they learn real fast the GIs will feed them.'' So many packages addressed to ``any soldier'' were received that each of the 20,000 soldiers of the 1st Cavalry Division can expect to get a Christmas package. Those who don't get a civilian gift can expect to get military T-shirts, underwear and socks. ``It might be a pair of green socks. It might be a Frisbee. But we've got one gift for every soldier,'' said Maj. Steve Stacey, the division's personnel officer. He also delivered the 1st Cavalry's message to the folks on the home front: ``Although we're homesick and we miss you, we're with you in spirit. We can't send any presents, so we send your our love.'' Midnight Mass has its own subtleties in the sand. Some services were to be moved up to dusk. That way, troops wouldn't violate the military ban on lights in the desert night. Lt. Theodore Borger, one of three Roman Catholic priests tending to the spiritual needs of the 1st Marine Division, was planning about 20 services. He was going to break out his special folding combat altar, but was not going to deliver any special message. ``There will be others that will talk to them about the evil or war. That's not my job,'' said Borger, 35, of Ottumwa, Iowa. Meanwhile, troops entertained themselves by singing lyrics to their favorite holiday tunes. The Marine version of ``Jingle Bells'' went like this: ``Dashing through the sand, with an M16 in hand, terrorizing the land, looking for Hussein. Treads on tracks will ring, giving troops a fright, opens up the door, we get out and fight.'' A few Marines stuck up stockings in their tents, and Cpl. Vincent Buck, 21 decorated the radiator grill of his truck with a plastic holy wreath his mother sent from Santa Barbara, Calif. His dad sent mistletoe. There were not to be any Christmas spirits of the alcoholic variety because of Saudi Arabia's strict ban on booze. So Maj. John Porter of the Army's Battle Command Training Program made other plans. ``We're going to have a party on the beach,'' said Porter, 38, of Leavenworth, Kan. ``We're going to have near-beer, near-wine, and the next morning we're going to wake up with near hangovers.'' Some combat training has been scheduled for Christmas Day, but most troops will have a light day. ``It's just another day in the desert,'' said Pfc. Mark Idleman, 19, of Wilson, Okla., a tank crewman with the 32nd Armored Regiment of the 1st Cavalry Division. ``Christmas is a bad topic over here,'' said Lt. Tyler Randolph, 24, of MacLean, Va., who serves in one of the units of the Army's 18th Airborne Corps. ``It just makes you miss everybody more.''

DOC.HEAD: Report: Surrendering Drug Lords' To Have Kitchenettes and Patios
DOC.TEXT: Jail cells for surrendering cocaine smugglers will be endowed with kitchenettes, private baths and individual patios, a Bogota newspaper reports. Citing Justice Ministry official John Jairo Mejia, El Tiempo said in Sunday's editions that each drug trafficker's cell will contain 290 square feet. A common outdoor ``green zone'' will surround the prisoners. Colombian drug bosses have said between 200 and 300 traffickers are willing to surrender to authorities in exchange for lenient judicial treatment. Besides an end to extraditions to the United States, the traffickers are demanding specially prepared jails protected by the army and police. Five traffickers have already turned themselves in, including Fabio Ochoa, the youngest of three brothers who help run the Medellin cocaine cartel. Mejia denied reports that traffickers would be given luxury jail cells. ``We are not talking about suites,'' El Tiempo quoted him as saying.

DOC.HEAD: President Sends Holiday Greetings To Troops Worldwide
DOC.NOTE: For Release Noon EST; Time set by source.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, in a Christmas message to U.S. troops worldwide, reiterated his vow to try to bring those serving in the Persian Gulf home without a shot fired and declared ``the world is behind you.'' ``In this season of peace it is your commitment and your courage that makes peace possible,'' Bush said in the taped message that was being broadcast on armed services radio beginning at noon today. ``Back home, some talk of the cost of war. But it is you who understand the price of peace,'' he said. Bush, who with his wife Barbara spent Thanksgiving visiting troops in Saudi Arabia, recalled that visit in his talk. ``And when I got back, I spoke to the American people, told them of your bravery and reminded them why we're there.'' Bush was spending the Christmas holidays with members of his family at the presidential retreat at Camp David, Md. ``We're in the Gulf because the world must not reward aggression, because our vital interests are at stake, and because of the brutality and danger of Saddam Hussein,'' Bush said. With the United Nations-set deadline of Jan. 15 for Saddam Hussein to leave Kuwait just weeks away, Bush said, ``When you come home, and we hope it's soon, you'll be welcomed as what you are: all-American heroes.'' Bush reiterated his vow to ``do my level best to bring you home without a shot being fired.'' ``The sacrifices you make will never be forgotten. America is behind you. The world is behind you and history is behind you.'' The president concluded the message with a story about a military couple both serving in the Gulf. ``I think of Lt. Mary Danko, the flight nurse who volunteered for Saudi Arabia. Her husband, a C-130 navigator, was already flying in support of Desert Shield. And when asked if leaving their baby with relatives was a hard thing to do, Mary said: 'it's the right thing to do. We're needed.''' ``And when asked, `now what about the kid?' Mary explained, `we're doing it for the kid.''' ``It's distant in time, but close within our hearts because on this Christmas Day, hour by hour, hand in hand, Americans will send their prayers eastward across the ocean and halfway across the world not only to the town of Bethlehem but to the sands and shores where you stand in harm's way,'' Bush said.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: What makes former heavyweight champ Mike Tyson angry? Paying taxes and getting pulled over by the police. ``I hate taxes,'' he told Spin magazine in its January 1991 issue. ``More than anything. They can take your money and all that stuff. But you know what they do? They humiliate you. Like, I can handle being broke, but it's just the fact of being humiliated.'' As for the police, Tyson, 24, hates officers who tell him, ``You might have a lot of money, but I'm the boss here.'' ``You know, if you're going to give me a ticket, give me a ticket,'' Tyson said. ``Don't give me a ticket and a lecture.'' Tyson lost the heavyweight title in February to Buster Douglas. --- COLUMBIA, S.C. (AP) - James Brown will perform in public for the first time since his imprisonment two years ago when he entertains soldiers at Fort Jackson on Christmas. The soul singer, who began a four-day furlough Sunday, is scheduled to entertain nearly 10,000 soldiers whose holiday leaves were canceled because of the Persian Gulf crisis. Corrections Commissioner Parker Evatt gave the ``Godfather of Soul'' permission to perform. Brown is serving a six-year sentence for aggravated assault, failure to stop for police and weapons violations stemming from a high-speed chase through Georgia and South Carolina. He was imprisoned in December 1988 and is eligible for parole March 8. In April, Brown, who had several previous arrests on drug charges, transferred to a work-release program in Aiken where he counsels youths about drug abuse. He stays at a minimum-security facility near Aiken at night. --- RADNOR, Pa. (AP) - Less than a year after Deborah Norville succeeded Jane Pauley on NBC's ``Today'' show, network sources are speculating that national correspondent Katie Couric will replace her. Don Browne, executive vice president of NBC News, denies the rumors, saying it's too soon after Ms. Norville's arrival to change the show's co-hosts. Ms. Couric, 33, is scheduled to substitute for Ms. Norville when she goes on maternity leave in the spring. ``She's no substitute - she's the successor,'' an unidentified source told TV Guide in its Dec. 29 issue. ``Deborah's a bright woman, but she doesn't come across that way on camera. She comes across as plastic. Katie's real.'' Ms. Couric, 33, joined NBC in 1989 as deputy Pentagon correspondent. She has filled in several times as weekend anchor of ``NBC Nightly News'' and is scheduled to sub for ``Nightly News'' anchorman Tom Brokaw on New Year's Eve. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Why did Francis Ford Coppola make ``The Godfather, Part III''? ``For the same reasons I made the second one: it didn't go away, and they basically promised me carte blanche,'' Coppola, 51, said in Sunday's New York Times. ```The Godfather' became my claim to fame and my claim to be able to continue making movies,'' he said. The first two ``Godfathers'' are the only movie and its sequel to both win the Academy Award for best picture. Earlier this year Coppola filed for bankruptcy and claims to owe up to $7 million after such flops as ``The Cotton Club'' and ``One From the Heart.'' ``I began to realize I didn't know who my audience was,'' he told the Times. ``When I made a film, a ton of people didn't just turn out to see it.'' He said he began to realize that he was getting older and didn't have a big audience anymore. ```The Godfather' always represented to me a chance to have a big audience,'' he said. Coppola will earn $5 million for writing, directing and producing the third chapter of the saga, plus a 15 percent share of the gross. --- SANTA BARBARA, Calif. (AP) - Steven Seagal and wife Kelly LeBrock, stars of the action film ``Hard to Kill,'' have added a vineyard to their Santa Ynez Valley ranch. The ranch is next to singer Michael Jackson's compound. The couple reportedly paid $1.7 million for a 100-acre parcel that includes a 50-acre vineyard. The parcel adjoins Seagal's 80-acre ranch about 30 miles north of Santa Barbara. LeBrock, a former model, starred in the film ``Woman in Red'' and later appeared in ``Weird Science.'' The couple bought the $2.8 million ranch in February.

DOC.HEAD: Panel: National Policy Needed on Rural Development
DOC.TEXT: If people living in small towns and on small farms are to be helped, a first step must be the formation of a national policy on rural development, a presidential panel has concluded. The National Commission on Agriculture and Rural Development Policy said in a report sent to President Bush that the 1980s ``were much harder on many rural areas than on their urban counterparts.'' It cited economic crises in the agricultural and energy sectors, along with ``tough new foreign competition in manufacturing,'' and the relative disadvantage rural people have in obtaining adequate, affordable health care, education and other vital services. Another factor noted by the report is the ``physical and social isolation'' that separate rural America from the economic activity of city life. The 15-member commission was appointed for two years by President Reagan. It was authorized by the 1985 farm law, which is now expiring. In its first report a year ago, the commission examined agricultural policy issues and called for a more flexible, market-oriented farm policy that would leave it up to farmers to decide what crops to plant but still provide a ``safety net'' for hard times. The 1990 farm law, which runs for five years after the current one expires, provided some of that flexibility in its commodity programs. In its final report, the commission focused on rural development and some of the things local people and their governments ought to be doing and thinking about. No massive federal aid package was called for. Rather, the commission felt ``there are many problems in rural America, and rural Americans are dealing with them, for their fate is in their own hands.'' Still, it said, the federal government has ``a critical support role to play'' through many channels, including the use of existing programs to help people and communities financially. ``When and if, a rural development policy is formulated, it will be done in a different context from that of the past,'' the report said. ``There is currently no defined rural development policy. Instead, there exists a loose collection of individual programs.'' Those partly resulted, the report said, from the division among various federal agencies and among the federal, state and local governments as to who had the responsibility for rural development. ``The federal government no longer plays the lead role, nor do we expect it to,'' the commission reported. As many others have noted in recent years, the report made it clear again that the problems of rural America are not homogeneous, nor should they be solely equated with agriculture. ``Farming is still a vital part of the rural economy,'' the report said. ``However, it directly employs less than 10 percent of the rural work force. Mining, manufacturing, tourism, services and government are also important industries in the rural economy.'' Thus, the report added, ``Neither farm policy nor any other single-issue policy can sufficiently address the needs of rural America.'' The commission said the ``first step toward helping rural America is to articulate the goals for rural development policy,'' which, it said, are not solely economic in nature. Three principles were listed by the commission as guides for rural development: -Rural areas and people must be economically self-reliant. In a highly competitive, market-oriented world economy, self-reliance is critical if the rural economy is to generate better jobs and income for its residents. -Rural areas and people must be able to adapt. The world economy has changed rapidly in recent years. Economic change is predicted to become even more rapid. As a result, rural areas must develop the ability to respond rapidly and effectively to changing market conditions. -The rural physical and cultural environment should be protected. The physical environment in rural areas and the cultural heritage of rural people are valuable elements of national life and livelihood, enjoyed by rural and urban residents alike, and deserve protection.

DOC.HEAD: Physicians Reassert That Chemical Weapons Were Used
DOC.TEXT: Doctors who visited Kurdish refugees in late 1988 say their interviews and examinations convinced them Iraqi President Saddam Hussein had used chemical weapons against his own people. The physicians vociferously disputed a U.S. military study in which the authors said there was no conclusive evidence that Iraq gassed the Kurds in August and September 1988. ``We disagree very strongly,'' Dr. Howard Hu said of the conclusions' reached by the military analysts who wrote a book entitled ``Iraqi Power and U.S. Security in the Middle East.'' The book is primarily about the Iraq-Iran war, which ended in July 1988. Hu, who works at Harvard Medical School, said in a telephone interview from Boston last week that he and two other doctors traveled to Turkey in October 1988 to interview Kurds who had fled Iraq after the alleged gas attacks. ``Was there any doubt that the Kurds had been gassed? No,'' Hu said. The doctors are associated with Physicians For Human Rights, a Boston-based group. They conducted in-depth videotaped interviews, examined alleged victims and administered a 14-page questionnaire. They saw people who had skin burns that are characteristic of chemical weapons burns, Hu said. Moreover, the reports from the refugees were consistent. According to the testimony, the refugees saw bombing runs by low-flying jets followed by the appearance of dark yellow clouds, the sudden death of animals and humans and they experienced skin blistering and severe irritation of the respiratory passages. Hu said the physicians did not see victims until nearly six weeks after the attacks, however. ``The team could not determine the number of weapons used, the scale of the attacks or the exact chemical composition of the chemical agents,'' the doctors said. President Bush and others have used Iraq's alleged use of chemical weapons against the Kurds as one of the justifications stopping Saddam's aggression in the Persian Gulf. ``We've seen him use chemical weapons on his own people,'' Bush said. But three analysts at the U.S. Army War College, whose book was released last summer, raise questions about whether Saddam gassed the Kurds in the fall of 1988. ``Having looked at all of the evidence that was available to us, we find it impossible to confirm the State Department's claim that gas was used in this instance,'' the authors wrote. ``To begin with, there were never any victims produced,'' they said. The authors said the claims rest solely on the testimony of refugees. The military authors did not visit Iraq, but looked at the available reports. They speculated the Kurds might have been injured by fuel air explosives instead of chemical weapons. Iraq denied at the time that it had gassed the Kurds and Turkish officials said they too found no evidence of chemical weapons injuries among the 60,000 Kurdish refugees. The authors said the conclusions in their book were their own and did not necessarily reflect the views of the U.S. military.

DOC.HEAD: `The Night Before Christmas' Author's Other Legacy Threatened By Age
LaserPhoto NY4
DOC.TEXT: After 168 years, Clement Moore's holiday poem ``The Night Before Christmas'' is solid as gold. But another of his creations, stately St. Peter's Episcopal Church - for which he donated the land and design - is falling apart. The church's patched, sagging roof probably couldn't support a sleigh, let alone eight tiny reindeer, and its back wall bulges like Santa's belly. ``There's a nice pile of stones out in the garden, and they've all fallen out of the tower,'' said Ronald Kastner, who heads a campaign to raise $3 million to repair the New York City landmark. The church's 130-foot bell tower is held together by steel cables and masked by scaffolding. The tower's four-faced clock is still and many of its stones have fallen and damaged the roof of the nave. Windows that once boasted Tiffany-style stained glass are boarded up. ``If we don't get the money,'' Kastner said, ``the tower will fall onto the roof, and the roof will collapse, and the church will close.'' The Episcopal Diocese of New York gave the congregation $500,000 for repairs, but St. Peter's must raise the needed $3 million more tself. The church is just one of Clement Clarke Moore's many accomplishments. Born in 1779, he grew up on what was then his family's rural estate. The area is now part of Manhattan's bustling Chelsea neighborhood. In 1817 Moore donated the church property for the General Theological Seminary, where he was a distinguished biblical scholar for three decades. But he is remembered for ``An Account of a Visit from St. Nicholas,'' also known as ``The Night Before Christmas.'' He is said to have written the poem during a sleigh ride home from Greenwich Village just before Christmas 1822, and to have read it later to his six children. The piece was published a year later in the Troy Sentinel and helped create St. Nick's image as a ``jolly old elf'' who looked more like a peddler than a children's saint. But even as Moore's composition was rising to fame, its pastoral setting was disappearing. In the 1820s, Chelsea was a two-stagecoach trip from what was then the city and is now lower Manhattan. But urbanites were moving steadily north to escape disease and congestion. Around 1830 Moore decided to develop his farm, called Chelsea, as a planned residential suburb. He sold the land in lots but attached restrictions: no alleys, stables or factories, and no building within 10 feet of the sidewalk. Moore the developer transformed the landscape. Moore the poet, said historian Stephen Nissenbaum, helped transform the nation's most widely observed holiday from ``a big public occasion of rowdiness that lasted a month into a domestic and private event within the family.'' St. Peter's, with its tower and massively buttressed fieldstone walls, became a focal point of the new neighborhood upon its completion in 1838. Moore persuaded the congregation to accept a neo-Gothic design inspired by his visits to English churches. By 1900 St. Peter's had about 500 parishioners, but membership fell off as the building declined. It was closed temporarily in 1941 because of leaks in the roof. Over the years water continued to seep into the building, loosening the mortar that held its stones and weakening the roof's wooden framing. When the Rev. Wray MacKay took over as vicar, the church averaged 10 people at Sunday services. But MacKay expanded the congregation by increasing its services, including an AIDS ministry, a food pantry, a program for the area's welfare hotel residents and seasonal clothing drives. The church now has about 200 members. Moore died in 1863 and is buried 130 blocks uptown at Trinity Cemetery. There, every Christmas Eve, carolers gather to sing the praises of the city's most illustrious theologian, poet, developer and architect.

DOC.HEAD: General Assembly Mulls Expanded Session, Other Reforms
DOC.TEXT: As the United Nations takes a stronger role in world affairs, hopes are rising that the General Assembly will become more efficient. The assembly, which ended its fall session last week, is to many minds long overdue for reform. U.N. officials say the sessions are too short, that delegations are dealing with too much nonessential business and a crush of unnecessary paperwork. Though the 15-nation Security Council gets most of the limelight at times of international crisis, the assembly, which includes all 159 member states, handles much of the organization's business. Timing is one important area. ``The timing of the U.N. General Assembly sessions was originally determined with an eye to sailing schedules of the Queen Mary,'' says the undersecretary-general for General Assembly affairs, Ronald Spiers. ``It is now anachronistic.'' The assembly still ends its fall meeting at the same time it did at the United Nations' founding in 1945. ``What kind of General Assembly is this, which works for three months and hibernates during the remaining nine months?'' asks Guido de Marco, Malta's foreign minister, who is president of the assembly this year. Spiers, the top American in the world body, says in a working paper that the assembly ``needs to be viewed as a year-round body; not in continuous meeting, but always available at call, not constrained by out-of-date considerations.'' De Marco says it should expand its calendar of meetings to focus on foreign affairs in the September-December session, and add assemblies on humanitarian affairs in March and an economic and social session in May and June. Spiers advocates a general debate in November, with assembly committees churning out the work of the body from January until the following autumn. De Marco says thrice-yearly assemblies would enable the General Assembly to focus its work on specific themes, attracting like-minded government ministers concerned with those areas. This would pave the way for advances in social, economic and humanitarian areas like the breakthroughs announced every fall in the political sphere, when foreign ministers congregate in New York every September. Among the resolutions remaining on the current agenda are retreads of anti-apartheid declarations; redundant anti-Israel measures; the report on the Drinking Water Supply and Sanitation Decade; and measures to be taken against Nazi, fascist, and neo-fascist activities. Spiers says that rather than carry over items from year to year, they should die out and be approached anew each session. Each year, the whole assembly is obligated to devoting time to such matters as appointment of new members of the Economic and Social Council, auditor's reports on U.N. activities and a host of other issues that could be disposed of at the subcommittee level, or simply shelved. ``We don't need so many resolutions,'' said de Marco. ``We need fewer, stronger, much more topical, and much more effective resolutions.'' Spiers and de Marco have been discussing their ideas separately with committee chairman, U.N. officials and ambassadors. ``I've been finding very positive reaction among the delegations,'' de Marco said. ``Wherever you meet delegations, you find that they are all discussing this matter,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Alumni Converge on Denver for 50th Anniversary of Singing Christmas Tree
DOC.TEXT: The yuletide holiday is such a big deal at West High School that even the campus Christmas tree bursts into song. Students at the school normally provide the voices for their Singing Christmas Tree, but this year, in honor of a half-century of song, alumni from the classes of 1940 to 1989 joined in at two weekend concerts. Mothers and fathers who memorized the verses to ``Silent Night'' and ``What Child is This?'' decades ago have been practicing for the reprise since October, some alongside their daughters, sons, nieces and nephews. Alumni representing every year of the tree's last 49 climbed the risers on the 24-foot tree's steel framework to stand between the branches and give the audience what looks like a Christmas tree come to life. Nearly 200 alumni came back for the golden anniversary, the first Singing Christmas Tree reunion since 1982, the school's centennial year. Two former West High music directors - James Fluckey and John Thorin - interrupted their retirements to help coordinate the event. The tradition that has drawn them together this holiday season started when West High teacher Willa Girault saw a singing Christmas tree in Jackson, Miss. At her suggestion, it began in 1940 with 46 singers standing on wooden planks and holding tree branches. ``It's our claim to fame,'' said Fluckey, who as music director from 1955 to 1983 was in charge when the tree was flown to Washington, D.C., for a 1972 performance in front of the White House. ``Every year we'd get people who'd come and say they'd been to the last 20 (concerts) and would never miss it,'' said Thorin, who was at West High from 1970 to 1988. That tradition helped instill a lifelong love of music in Denver resident Bill Keith, one of those back for the reunion. ``I think it all started here,'' said Keith, who was part of the singing Christmas tree from 1943 to 1946. He attended the Juilliard School of Music on a scholarship after graduation from West High and went on to teach music to high school and college students. He was chosen by a panel of off-campus judges to be one of this year's soloists, standing as a star near the top of the tree to sing ``Silent Night.'' In the old days, the student body voted to pick the tree's stars and everybody wanted to be one, said Dale Lechuga of Greeley, one of the stars in the late 1960s. ``There was nothing like it,'' she said. But there were pitfalls to standing near the top, so close to the stage lights, said Janet Kitzman, who recalled that people sometimes passed out up there. Kitzman, who graduated in 1952, is singing with her son and two daughters this year. After 50 years, school officials acknowledge that enthusiasm for the Singing Christmas Tree had dwindled in recent years. West High vocal-music diredtor Stephen Nye had commemorative buttons and sweatshirts made up for 1990 to try to rekindle the old spirit. ``Some of the glow had become tarnished,'' he said, ``so we're trying to renew interest in it. ''

DOC.HEAD: Guerrillas Play Santa Claus, Distribute Hijacked Goodies to Poor
DOC.TEXT: In what they termed ``Operation Yuletide Seizure,'' Communist rebels commandeered a dairy truck, drove it to a Manila slum and handed out butter and cheese. The driver, Marcus Cordero, said three armed rebels flagged down his truck in suburban Quezon city and ordered him to drive to the Santa Mesa district. When they arrived, crowds of people from a squatters' neighborhood had already lined up to receive about $1,140 worth of butter and cheese. Residents of the neighborhood said the rebels tipped them off in advance of Friday's incident to be ready for ``gift-giving.'' The driver and a companion were released unharmed. In a statement to news organizations, the Alex Boncayao Brigade, Manila wing of the communist New People's Army, claimed responsibility for ``Operation Yuletide Seizure.'' ``We undertook this action knowing that in these crises-ridden times the Christmas season has brought nothing but bitterness and additional pressure to the impoverished,'' the brigade said. The incident took place about 1{ miles from President Corazon Aquino's office in the heart of the city. ``We stand by the legitimacy of our actions in the context of the people's protracted war against imperialism and its local minions, the bureaucrat capitalists,'' the brigade said. ``In this light, we hold that the Filipino people have the right to seize from the profiteers the basic goods which are being denied them.''

DOC.HEAD: Vicks VapoRub Still Around, In Same Blue Jar, After 100 Years
DOC.TEXT: One hundred years after a pharmacist mixed the first batch of Magic Croup Salve, later renamed Vicks VapoRub, mothers are still tucking sick children into bed with a smear of the gooey, aromatic concoction. One of America's most enduring cold remedies, Vicks VapoRub still comes in the same distinctive blue jar and still unclogs millions of stuffed noses with its unmistakable vapors. It is little changed from the mix of menthol, camphor and eucalyptus oil in a petrolatum base that Lunsford Richardson created at his Greensboro, N.C., pharmacy in 1890. People under the weather with colds or the flu smear the vaporizing salve on their chests or throats or dab it under their noses for congestion relief. Generations of children recall it as their mothers' favorite cure-all. In the early days, the Richardson family used coffee pots to pour warm salve from large kettles into small jars. Vap-O-Rub salesmen in a fleet of Ford Model T's traveled the countryside searching for customers, tacking advertisements high up on barns and trees with ladders provided for the job. Today, Vicks VapoRub is sold in more than 100 countries and is made at more than a dozen plants around the world, from its birthplace in North Carolina to factories in Mexico, India and Australia. More than 1 million gallons of VapoRub are sold worldwide each year, according to its maker, Richardson-Vicks Inc. Nearly 4 out of 5 Americans have used the product at one time and if every container ever sold in the United States were laid side to side, they could circle the globe twice. But as VapoRub enters its 100th year of fighting colds, Richardson-Vicks is trying to stem a long sales decline by touting it as something more than an old-fashioned remedy. U.S. sales of VapoRub began falling off in the late 1960s as consumers began turning to new over-the-counter cold remedies once available only by prescription, said Debra Bennetts, spokeswoman for Richardson-Vicks at its Connecticut headquarters. In 1967, Richardson-Vicks introduced NyQuil, a nighttime cold medicine that is now the company's top seller. VapoRub sales kept falling in the 1980s, dropping by nearly 10 percent in 1987-88 to a level maintained for the next two years, Bennetts said. The company, acquired by The Proctor & Gamble Co. in 1985, would not provide actual sales figures. But sales appear to be better this year thanks to an ad campaign aimed at older people unable to take oral decongestants and cough remedies because they take medication for heart disease or high blood pressure. ``Who cares if you've got high blood pressure and catch a cold?'' the ad reads. ``We care.'' VapoRub's early success was due as much to the marketing skills of Richardson's son, Smith Richardson, as to its formula. The elder Lunsford Richardson formed the Vick Family Remedies Co. in 1905 to manufacture and sell his line of 21 home remedies, but his son convinced him to concentrate solely on the original product. He renamed the salve VapoRub to dramatize its aromatic characteristics. Sales reached $50,000 a year by 1910. The compny could afford to buy a fleet of Model T Fords for its salesmen, who used ladders provided by the firm to tack signs on barns and trees - an early form of billboard advertising. Heading north, Richardson used a different marketing strategy: newspaper ads resembling news articles that were accompanied by coupons for free Vap-O-Rub Salve. The ads did not make any outrageous claims, like those for many medical remedies of the day. The epidemic of Spanish influenza near the end of World War I led to a nearly fivefold increase in sales in three years. The company began expanding into foreign markets in the 1920s, and by the end of the decade, was selling VapoRub in 60 nations. It began to diversify in the 1930s, when it introduced its cough and nose drops.

DOC.HEAD: University Wrestles with Jewish Identity
DOC.TEXT: The alarm first sounded three years ago when one of Brandeis University's dining halls started serving pork and shellfish. Now the departure of the school's president has heightened debate over the school's Jewish identity. One Jewish scholar argues that the changes made by President Evelyn Handler symbolized something not only about the school but about choices Jews have to make in American society. ``Brandeis University has been struggling with what could be seen, in a complex way, as this temptation to assimilate,'' Gordon Fellman, an associate professor of sociology, wrote in the November-December edition of Tikkun, a liberal Jewish publication based in Oakland, Calif. Founded in 1948, the year Israel became a state, Brandeis was named after Justice Louis D. Brandeis, the first Jew on the U.S. Supreme Court. The school's Jewish founders wanted it to be nonsectarian, like Harvard and Notre Dame. The school today has an enrollment of 3,600 and an endowment of $150 million. In recent years, the student body was estimated to be 65 percent Jewish; a school spokesman said he didn't know what that percentage is now. Handler became the university's fifth president in 1983 and encountered criticism in 1987 over changes in the dining hall and the school's logo. The menu change officially was billed as internationalizing the cuisine, Fellman said. Brandeis had always maintained one dining hall for kosher students and another hall for others. But while the non-kosher hall would serve milk with meat, violating strict Jewish dietary laws, it did not serve meat considered impure in the Jewish tradition until 1987. At about the same time, Brandeis removed the Hebrew word for truth from the school's logo, Fellman said, and the university calendar dropped references to Jewish holidays. Amid a campus outcry, the logo and holiday references have been restored. Handler announced in June that she would resign at the end of this school year. She's now on sabbatical. She has refused to discuss her decision to step down. ``I'm not prepared to talk to you over the telephone or any other place,'' she said when asked for an interview. David Rosen, a university spokesman, said members of the Brandeis community blew changes in the dining hall and the school logo out of proportion. ``I think it's grossly unfair to suggest that she was trying to disavow that (Jewish) heritage, but the controversy was cast in those terms by some people,'' he said. ``These are all very terrible misunderstandings. They were all just a bum rap.'' He said Handler stressed the school's nonsectarian philosophy and was seen as attempting to attract students from more diverse backgrounds. She also tried to attract more donors to the school, which largely relies on the American Jewish community. This year, the school has had to institute a hiring freeze and cuts in spending to make up a $3 million budget gap. The philosophy of the university has changed under the interim president as it conducts a search for Handler's replacement, Rosen said. ``I think the current interim president, Stuart Altman, while reaffirming the interest in diversity, has also felt a need to be more open and forthcoming about the Jewish heritage than Dr. Handler did,'' he said. Fellman said the debate may be healthy for the school. ``I think part of what Handler did inadvertently was to surface the issue of Jewishness among many of us,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Condemned Inmates Draw Christmas Cards
With PM-Moore's Church, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The assortment of 12 Christmas cards includes smiling Santas and bouquets of holly wrapped in messages of love, an angel of peace playing a flute, a pair of doves floating above mistletoe and fir. No doubt greeting cards drawn by professional artists, you say? No. They were crafted on Death Row by 10 inmates, two of whom have been executed since their ink drawings first were published. Before his death in September 1987 for killing a probation officer, Joseph Starvaggi envisioned the spirit of Christmas as a floating angel playing the flute as the Star of Bethlehem shines through her wing. Starvaggi's Angel of Hope is the second most popular card. The most frequently ordered Death Row design was drawn by Bob Black, 43, convicted for the 1985 contract slaying of his wife. His sketch shows an inmate hunched over a Bible inside a prison cell, barren except for a paper Christmas tree and paper star taped to the wall. The cards are marketed by Help Our Prisoners Exist, a support group for Death Row inmates and their families that advocates the abolition of capital punishment. The 12-card assortment sells for $8. ``The cards show that Death Row inmates are sensitive human beings,'' said Ken Robison, a stepfather of a Death Row inmate and HOPE co-founder. ``A person influenced by drugs or alcohol or mental illness or passionate rage can commit a terrible crime. We can't diminish that fact,'' Robison said. ``That does not take away from the fact that they are caring, creative people and they have a message.''

DOC.HEAD: 10 on Fishing Boat Crew Missing After Typhoon Russ
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS in 3 grafs with search suspended, no sight of missing; pick up 4th graf, `The Marguarita ...'.
DOC.TEXT: The Coast Guard today called off a search for 10 crew members of a South Korean fishing boat missing for three days since Typhoon Russ swept the area, officials said. A military transport ship located the partially submerged hull of the 68-foot Marguarita I 35 miles off the southern tip of Guam on Sunday, but there was no sign of the crew, the Coast Guard said. The Coast Guard cutter Assateague and a C130 aircraft searched a 19,000-square-mile area but didn't locate any crew members, said Lt. Bob Ritchie of the Coast Guard Rescue Center on this U.S. island territory in the Western Pacific. He said the search was called off today. The Marguarita I sailed from Agana on Thursday, even though it was well known the typhoon was bearing down on the island, said Coast Guard Lt. Jeffrey Lee, duty officer for the Joint Rescue Coordination Center in Honolulu. The fishing vessel radioed its agent here late Thursday that it was disabled with a clutch problem, Lee said. Communication with the boat was lost Friday when electrical power went out on Guam as Typhoon Russ battered the island with wind up to 150 mph. Federal Emergency Management Agency officials said the storm damged or destroyed more than 2,000 homes and injured 88 people. No deaths were reported. Guam Power Authority officials said they expected to have electrical power restored to 60 percent of the island today. Water service remained disrupted in many areas because pumps were without electrical power. Gov. Joseph Ada has asked President Bush to declare the island a disaster area.

DOC.HEAD: Christmas Often Brings Out Worst In Kids
With PM-Moore's Church, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: When the materialistic side of Christmas rears its ugly head, child psychologists admit it often has a child's face. Never mind visions of sugar plums. For many children, the only things dancing in their heads - with all the resolution of a Nintendo or TURBO-Grafx-16 home video game - are dreams of Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, Batman and Go-Go My Walking Pup. Experts on child development call it a natural process for youngsters to want things. At around age 2, they say, the average child says ``mine'' about everything in view. It's only over time that they develop a sense of what is theirs and what belongs to others. ``To learn how to give they first have to learn what it feels like to be recipients - of love or gifts or whatever, so you could consider it a developmental process,'' said Caroline Persell, head of the sociology department at New York University. ``If it's sort of a stage that people have to go through, hopefully they get beyond it when they see some of the fun of thinking of gifts for other people. That's part of the fun of Christmas.'' But don't most children think 'tis better to receive than to give? ``I think kids from a very young age are capable of being totally selfish,'' said Martin Hoffman, head of the NYU psychology department. ``But they are also capable of being quite empathic and sympathetic toward others who do not have what they have.'' The problem, Hoffman said, is not that children are inherently selfish, but that Christmas thrusts them into a context that surrounds them with all sorts of neat things they would like to have. And they usually respond with according materialism, even greed. But change the context, and the same child might offer a pleasant surprise. ``Most kids, as greedy and self oriented as they appear when they go to visit Santa in the department stores and sit on his lap and ask for everything under the sun, if put into the position of knowing that there are other children who have nothing - and if there are adults around who make the suggestion that they might want to share some of their things - most kids would share a lot,'' Hoffman said. Hoffman explained that children, and parents too, are bombarded by television commercials that put them in the context of gift getters, rarely as potential givers. But it needn't be that way, Hoffman asserts. In that sense, Hoffman said, children reflect American society as a whole. ``This whole American culture is probably the most materialistic culture in the history of humankind. On the other hand it is also a very giving culture.''

DOC.HEAD: Two U.S. Sailors Killed When Tour Bus Overturns
With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Two sailors from the aircraft carrier USS Midway were killed when a tour bus they were on overturned, the military's Joint Information Bureau said today. Five other U.S. sailors were injured, of whom two were in serious condition in the accident Sunday about 50 miles south of al-Dhafra airbase in Abu Dhabi. The sailors were on shore leave, taking an off-road tour in an all-terrain bus when the accident occurred, the military said. The statement said the cause of the accident was under investigation. A Navy spokesman said that because of the remoteness of the area, helicopters from the Midway flew to the scene to assist local authorities. One of the injured was flown to the hospital ship USS Comfort and three to the Midway. The whereabouts of the fifth were not immediately known. The names of the dead and injured were being withheld, pending notification of next of kin. The accident brought the number of U.S. deaths in Operation Desert Shield to 80. On Saturday in the Mediterranean, a chartered Israeli ferry carrying U.S. sailors capsized while returning to the USS Saratoga from the Israeli port of Haifa, killing 21. It was the singe largest death toll from accidents related to the operation. Five other Western military personnel have also died. The Midway, currently deployed mainly in the Arabian Sea, was on a port visit to Abu Dhabi.

DOC.HEAD: S.F. Mayor Will Sign Landmark VDT Law, Aides Say
DOC.TEXT: Businesses will have up to four years instead of two to provide safer equipment and working conditions for video display terminal users, under a compromise Mayor Art Agnos has agreed to sign, his aides say. What was hailed as the nation's toughest VDT law won final approval last week from the city Board of Supervisors, but Agnos wouldn't commit to signing it until he talked to business and labor groups about its impact and cost. After a weekend meeting with Agnos, the two sides agreed Saturday to several amendments, one extending the compliance period from two years to as many as four years, the mayor's aides said. The compromise, which Agnos plans to sign Thursday, must go back to the supervisors for approval. ``This is an example of what happens when both sides come to the table. And we now have something that both sides can live with,'' said Claude Everhart, deputy mayor for government operations, who mediated the negotiations. The compromise measure still calls for frequent work breaks, proper lighting, anti-glare screens, adjustable computer furniture and equipment to make VDT use safer. Among the problems associated with regular work at a computer keyboard are nerve damage to the wrists and fingers, back and neck strain, eye strain, sleep disturbances, chronic headaches, nausea and fatigue. Labor leaders hope the VDT law will be a model for other cities and counties in California and for the state and other states nationwide. Business groups have consistently opposed efforts to pass such legislation because of its expense and because some doubt VDT use causes health problems. City budget analysts estimate businesses will spend as much as $76.5 million and the city as much as $6 million to comply with the law. The board on Dec. 17 passed the ordinance on a 7-4 vote, just short of the eight votes needed to override an Agnos veto. At Saturday's eight-hour meeting, business and labor leaders agreed to implement the law in three stages. First, any new equipment purchased one year or more after the law is adopted must conform to the new standards. Within 30 months, businesses must bring most workstations into conformance with VDT safety standards. If doing so costs more than $250, those businesses will have an additional 18 months to comply. The law applies to companies with 15 or more employees. It also creates an advisory panel to monitor research about possible radiation hazards and other heath effects from VDT use.

DOC.HEAD: Bacteria Found That Remove Contaminants From Radioactive Waste Water
DOC.TEXT: Scientists have discovered harmless bacteria that can remove radioactive contaminants from waste water, a report published today said.
