DOC.HEAD: Relatives of Murder Victims Mourn as Holiday Approaches
DOC.TEXT: Christmas can be a recurring nightmare for people who have lost close relatives to violent crimes. ``We haven't put up a tree in three years,'' said Rocky Pennington, whose two daughters, Cheryl Genzer, 25, and Lisa Pennington, 16, were murdered Sept. 23, 1987. ``We don't have any reason to celebrate.'' To cope, Pennington and more than two dozen others met last week for a Christmas gathering by a group called Survivors of Homicide. At the gathering, Jerry and Debbie Maguire sat quietly, grief and disbelief still frozen on their faces. This will be their first Christmas without children Justin, 14, and Sammie, 11, who were found shot and gagged in a closet in their El Reno home on July 14. This also will be the first Christmas for Ken Busch without his 7-year-old daughter, Kathy, who was stabbed to death and left in a trash bin in Yukon last February. Busch said he would celebrate Christmas, if only for the sake of his two remaining children. ``I wish I could sleep right through this,'' Busch said. ``It's going to be difficult, and I really want Kathy to be here. But I have to go on for the living.'' Judy Busch, Kathy's grandmother, acted as the group's moderator. She founded the group Sept. 3 with the help of Robert Brown, an Oklahoma City counselor. ``We need to realize we are doing all right - that we are going to get through this,'' Mrs. Busch said. ``It's not been easy; there are a lot of things to think about during this holiday.'' Pennington and his wife, Charlet, are spending the holiday season in court, ``taunted,'' Pennington says, by the legal system, the media and the man accused of killing their daughters. ``We have to go into that courtroom and that creep just grins at us, forcing us to brush past him as we walk in,'' Pennington said. ``He claims he has religion - he says God has forgiven him - but I won't forgive him.'' John and Bonnie Krueger's 31-year-old son, Randy, was found dead of a gunshot to the head June 9. They suspect Randy was murdered. ``We're in total limbo,'' Krueger said. ``Emotionally, you just can't cope. The family tells you to forget, but then the police ask you to remember every little detail.'' ``How are you supposed to forget?'' Mrs. Krueger asked. ``When I was putting up the Christmas tree, I found Randy's first grade pictures.'' Family members should not forget, Brown said. ``Something that we do different here is that we focus on the victims' lives prior to the murder,'' Brown said. ``So much of what they remember of the victim is the murder. So much of what they are focused on is that dark day,'' he said. ``This helps them get the victim's life into perspective.''

DOC.HEAD: Township Blaze Kills One, Destroys 70 Homes
DOC.TEXT: Fire raced through a township outside Cape Town, killing one man and destroying 70 homes, police said. The fire broke out early Sunday in Khayelitsha. The township has been the scene of widespread political unrest, but police spokesman Jan Calitz said there was no sign the fire was arson. A statement from fire officials reported the cause as ``smoking material igniting bedding.'' Police said the blaze started in the home of D. Mahanwana, who was found burned to death in the shack. The township is home to tens of thousands of blacks, most of whom live in ramshackle dwellings.

DOC.HEAD: Iran Says It Arrests Thousands Of Drug Traffickers, Addicts
DOC.TEXT: More than 1,900 alleged drug traffickers and 16,000 addicts were arrested in Iran in a five-week nationwide sweep, Tehran radio reported Monday. The broadcast, monitored in Nicosia, quoted the Komiteh, the organization responsible for internal security, as saying that more than 1,653 pounds of various drugs were confiscated in the crackdown. The radio said 57 guns and 80 vehicles also were seized. Iranian law calls for a mandatory death sentence for possession of drugs. More than 1,500 people accused of drug trafficking have been hanged in the past two years, and more than 100,000 people accused of being addicts have been sent to hard labor camps. Iranian opposition groups and independent human rights organizations claim the executions actually are carried out to crush political opposition.

DOC.HEAD: Former Times Crossword Editor Dead at 77
DOC.TEXT: Edmund Akenhead, for 18 years the editor of the crossword puzzle in The Times of London, has died at age 77, the newspaper reported Monday. Akenhead, who died Saturday, joined his family's law firm in Newport in 1936. After war service in the Glider Pilot Regiment he took a legal post in the Colonial Service in Dar-es-Salaam, in what is now Tanzania, where he began setting crosswords for the Tanganyika Standard. Returning to England, he became the third editor of The Times' crossword in 1965. The Times's obituary said: ``He began the practice of returning edited puzzles to their compilers with detailed reasons for his alterations, which quickly produced a consistent standard of excellence from his team of 10 compilers, most of whom he himself recruited. ``He allowed no sloppiness of thought or expression: `As a lawyer I cannot pass IOU as meaning debt. It is evidence of acknowledgment of debt'; or `The dictionaries do not define okapi as a giraffe. The fact that it is related to the giraffe does not make it one.''' Akenhead retired from the Times in 1983. His coat of arms, granted by the College of Heralds in 1989, incorporated a miniature crossword puzzle. He is survived by his wife and two sons. Funeral arrangements were not announced.

DOC.HEAD: Police Arrest Man Demanding Return Of Smuggled Heroin
DOC.TEXT: Police on Monday said they had arrested a Lebanese man who filed a complaint demanding the return of a lost suitcase full of heroin. A police spokesman said on condition of anonymity that Jamal Dahman, 31, of Tripoli was arrested Saturday after trying to retrieve a suitcase containing 5{ pounds of heroin from Athens Airport's lost-and-found office. Dahman had lodged a formal complaint and demanded the suitcase be returned after it was lost upon his arrival from Damascus, Syria, on Dec. 15. The suitcase arrived from the Persian Gulf emirate of Abu Dhabi on Saturday, and police dogs discovered the heroin. According to the police spokesman, Dahman made repeated phone calls to the airport, and police waited for him to come and pick up the bag. The spokesman said police believed Dahman was a member of an international drug smuggling ring. Dahman told police he was to deliver the bag to an unidentified buyer in Athens, the official said. The heroin has a street value of $330,000.

DOC.HEAD: 82nd Airborne Runs Away the Christmas Blues
LaserPhoto DHR3
DOC.TEXT: Santa Claus sat near the starting cannon and a military band played Christmas carols Monday while soldiers of the 82nd Airborne enjoyed a five-mile Jingle Bell Jog. The run was part of a day off that included music, volleyball, a talent show and Christmas Eve services that were off-limits to the media because of Saudi Arabia's strict religious laws. ``Christmas is where the heart is, and in the 82nd Airborne Division, everybody's heart is in the right place,'' said the Santa Claus, Lt. Col. Bob Murphy, 43, of Fayetteville, N.C. He was dressed in a Santa suit, complete with white whiskers and black boots. He handed out razor blades, candy, Frisbees, yo-yos and other gifts stashed in a brown garbage can liner. ``Sure, we'd love to be home with our loved ones, but, my gosh, we got an important mission to do over here,'' Murphy said. ``Right now, we're at peace. That's the reason we're here - to preserve that peace.'' The Army division's band, led by Chief Warrant Officer Willie James Lockett, played ``Deck The Halls'' to entertain the troops. ``We're doing this so the soldier won't be lonely and think about what it's like back in the world where he isn't,'' said Lockett, 35, of Jacksonville, Fla., a 17-year Army veteran. ``My Christmas tree will be up whenever I get back. ``If it's the year 2002, that sucker will still be up.'' Chief Warrant Officer Ben Cooper, 30, of Monticello, Ark., finished first in the jog with a time of 24 minutes, 31 seconds. Keeping busy helped keep his mind off his wife and three kids back home. ``You try to stay occupied instead of sitting around moping (and) thinking about how bad off you are,'' Cooper said. Capt. Michael Thomas, 30, of Trenton, N.J., ran the race wearing a Santa's cap and a pair of Bart Simpson shorts. He's been away from home six times in the past eight years. He even saw a bright spot in spending Christmas in the desert. ``Actually, out here, we're away from the commercial side of Christmas,'' he said. ``You have to look inside yourself to find the real Christmas spirit.'' Lt. Lisa Titus, 27, of the Army's 18th Airborne Corps got time off to run the race with her husband, Greg, a captain who commands a battery of artillery with the 82nd Airborne. She sat on Santa's lap but didn't make a Christmas wish. ``I didn't need a present because my husband's already here,'' she said. However, the couple left their 14-month-old son, Lance, with a nanny back in Grand Rapids, Mich. ``That's probably the worst part, being separated,'' she said. ``A lot of people made a lot of sacrifices to be here. We'll make it up when we get home.''

DOC.HEAD: Oops! Museum Puts on Show of Illustrator's Flops
LaserPhoto AB1
DOC.TEXT: He's famous for his homespun eloquence and the puckish charm of his portraits of young Americans making their way in the 20th century. But even Norman Rockwell occasionally goofed. From an unflattering portrait of a cow's posterior to a baseball study with the umpire looking the wrong way, works that Rockwell banished to a drawer are getting a second look in a new exhibit at the Norman Rockwell Museum. It's called ``Flops!'' ``It was sort of as a joke the idea started,'' said curator Maureen Hart Hennessey. But after it began to take shape, organizers realized the exhibit, which takes its title from a chapter in Rockwell's autobiography, showed a new side of the illustrator and shook up the museum's routine. ``I think sometimes there's a tendency to think that we're some kind of shrine to Rockwell and that's not true,'' she said. Of his own work, Rockwell wrote that sometimes he found ``I've been molding a handful of air.'' But some of the pictures hanging in a room of the little white house that houses the museum hardly seem to merit Rockwell's scorn. ``We're not saying that these things are flops,'' Hennessey said. Guides occasionally ask visitors if they agree with Rockwell's assessment of his work. ``It's raised a lot of good questions for us.'' One piece dominates the room: a large panoramic mural of the Soviet, British and U.S. ambassadors sitting at a session of the U.N. Security Council. Behind them crowd about 70 figures, representing everyone from a typical U.S. family to starving children of the world. In his autobiography, ``My Adventures as an Illustrator,'' Rockwell tells of his travails with the work. He said he could not persuade U.S. Ambassador Henry Cabot Lodge to smile and couldn't stop Soviet delegate Andrei Vishinsky from beaming. But eventually, wrote Rockwell, the work seemed ``empty and pretentious.'' For another ``flop,'' Rockwell went to the trouble of staging baseball players Stan Musial and Joe Garagiola for a picture of a burly umpire daintily sweeping home plate. All went well until Rockwell realized that a real umpire would never face the pitcher, turning his backside to the grandstand. One of the flops simply failed to find an audience. For a Saturday Evening Post cover that was supposed to be a whodunit, Rockwell posed several famous actors, ranging from Ethel Barrymore to Lassie. All that was visible of the victim, Van Johnson, was a pair of legs with spats protruding from beneath a table. Visual cues tip off the astute viewer to the method and murderer. But the Post decided it just wasn't ``up to scratch,'' Rockwell wrote. ``The movie stars kill it,'' the editors said. ``The readers will be so busy recognizing the stars that the idea will be lost.'' What the failed pictures may show is an artist uncomfortable with famous subjects, Hennessey said. ``He says in his autobiography that he was more comfortable staying in his own back yard and painting his neighbors,'' she said. Out of a seven-decade career that produced more than 3,000 works, Rockwell spent the last 25 years of his life in Stockbridge, immortalizing the town's picturesque New England setting and several of its residents. The small exhibit of flops, which opened in November and runs through January 1992, has been ``getting a chuckle from very serious people,'' said museum spokeswoman Beatrice Snyder. Perhaps the funniest picture in the room is a calendar illustration called Mrs. O'Leary's Cow. The cow is craning its neck to peer at a lighted lamp within striking distance of her left hind hoof. ``Turned out to be my worst failure,'' Rockwell observed in his book. ``Not that it was a bad painting. But who wants to look at the rear end of a cow for twelve months?''

DOC.HEAD: Priest Jailed 26 Years Rejoices in Christmas
LaserPhoto XTIR2
DOC.TEXT: The chapel is simple, and the pews are planks propped on stones. After nearly 26 years in jail in a country he calls ``the hell of the world,'' a Christmas dream has come true for the leader of Albania's Roman Catholics. For the first time since 1967, when Albania became the only Communist state to outlaw religion, Simon Jubani and thousands of his flock can gather to celebrate the birth of Jesus. Greek Orthodox believers in southern Albania have opened three churches. Moslems are repairing some of the few mosques that survived state efforts to wipe out religion. Moslems make up about 70 percent of Albanian believers; another 20 percent are Orthodox and 10 percent are Catholic. The miraculous change in believers' fortunes came in November, after the ruling Communists lifted the ban on religion as part of limited reforms in the isolated, backward land of 3.3 million people. Young people in Shkodra who had dared to preserve their Catholic faith took over this small chapel in a rundown cemetery. Since Nov. 4, Jubani said, Mass has been celebrated every day. From 1,000 to 2,000 people flock daily to the chapel on the city boulevard named for the father of Stalinist Albania, Enver Hoxha. Jubani was jailed eight times for nearly 26 years on charges of propagandizing against the atheist Communism brutally imposed by Hoxha. He was surprised when the government freed him in April 1989, and he began celebrating Mass in secret in his home. Without the changes wrought in the Communist world by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Jubani said, he would have served out the remaining 20 years of his last sentence. Asked how he survived jails in which he said at least 100 Roman Catholic priests had died, Jubani said he was sustained by faith in the traditional Catholicism of Shkodra. ``As Byzantine power could not do anything to us for 900 years, and Ottoman power could not do anything for 500 years, so the Communists also could do nothing to us,'' the 63-year-old priest said with a smile. Shkodra, he said, ``is like an oasis in the Albanian desert.'' Shkodra is reputedly one of Europe's oldest cities, and was for centuries a center of Catholicism. Under Hoxha, it decayed as funds flowed south to his hometown of Gjirokaster near the Greek border. Reported unrest in Shkodra earlier this year - and perhaps the influence of Hoxha's successor, Ramiz Alia, a Shkodra native - have led the Communists to pay more attention to Albania's third city of about 80,000. But that was not sufficient to quell an explosion of popular anger this month after Alia announced that other political parties would be permitted after 46 years of one-party rule. A Hoxha statue was blown up, local Communist headquarters and the radio station vandalized and hundreds of windows smashed before security forces intervened. ``We are living in political chaos,'' said Jubani, referring to the turmoil and hatred that could be unleashed by the Communists' reforms. His chapel is a haven of humanity, and believers have given it the spirit of Christmas. One carefully painted a wooden altarpiece. Another brought Virgin Mary portraits and other artifacts Jubani said were hidden from the Communists ``by the religious spirit always in our hearts.'' Other believers proudly showed a nativity scene. ``Albania is the hell of the world,'' Jubani said, referring to the Communist rule of terror that he said extended even to pulling gold from the teeth of corpses in Shkodra cemeteries. The Communists ``built here in Albania their kingdom of ignorance, their kingdom of poverty, their kingdom of immorality,'' Jubani said. Now, the first opposition group, the Democratic Party, has asked for his support. Jubani demanded in return that the new party pledge to help restore all churches, schools and monasteries to Catholics. Albania's believers also need Bibles and money to restore churches that have survived 23 years as warehouses or cattle sheds. Shkodra's Roman Catholics got back one church last week. Still to come is the former cathedral, currently used as a sports hall adorned with Communist slogans. For now, however, it is enough simply to celebrate Christ's birth. ``For the first time in 23 years, there will be midnight Mass,'' Jubani said, beaming, as he bade farewell to foreign reporters. ``Merry Christmas.''

DOC.HEAD: Maine Begins Far-reaching Bottle Recycling
DOC.TEXT: Maine consumers will become the nation's busiest recyclers next Monday, when the state's bottle deposit law is expanded to include nearly all non-dairy beverage containers. Even though Maine residents will have to rinse, save and return more bottles and cans than ever, they seem to be taking the new law in stride. ``It will probably be more of a nuisance in a sense,'' said Charlene Haney of Caribou. ``I suppose once you get used to it, it will be all right.'' Mrs. Haney said the need to reduce the mountains of throwaways filling landfills more than justifies the extra burden. ``I understand why they're doing this,'' she said. For more than a decade, Maine residents have been paying deposits on beer and soda containers under a law designed to reduce litter. But with the advent of the solid waste crisis, the law took on new meaning. A comprehensive solid waste law expanded the ``bottle law'' to include liquor bottles as of Jan. 1, 1990, and wine bottles on Sept. 1, 1990. Aseptic containers, or ``juice boxes,'' were banned in Maine as of September. As of Dec. 31, the bottle law will include all non-carbonated juice containers holding a gallon or less. Deposits are 5 cents, except on liquor and wine bottles, which carry a 15-cent deposit. Excluded are containers for milk and other dairy products, cider, cough syrup, sauces, baby formula, soup and vinegar. Maine's new law, considered the nation's most expansive, will increase by as much as 50 percent the 600 million tons of beverage containers already in the recycling stream, according to Denise Lord of the Maine Waste Management Agency. ``We're geared up for it,'' said Gary Hilliard, president of Returnable Services Inc., whose company accepts, pays refunds and sorts used bottles and cans before taking them to centers that recycle plastic, metal and glass. Hilliard added space to his Augusta warehouse by tearing out closets and using overhead room, but he acknowledges that he may have to build an addition. Besides adding to the volume of containers being recycled and kept out of dumps, Maine's law is also creating a new line of business for companies such as Hilliard's. Juice makers are hiring those companies to pick up their brands' containers from restaurants and other retailers and take them to recycling centers. Beer and soda manufacturers in Maine generally do that themselves. Ms. Lord said the law also has social benefits: ``We're seeing a real increase in the number of community organizations using bottle drives as fund-raisers.'' Other states are watching carefully to see how Maine's law works out, said Pat Franklin of the National Container Recycling Coalition, a Washington, D.C.-based advocacy group. Various components of Maine's law have been adopted in other states, but Maine's law is the most comprehensive, she said. A few kinks in the law remain to be worked out. It's not clear, for example, whether grocers or companies hired to pick up empties must sort containers by manufacturer. But that won't delay the new law, even though a ruling by the state isn't expected until January, said John Joyce of the Maine Grocers Association. The law is expected to cause some manufacturers to pull products that sell poorly in Maine, said Joyce. Other products may disappear briefly if manufacturers decide not to use temporary stickers while cans and bottles are being redesigned with marks showing they are returnable.

DOC.HEAD: Luxury Buyers Rushing to Beat New Tax on Jan. 1
DOC.TEXT: When H.A. Sinclaire eased his new $34,000 Christmas-red Audi 100 Quattro out of a Northern Virginia showroom recently, he did so a few months earlier than he had planned - and saved $400 in taxes. All over the country, well-to-do people like Sinclaire are rushing to buy before the federal government begins Jan. 1 imposing a new tax on fancy cars and other luxury items. ``If I can avoid paying taxes, I try,'' said Sinclaire, a retired physician who lives in horse country around Middleburg, Va., just outside Washington. ``I don't like how they're spending most of my money anyway.'' As a gathering recession compels many Americans to curtail their purchases, some of the country's tonier establishments are noticing a surge in spending among upper-crust shoppers eager to beat the tax. The strength of the trend varies by product. But luxury-item retailers and manufacturers hope it will help sweeten what generally has been a lackluster buying season. ``Probably 30 percent of our customers are coming and saying it's a factor in their decision,'' said Michael Sclafani, vice president of Sovereign Motor Cars Ltd. in Brooklyn, N.Y., which sells Mercedes-Benz's. Neiman Marcus spokeswoman Pat Zajac says that sales managers at the company's 24 upscale department stores report increased purchases of expensive furs and jewelry - both of which will be subject to the new tax. At the firm's Dallas store recently, she said, a man ready to buy an $11,000 fur decided to buy a $22,000 one instead when he learned of the tax savings. The trend is most noticeable in the automobile industry, where new levies will drive up the price of some cars by thousands of dollars. Independent auto analyst Susan Jacobs of Little Falls, N.J., said top-end cars are showing increased sales in November - with BMW and Jaguar sales up about 25 percent over October - reversing a months-long decline. The swelling business is, in part, courtesy of a luxury tax in the budget package Congress and President Bush enacted in the fall. Beginning Jan. 1, it slaps a 10 percent tax on the amount paid above $30,000 for cars, $100,000 for private boats, $250,000 for private planes, and $10,000 for jewelry and furs. The government expects to reap $1.5 billion from the levy over the next five years. The stakes are even greater for people shopping for cars that get low gasoline mileage, which tend to be European imports. The gas-guzzler tax, now ranging between $500 and $3,850, will be doubled Jan. 1. Meanwhile, many merchants - especially auto and boat dealers - are advertising that customers can avoid the tax by acting quickly. ``On January 1, the tax man will be fishing for an extra 10 percent,'' announced Hatteras Yachts of High Point, N.C., in a recent Wall Street Journal ad. Hatteras' boats sell for $350,000 to $6 million. That means someone who buys before Jan. 1 will save at least $25,000 in taxes. ``The type of person in a position in life to buy our product didn't get there by taking money for granted,'' said Hatteras marketing director Bryant Phillips. But not all luxury businesses are enjoying a pre-levy rush of customers. Chairman Michael Roman of Jewelers of America, a trade association representing 13,000 jewelry retailers, says his industry's $20 billion annual income has been affected little by purchasers hoping to save money on the tax. ``Most jewelry purchases are to commemorate an event, so you're buying with your heart,'' Roman said. Pittsburgh, Pa., furrier Carl Herrmann said the slow economy and the uncertainty of the Persian Gulf crisis has canceled any business boost from buyers eager to avoid the tax. ``There's a three-letter word sitting over peoples' heads - war,'' said Herrmann. As for buying before the tax is imposed, he said, ``I haven't heard that once.'' The nation's private aircraft makers seem barely affected by the new tax, because about 90 percent of the 1,500 planes sold annually will avoid the levy anyway, said James Gormley, president of the industry's trade group. Planes that are used mainly for business or cost less than $250,000 will be exempt.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Keep `Socialist' In Country's Name
LaserPhoto MOSB6
DOC.TEXT: After an emotional vote to keep ``socialist'' in the country's name, the Soviet Congress on Monday endorsed the concept of a new Union Treaty to keep the nation from breaking apart. The national parliament also voted to require every republic to hold a referendum asking its residents whether they want to remain in a restructured union. Lawmakers later approved President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's proposal for a national referendum to decide whether to scrap Communist ideology and allow private ownership of land. The 2,250-member Congress of People's Deputies charged the Supreme Soviet, the smaller standing legislature which it elects, to draft the precise wording of both referenda and set dates for them. Officials said votes on the private property referendum would be counted separately in each republic. But it was unclear whether a few republics could permit private property if the majority did not. The legislature of the republic of Russia, which encompasses three-quarters of the Soviet land mass, already has approved private property. Boris Yeltsin, Russia's president and Gorbachev's main political rival, has said there is no need for a referendum. Alexander Zhuravlev, a deputy from the Byelorussian capital of Minsk, set off hisses and a raucous debate by suggesting the Soviet Union rename itself simply ``Russia.'' A legislative committee had proposed changing the country's name from the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics to the ``Union of Sovereign Soviet Republics'' to reflect the republics' growing autonomy. Urging the Congress to ``take a holy act'' the day before Christmas, Zhuravlev said ``our fatherland is Russian, and so I propose that we call ourselves as we did in the past: Russia.'' Leningrad Mayor Anatoly Sobchak proposed instead that the Congress adopt the name favored by the late Nobel Prize winning dissident Andrei Sakharov: ``The Union of Soviet Republics of Europe and Asia.'' Other delegates chipped in with ``Union of Soviet Republics'' and ``The Treaty Between Russia and Its Colonies.'' Congress chairman Anatoly Lukyanov cut off the heated debate, telling the deputies to ``put your emotions back in your pockets.'' The Congress then voted 1,365-189 with 170 abstentions to retain the name Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. Immediately after the vote, a delegate who did not identify himself rose to object that it was meaningless. ``We have voted for socialism. But what kind of socialism?'' he said. ``Stalinist socialism? Brezhnev-type socialism? Ration-card socialism? Or Swedish socialism? No matter what we name our country, we still need to define its economic system.'' The deputies paid no heed to his criticism, and proceeded to endorse the general concept of a new Union Treaty proposed by Gorbachev to hold the independence-minded republics together in a loose federation. The Congress' vote of 1,491-88 with 141 abstentions is not binding. The treaty, which would replace the 1922 document that formally created the Soviet Union, must be adopted by the legislatures of the 15 republics. In the past year, all 15 republics have declared some form of political independence or economic autonomy in which their laws take precedence over national ones. In the referendum envisioned by the Congress, citizens across the country will vote on the general question of whether their republics should stay in the Soviet Union, and not on a specific treaty. Republics that vote not to remain in the Soviet Union still would not gain immediate independence. Gorbachev has insisted they follow a complicated secession law approved last spring that includes a waiting period of up to five years. Parliaments of several republics, including Georgia, Lithuania, Latvia, Estonia and Armenia, have said they will not sign a new Union Treaty. Gorbachev's proposed draft would give more economic autonomy to the republics, while retaining a powerful central government in Moscow with control over foreign policy, banking, taxation, defense, transportation and communications. The Congress also approved a resolution on ``the state of the union'' that included a vaguely worded, non-binding endorsement of Gorbachev's proposed changes in the structure of government. Later in the week, the lawmakers are expected to consider specific changes and constitutional amendments needed to put them into effect. Monday's resolution did not spell out Gorbachev's proposals, which include a national Security Council, a vice presidency and a Federation Council made up of leaders of the republics.

DOC.HEAD: Trying to Keep Arctic Refuge Rivers from Being `Loved to Death'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `It took ..., with 3 grafs to UPDATE with comments from Fish and Wildlife official on timetable, range of proposals
DOC.HEAD: LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Wilderness buffs worried about losing the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge's coastal plain to oil drilling have been visiting it in record numbers - and may pose a threat of their own to the fragile area. Environmentalists fear the traffic is straining resources along the refuge's major rivers. Commercial operators worry that hundreds of rafters, hikers and photographers who come to see grizzlies, caribou and untrampled tundra each summer are running into other people, too. ``Rivers like the Hulahula and the Kongakut have lost some of their wilderness character,'' said George Heim of Anchorage-based Alaska River Adventures. ``You're not getting what you go up there for if you end up sharing the river with 20 other people and jockeying for campsites.'' The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, which has received complaints of crowding and litter from river users, has started working on river management plans for the arctic refuge. It took public comment through Dec. 15 on several plans. Phil Garrett, the assistant refuge manager, said Monday that a draft report on the agency's proposal should be done in several months, and a final report should be issued by the end of September 1991. ``It's a complicated issue,'' Garrett said. ``There are several different alternatives and a whole host of choices for each alternative. They range from no regulation to no access by motorized vehicles.'' Fish and Wildlife officials acknowledge that there may be problems in the the refuge. ``When we took a look at the increase of use along selected rivers, it became evident there was some reason for possible concern,'' said Tom Edgerton, the agency's Fairbanks-based recreation planner for the arctic refuge. He stressed that federal officials are trying to prevent potential problems and aren't sure if higher visitor traffic actually is damaging wilderness. ``I haven't seen any documentation that shows damage to wildlife at this point, but it's one of the things that we'll be looking at,'' said Edgerton. He said he has gotten reports of caribou harassed by airplanes and of litter along the rivers. Since 1985, commercial recreational use on the refuge's three major rivers - the Kongakut, Hulahula and Sheenjek - has increased more than 500 percent, from 355 visitors to 1,794 in 1989. The number of visitors on private backpacking, fishing or hunting trips isn't known, Edgerton said. Although those numbers are tiny compared to those at many national parks and refuges, they have a stronger impact in this sensitive region of tundra and short growing seasons. ``The farther north you go, the slower it takes to recover,'' Edgerton said. Many of the environmental groups that oppose drilling on the coastal plain also are calling for greater recreational restrictions, such as keeping group sizes to six and the number of river trips to one a week. ``You certainly want people to be able to get out and enjoy their wilderness, but the downside is people can love a place to death,'' said Sharon Sturges of the environmental goup Trustees for Alaska. Some of the plans, however, would restrict access and activities not just by commercial recreationalists but by hunters, trappers and others who use the arctic refuge. Ed Grasser, a hunting guide who visits the refuge in the off-peak months of August and September, agreed river rafters perhaps should be restricted to ease crowding. But he said his business shouldn't be limited unless wildlife populations are shown to have suffered. ``It's public land, and as long as visitation is regulated to the point where habitat or wildlife aren't being harmed, I don't think it's right to prohibit people from visiting simply because a small group of people have an aesthetic sense that they don't want to have violated,'' Grasser said. ``If it's actually doing environmental damage, I sure haven't been able to locate any. That's a vast, vast area.'' The 19 million-acre refuge in the northeast corner of Alaska was created by Congress in 1980, but its 1.5 million-acre coastal plain was exempted from wilderness designation. The oil industry believes huge oil fields lie beneath the coastal plain and has asked Congress to approve drilling there.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Delivers Holiday Message Of Hope That Apartheid Will End
LaserPhoto JOH1
DOC.TEXT: On the eve of his first free Christmas in nearly 30 years,Nelson Mandela on Monday recalled bleak holidays in prison and expressed hope this holiday season will be South Africa's last under apartheid. In a holiday message read at his Soweto home, the African National Congress leader noted his brethren still in prison or exile and the political violence that has killed thousands of people in black townships. ``This is a year that has been marked by moments both of hope and despair. As it comes to its close, the message we wish to convey ... is one of hope,'' he said. Mandela, 72, the ANC's deputy president, was freed in February after 27 years in prison. Shortly after he spoke, ANC president Oliver Tambo met for the first time with President F.W. de Klerk. Tambo, who ended 30 years in exile on Dec. 13, echoed Mandela's desire that apartheid be abolished by Christmas 1991. ``The South Africa so many have sacrificed so much to achieve is in sight,'' Mandela said in his message. He urged people of all political persuasions to ``persist in their noble efforts'' to solve the nation's problems peacefully. Asked to think back on his past Christmases, Mandela recalled his first one at the notorious Robben Island maximum-security prison. Inmates were not allowed to have visitors, and celebration was limited to sweets and biscuits provided by the church, he said. He paused, then said with a smile, ``I've never cared for sweets in my life, but in prison I thought that they were very delectable indeed.'' As years went by, conditions improved. Prisoners were allowed to order special groceries for the holiday and created their own celebrations, he said. ``But that is nothing compared to what I look forward to at the moment, when I am able to celebrate Christmas as a free man,'' said Mandela, seated in a high-backed leather chair in his lavish Soweto home. He did not mention the government or de Klerk but appeared to direct his message at them when he said: ``Our thoughts turn to all those others in the country who will not be with their families; those who are still held as political detainees and prisoners.'' The government has agreed in principle to allow thousands of exiles to return and to free political prisoners, but the ANC has accused it of delaying the process. Mandela also decried what he called the ``unacceptable campaign of violence'' in black townships, where eight more people died over the weekend. Most of the fighting involves Xhosas and other supporters of the ANC, against backers of the Zulu-based Inkatha Freedom Party. Both sides have accused security forces of playing a part in the unrest. Police deny the allegations. Mandela said a meeting between himself and Inkatha leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi is crucial to peace and is ``on the cards.'' The rival black leaders have not held peace talks. This month they declined even to walk together through Tokoza township during a tour by political and church leaders. Since being freed from prison, Mandela has met frequently with de Klerk for talks aimed at setting up formal negotiations on a new constitution. Tambo met de Klerk for the first time Monday morning in Pretoria. The meeting was not announced in advance. Mandela mentioned it during his news conference and said no major political issues were expected to be discussed. Tambo later told reporters he hoped South Africa would have a ``full recovery from apartheid'' by Christmas next year. An Information Ministry statement said de Klerk wished Tambo continued recovery from a severe stroke suffered in August 1989, and that both agreed violence must end for proper negotiations to begin.

DOC.HEAD: Nation's Leaders Scatter for Holiday, But Still in Touch
DOC.TEXT: The nation's leaders scattered across the United States for the Christmas holidays Monday, but they're staying in touch with each other to monitor the volatile situation in the Persian Gulf. President Bush spent the day before Christmas at Camp David, Md., being briefed by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney on the Gulf crisis. U.S. forces in Saudi Arabia were on heightened alert in case of attacks during the holiday. Cheney and Gen. Colin L. Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, returned to the United States Sunday after a five-day trip to Saudi Arabia to check on the readiness of roughly 300,000 U.S. forces in the Gulf. A previously televised Christmas message from Bush was broadcast to the troops on Monday. Bush plans to stay at the presidential retreat in the Cacoctin Mountains 60 miles from Washington until Jan. 2. The president gathered his family with him. Bush can communicate with his aides and others through a sophisticated communications system at Camp David. The retreat is also a short helicopter ride from the White House should the president need to return to Washington. In previous years, Bush has traveled to Beeville, Texas, for an annual turkey hunt right after Christmas but this year he canceled the trip in part because of the Gulf crisis, aides said. Secretary of State James Baker has accompanied Bush on the turkey hunt in the past. He is spending Christmas in his hometown of Houston, Texas, the State Department said. Cheney, a former congressman from Wyoming, is flying to that Western state for the holiday Monday, shortly after he finishes briefing Bush, the Defense Department said. Cheney told reporters at the tail end of his trip that he was pessimistic about Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's intentions. ``I see no sign that Saddam Hussein intends to withdraw his forces from Kuwait,'' the defense chief said. A U.N. resolution authorizes the anti-Iraq coalition to use force if necessary to push Iraq out of Kuwait if its troops have not withdrawn voluntarily by Jan. 15. Meanwhile, Vice President Dan Quayle is preparing to leave on a New Year's troop morale-boosting trip to Saudi Arabia on Dec. 29. He returns on Jan. 2. For Christmas, Quayle took his wife, Marilyn, and three children on a skiing vacation to Vail, Colo., spokesman David Beckwith said. A key player in the Gulf policy arena, Brent Scowcroft, the national security advisor, planned to stay in the nation's capital for the holidays, the White House said. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, just back from a trip to the Middle East, was vacationing in his home state of Maine. The top Senate Democrat said Sunday he was still hopeful the Gulf crisis could be resolved peacefully through diplomatic means. Congress returns Jan. 3 and is likely to begin debate on Gulf policy then. But Mitchell said he has not set a timetable for when the debate will take place. He said he wants to find out the status of any diplomatic activity before lawmakers embroil themselves in the future policy debate.

DOC.HEAD: US Says Salvadoran Rebels Planning Offensive
DOC.TEXT: The State Department said Monday leftist rebels in El Salvador are planning intensive military attacks in early 1991 as a follow-up to a nine-day Christmas truce they have unilaterally declared. ``Instead of negotiating to bring peace to El Salvador in 1990, the guerrillas have chosen to bring death and destruction to their country and its people,'' department spokesman Richard Boucher said. ``While professing to observe a truce, they are preparing for more war,'' he said. He said the latest round of attacks by the FMLN rebels caused 16 civilian deaths and 108 civilian casualties. The attacks on coffee and cotton farms, public transport, banks and other civilian property have put many poor Salvadorans out of work. ``These targets have no conceivable military value,'' Boucher said. ``As the government has made more concessions at the bargaining table, the FMLN has stepped up violence and militarism.''

DOC.HEAD: In Colonial America, No Christmas, and Surely No `Mad Mirth'
DOC.TEXT: Christmas is a solid - and almost secular - part of American life, but it had to battle to establish itself in North America. The holiday was banned in Boston in 1659 and anyone caught feasting could be fined five shillings. The ban was lifted 22 years later, but two staunch Puritan Congregationalist scholars and clerics - Increase Mather and his son, Cotton - kept up the crusade against observing the holiday in New England. Increase thought Christ probably had been born in September, while Cotton said the occasion, in any event, hardly justified ``mad mirth.'' No such misgivings moved the South. In Virginia, where Anglicanism held sway, there was no doubt: Christmas was meant to be celebrated. John Smith and his Virginia companies recorded that they ate oyster, fish, meat, wild fowl and bread on Christmas day in 1608. Smith later recorded that, ``Wherever an Englishman may be, and whatever part of the world, he must keep Christmas with feasting and merriment.'' In a new book, ``Keeping Christmas: The Celebration of an American Holiday,'' historian Philip Reed Rulon of Northern Arizona University recounts the battle Christmas had to fight before it ``embedded itself into the marrow of the people.'' The Christmas chasm was largely a carryover from England where, Rulon notes, Episcopalians, Roman Catholics, Lutherans, members of the Reformed sect and Moravians kept the holiday while Quakers, Scotch-Irish, Methodists, Baptists, and the ``Plain Dutch'' - Mennonites, Brethren and Amish - joined Congregationalists and Presbyterians in rejecting Christmas. Christmas was something the Puritans wanted to `purify'' the Church of England from. And the Pilgrims, founders of another American holiday, Thanksgiving, intended to start fresh in the new world, free of any of the Roman Catholic traditions that had been retained by the Anglicans. ``The name of Christmas savors of superstition,'' Increase Mather wrote in 1681. ``It can never be proved that Christ was born on December 25. It is most probable that the Nativity was in September. The New Testament allows of no stated Holy Days but the Lord's Day.'' Cotton took a different tack. He was willing to accept the notion of observing the birth of Christ, but thought Christmas should have nothing to do with merriment. ``Can you in your conscience think that our Holy savior is honored by mad mirth, by long eating, by rude revelling?'' asked Cotton. But even in New England, the battle was a lost cause. Against the iron will of the Mathers, pastor Henry Scougal preached a Boston sermon that told the Christmas story and made the case for celebration. He asked:``Can we be insensible of our happiness when angels do so heartily congratulate it?'' Christmas suffered a setback in the Revolutionary War. It was associated with the defeated side - the Anglican English troops and their American Tory sympathizers. But Thomas Jefferson championed separation of church and state, and that allowed Christmas to become a festival free of both. It was years later, Rulon says, that Baptists, Methodists and Presbyterians ``brought the holiday back to the pulpit and pew.''

DOC.HEAD: Habitat for Humanity Will Mark 15th Anniversary With Building Blitz
DOC.TEXT: Habitat for Humanity will celebrate its 15th anniversary next year by building 1,500 homes for the needy in 225 communities around the nation. Habitat said the 16-week building blitz will begin in Miami on June 16 and end in Columbus, Ohio, with a three-day convention, starting Sept. 26. Former President Carter, one of Habitat's best-known volunteers, will be the keynote speaker at the meeting. During the anniversary project, 15 work teams will travel from community to community, building new homes and renovating old ones, Habitat officials said. Habitat will provide food, housing and transportation. ``This will be the most exciting year in Habitat for Humanity's history,'' said Millard Fuller, Habitat's president and co-founder. Fuller said the Christian housing group also plans to complete its 10,000th home early in the year and to complete its 15,000th by the end of the year. Volunteers build and renovate homes by using donated materials. Recipients are required to work on their homes and the homes of others. Houses are purchased on a non-profit, no-interest basis.

DOC.HEAD: Top State Aide Resigns, Citing Family Reasons
DOC.TEXT: Richard McCormack, the State Department's fourth-ranking official, is resigning - and looking for a job that allows him more time with his family. McCormack, 49, is under secretary of state for economic and agriculture. He said he wants to spend more time with his three children, including a nine-month old baby. His resignation will become effective in early 1991. Among McCormack's principal duties has been to prepare for the annual seven-nation economic summit meetings, a task requiring frequent travel abroad. McCormack served as ambassador to the Organization of American States from 1985 to 1988 and was assistant secretary for economic affairs from 1982 to 1985. He was appointed to his current post in 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Rushdie Says He Will Not Authorize `Satantic Verses' Paperback
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with comment from Rushdie and Moslems. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Salman Rushdie has embraced Islam and promised not to authorize a paperback version of his controversial novel ``The Satanic Verses,'' a group of Islamic and Egyptian officials announced today. Earlier this year, Rushdie had insisted on the need for a paperback version, but a spokeswoman for his defense committee confirmed that the statement was genuine. In a statement released by Dr. Hesham el-Essawy, president of the Islamic Society for the Promotion of Religious Tolerance, Rushdie also declared that he did not agree with any statement uttered by characters in the book that cast aspersions on Islam, questioned the authenticity of the Koran, or rejected the divinity of Allah. He also agreed not to authorize any further translations of the work. Rushdie did not disavow the book, but insisted today that it was a moral fable. All the things that Moslems found insulting, he said, ``take place in the dream of a man who has lost his mind. He has lost his mind because he has lost his faith.'' In a telephone hookup with a news conference organized by el-Essawy, Rushdie said it was up to the government of Iran to remove the death sentence against him. ``I feel a lot safer tonight than I felt yesterday,'' he added. Rushdie has been in hiding under police guard since February 1989, when Iranian leader Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini said the writer deserved death as a blasphemer. Iran offered a $1 million bounty for Rushdie's death. ``This is the way we hope that will earn Rushdie's release from his predicament. This is how we intend to make him a free man,'' said el-Essawy. El-Essawy argued, as he has in the past, that Rushdie could not be sentenced to death as an apostate because he was not a believing Moslem. Now that Rushdie has embraced the faith, by ``declaring there is no God but Allah and that Mohammed is his last prophet,'' el-Essawy said that ``the slate is wiped clean.'' El-Essawy characterized Rushdie as a ``convert,'' and quoted the author as saying, ``There is no difference between Rushdie and Islam.'' Other British Moslems who have been prominent in the controversy demanded more from Rushdie. ``It puzzles me that he hasn't gone far enough to remove the hardback, if that's the intention. The Moslem community has been suffering for a long time,'' said Sher Azam of the Council for Mosques in Bradford, where the book had been publicly burned. ``Until the book is completely removed our campaign goes on,'' Azam said. Iqbal Sacranie, joint convener of the UK Committee on Islamic Affairs, said Rushdie's statement was a positive step. However, ``It seems to us that the most appropriate course of action ... is the withdrawal from circulation of this blasphemous book.'' Rushdie recently has come out of hiding for a television interview, and on Dec. 5 he appeared at a London bookshop to sign copies of his latest book, ``Haroun and the Sea of Stories.'' Iran severed diplomatic relations with Britain over ``The Satanic Verses'' but ties were restored in October after an 18-month break. On Dec. 9, however, Iranian Minister of Culture Mohammad Khatami said the death sentence against Rushdie could not be revoked. El-Essawy said he met with Rushdie on Friday in a secure location. He said they were joined at the meeting by Dr. Mohammed Ali Mahgoub, an Egyptian government official who heads the Supreme Council of Scholars of Islamic Affairs; Youssef Ahmed El Sharkawy, 2nd Secretary at the Egyptian Embassy and two clergy from the Regent's Park Mosque in London. According to el-Essawy, Rushdie made four points in the statement: ``1. To witness that there is no God but Allah, and that Mohammed is his last prophet. ``2. To declare that I do not agree with any statement in my novel `The Satanic Verses' uttered by any of the characters who insults the prophet Mohammed, or casts aspersions upon Islam, or upon the authenticity of the holy koran, or who rejects the divinity of Allah. ``3. I undertake not to publish the paperback edition of `The Satanic Verses' or to permit any further agreement for translations into other languages while any risk of further offense exists. ``4. I will continue to work for a better understanding of Islam in the world, as I have always attempted to do in the past.'' ``The Satanic Verses'' has sold more than 1 million copies in English - almost three-quarters of those in the United States - and was on the Sunday Times of London's best-seller list for nearly a year. It has been translated into 15 languages and banned in more than 20 countries. Rushdie, born in Bombay and now a naturalized British citizen, has been in hiding since Feb. 14, 1989. Moslems worldwide objected to Rushdie's use of the names of the Prophet Mohammed's wives for the prostitutes in his novel and the implication that Mohammed wrote the Koran, Islam's holy book, instead of receiving it from God. In September 1989, a trade survey found booksellers in England divided on the question of stocking any paperback edition. Forty percent said they would not handle it, 44 percent said they would, according to Publishing News. A London newspaper, The Observer, reported last year that Viking Penguin had decided to publish the paperback in 1990, but the company never made any announcement. In January, the company said it was unlikely to announce its plans in advance because of the security implications.

The Bush administration put Thailand on notice Monday that it will consider imposing retaliatory tariffs unless the country takes steps to improve the protection of American copyrights. U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills announced that she had begun an investigation into Thailand's copyright enforcement practices. ``We have repeatedly expressed our strong concern to Thai officials at all levels that the rights of U.S. copyright holders are not adequately safeguarded,'' Hills said. ``Unfortunately, we have seen no improvement in Thailand's willingness to shut down the considerable illegal copying of U.S. movies, music, books and computer software or to ensure that U.S. companies obtain prompt and effective redress through Thailand's legal system,'' she said in a statement. The investigation was being conducted under a provision of U.S. trade law known as Section 301 that allows America to boost tariffs on a country's imports if the administration makes a finding that American exports face unfair practices in another country. Hills acted after receiving a petition on Nov. 15 from the Motion Picture Association of America, the International Intellectual Property Alliance and the Recording Industry Association of America. She said that her office wants to begin consultations immediately with the Thai government in an effort to resolve the problem. If those talks fail to produce an acceptable resolution of the case, then the administration would have the power to target a list of Thai exports to the United States for higher tariffs.

DOC.HEAD: Fifth Arson Fire in small New Hampshire Town
DOC.TEXT: The fifth suspicious fire in this small town since Aug. 25 damaged a vacant turn-of-the-century hotel for the second time. The three-story Alpine Hotel was heavily damaged Saturday night when fire broke out on its top floor. Authorities said the 40-room hotel was slightly damaged by fire last month. The Upland Terrace, another vacant hotel, was destroyed Aug. 25, and the vacant carriage house of another hotel and a vacant apartment building also have been destroyed since then. ``They're all arson. We're sure of that,'' said Howard Keach Jr., chairman of the selectmen in the town of 1,800. He said four of the fires occurred on Saturdays at about 9 p.m., and the other on a Sunday at the same time. The hotels once were used by Hassidic Jews, who have been coming from the New York area for years to vacation in Bethlehem, but Keach said that appeared to have nothing to do with the fires. Bethlehem is about 15 miles southwest of Jefferson, which was hit by 26 arsons during six months in 1988. A former Jefferson firefighter was arrested, but a Superior Court jury acquitted him in June 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Developments in the Persian Gulf
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Here are Monday's developments in the Persian Gulf crisis: --- Saddam Hussein said in a Spanish television interview that Israel will be Iraq's first target if war breaks out. The Iraqi president was quoted as saying Tel Aviv would be targeted whether or not Israel joined an international war effort against Iraq. Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir responded to the reported threat by telling Israel radio that Iraq ``will be harmed in a most serious way'' if it attacks Israel. --- A senior official of the Palestine Liberation Organization, Israel's most implacable enemy, indicated in an interview that the PLO would side with Saddam if war broke out. ``We have coordinated our plans to fight with Iraq in one trench,'' PLO Chairman Yasser Arafat's chief political adviser, Hani Al-Hassan, told the Iraqi daily newspaper Al-Jumhuriya. --- The readiness of U.S. forces to fight was the topic as Defense Secretary Dick Cheney met with President Bush. Cheney, returning a day earlier from a five-day trip to the Middle East, said American troops would be ``prepared today, if we were ordered today, to take military action.'' --- The Iraqi Embassy in Washington said the Iraqi envoy to the United States, Mohamed Al-Mashat, and Baghdad's envoy to the United Nations, Abdul Al-Anbari, were among those summoned home. Iraqi envoys to a number of European nations were also recalled for talks, officials said. It was unclear how many were involved, and no details about the talks were disclosed. --- U.S. forces in the Persian Gulf were on heightened alert to guard against possible terrorist attacks during the holiday season, said a military source. U.S. troops planned a low-key Christmas in Moslem Saudi Arabia, with non-religious Christmas carols favored on Armed Forces radio and plastic Christmas trees discreetly displayed behind closed tent flaps. --- President Bush taped a Christmas message to be broadcast to U.S. troops worldwide. ``The sacrifices you make will never be forgotten. America is behind you. The world is behind you and history is behind you,'' the president said in the message. --- Conservative Soviet lawmakers submitted a resolution to the parliament demanding a vote before any Soviet troops are sent to the region. The resolution seeks a special legislative session held on the topic Jan. 14, the day before the U.N. deadline for an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Calif. High Court Upholds Most of Anti-Crime Initiative
DOC.TEXT: The state Supreme Court today struck down part of an anti-crime initiative that would have stripped California defendants of any rights that are not provided in the U.S. Constitution. The court upheld most of Proposition 115, the so-called ``Speedy Trial'' initiative, but struck down its broadest provision, a repeal of independent state constitutional rights for criminal defendants. The court ruled unanimously that the constitutional provision was such a fundamental change that it amounted to a ``revision'' of the state Constitution, which cannot be done by initiative. The provision would have required California courts to follow U.S. Supreme Court rulings in applying a long list of constitutional rights, rather than more liberal rulings based on the state constitution. But the court voted 6-1 to uphold the rest of the measure, which was passed by voters in June and contained numerous provisions aimed at shortening trial and pretrial proceedings. They included measures to reduce the length of preliminary hearings, which can stretch for months and even years in California; eliminating preliminary hearings after a grand jury indictment; requiring judges rather than lawyers to question jurors; and requiring defense lawyers to be prepared for trial in 60 days. The measure also expands the death penalty, allows 16-year-olds convicted of capital murder to be sentenced to life without parole, and establishes penalties for a newly defined crime of torture. In the opinion, by Chief Justice Malcolm Lucas, the court rejected the provision would have required state courts to follow U.S. Supreme Court rulings in such areas as equal protection, due process, assistance of counsel, speedy trial, unreasonable searches, privacy, self-incrimination, double jeopardy and cruel and unusual punishment. California courts have interpreted many of those rights more broadly than federal courts. For example, state courts have construed privacy rights to limit police surveillance and have ruled some non-capital sentences to be cruel and unusual punishment. In finding the proposed change to be a constitutional revision rather than an amendment - the first such ruling since 1948 - the court noted Proposition 115 would have stripped state courts of the power to interpret fundamental defendants' rights. The only justice to vote against the majority ruling, Stanley Mosk, argued that the whole initiative should be thrown out, saying its elements were so diverse that the measure violated the rule limiting initiatives to a single subject.

DOC.HEAD: Matriarch of San Diego Zoo Elephant Herd Euthanized After Accident
DOC.TEXT: A 51-year-old elephant at the San Diego Zoo had to be killed because of injuries she suffered after falling headfirst into a concrete moat, officials said. Maya, an Asian elephant who was the oldest mammal at the zoo, apparently suffered torn ligaments in her legs Sunday as she tried to climb out of the moat surrounding her enclosure, said zoo spokesman Jeff Jouett. Veterinarians resorted to a fatal dose of sedative when Maya was unable to stand on her own following a treatment of fluids, painkillers and steroids. ``I counted 27 people there trying to help,'' Jouett said. ``When she would try to rock and stand up, there was a lot of calling and urging to her.'' Elephants cannot convalesce while sitting or lying down because their weight exerts life-threatening pressure on their lungs, Jouett said. Jouett said 51 is fairly elderly for an elephant, but they have been known to live into their 60s in captivity. Maya, who was captured in India and brought to the zoo Nov. 8, 1941, was bumped into the moat by another elephant. Two nearby keepers didn't see the fall but heard the commotion. The 7,100-pound elephant was walking without difficulty in the moat, but she apparently crippled herself while trying to climb out on bales of hay that zookeepers set up like steps, Jouett said. Maya then was fitted with a harness and lifted by crane into a sitting position. But it was evident when workers tried to get her to stand that her legs wouldn't support her, and she was then put to death. Elephants have been knocked into the moat before without suffering serious injury, but Jouett said Maya's age may have made her accident worse. Tests after her death showed she suffered from degenerative arthritis in her legs. He described her as a generally calm, easygoing creature, but one who often would assert herself to show she still led the herd. ``There's some concern over how the remaining four elephants will react,'' Jouett said. ``They'll notice she's gone and I'm sure it will be upsetting to them.'' After the accident, the zoo's Elephant Mesa was closed to the public for the rest of the day.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: He's bug-eyed, missing two fingers and has no chin, but Bart J. Simpson has what it takes to capture Entertainment Weekly's Entertainer of the Year title. The folk anti-hero who was a virtual unknown just one year ago became an underachiever for the ages in 1990. He's got his own TV show, Butterfinger candy advertising contract, a record album and a ``Do the Bartman'' rock video. Entertainment Weekly said Bart also deserves credit for not catching typical Hollywood afflictions: He didn't punch out any paparazzi, wear glasses to make himself look smarter, harangue his fans about flavor-of-the-month political causes, make a trip to the Betty Ford Center or sing the National Anthem. Entertainment Weekly runners-up for the entertainer of the year trophy included Julia Roberts, Madonna, Arnold Schwarzenegger, M.C. Hammer, Stephen King, Sean Connery, Arsenio Hall, David Lynch and the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles. --- NEW YORK (AP) - M.C. Hammer, President Bush, Saddam Hussein, Sinead O'Connor and Bart Simpson might not appear to have a lot in common. But People magazine includes each of them in its list of the most intriguing people of 1990. The magazine blames Saddam for bringing the world to the brink of war. It says Bush's place is history is insecure as he faces his toughest crisis. It credits Hammer with bringing showbiz flash and footwork to rap. And O'Connor? She's a ``haunting rebel voice heard in an age of flashing legs and lip sync.'' As for Bart, People says he gave underachievers a good name. It calls Julia Roberts the first new female star of the '90s for her role in ``Pretty Woman,'' while crediting Ken Burns, the producer of the 11-hour ``Civil War'' with making a name for himself through public television. Also named were Patrick Swayze, Francis Ford Coppola, Delta Burke, Michael Ovitz, Nancy Cruzan, Gen. Colin Powell, Fidel Castro, Effi Barry, Dr. Anthony Fauci, Nancy Ziegenmeyer, Nelson Mandela, Neil Bush, Keenen Ivory Wayans, Claudia Schiffer, William Styron, Laura Palmer, Bo Jackson and Princess Caroline. --- LONDON (AP) - Playwright Tom Stoppard and his wife, Miriam, are separating, they announced Monday. The law firm of Harbottle and Lewis, in a statement to the British news agency Press Association, said: ``Tom and Miriam Stoppard, who have amicably maintained separate residences for some time past, announced today that they have agreed on a legal separation.'' Stoppard and his wife, both 53, have been married 18 years and have two sons. Stoppard has two other sons by a previous marriage. Miriam Stoppard, a medical doctor, writes an advice column in the magazine TV Times. --- ASTORIA, Ore. (AP) - Arnold Schwarzenegger's new film, ``Kindergarten Cop,'' has been flunked at the Astoria school where much of the movie was made. After previewing the film, Astor Elementary School Principal Judy Bigby and Astoria School District Superintendent Len Carpenter dropped plans to take all the children from Astor School to a special showing of the movie Jan. 9. Bigby said the film, rated PG-13, included unnecessary nudity, excessive violence and bad language, making it inappropriate to show as a school function. Dozens of Astor Elementary School children appear in the movie as does their school, spruced up by Universal Studios. Universal Studios was closed Monday and studio officials could not be reached for comment. At Astoria's Liberty Theater, where the movie is playing, manager Glen Schaefer said he was disappointed that the movie included material unsuitable for the youngsters who appear in it. However, he said the reaction from viewers has been generally favorable. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Ron Silver is out and his understudy, Tom McGowan, is the new star, at least for the moment, of ``La Bete,'' a new Broadway-bound comedy that will open Wednesday at the Wilbur Theater in Boston. Gary Springer, a spokesman for the show, called Silver's departure ``amicable,'' saying that the actor's withdrawal was due to ``irreconcilable interpretive differences.'' Whether McGowan will have the role when the play opens in New York was not certain. ``Everything is still under discussion,'' Nance Movsesian, a Boston spokeswoman for the production, said Monday. The play, written by David Hirson and directed by Richard Jones, is set on the 17th century estate of a French prince whose court is disrupted by a manic troubadour. The play is still scheduled to open Jan. 31 at the Eugene O'Neill Theater in New York. The producers are Stuart Ostrow and Andrew Lloyd Webber.

DOC.HEAD: Drizzle, Soldiers Mark Christmas Eve in Bethlehem
LaserPhoto JRL1-3
DOC.TEXT: Under the watchful eyes of Israeli soldiers, the Roman Catholic patriarch of Jerusalem came to this biblical town Monday to open the Christmas season in the Holy Land. Hundreds of soldiers and police guarded Bethlehem as a procession of white-robed priests led the patriarch, Michel Sabah, into the Church of the Nativity, built over a grotto where tradition holds that Christ was born. Sabah's midnight Mass in the neighboring St. Catherine's Church opened a holiday season in the Holy Land featuring three celebrations of Christ's birth. The others are the Greek Orthodox Christmas on Jan. 7 and the Armenian Orthodox celebrtion on Jan. 19. In past years, Bethlehem's Manger Square would have been crowded and ablaze with lights, but this year only a few dozen tourists wandered through Manger Square on Christmas Eve. Most visitors were scared away by the Persian Gulf crisis and the Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Father Wally Anthony, a Catholic priest from Flint, Mich., now with the church in Rome, noted the lack of tourists and the abundance of heavily armed police and soldiers. ``Sometimes when you read the scriptures, you read about the soldiers there in the times of 2,000 years ago, and you can identify with that same kind of environment,'' he said. As in the past three years, Palestinian town officials canceled Christmas celebrations. The town had few decorations for the holiday, and stores and restaurants were closed by a strike called by uprising leaders. The Israeli government sponsored a holiday choir concert, but this year only one foreign choir, from the First United Methodist Church of Oklahoma City, took part. Most color on the drab, rainy day came from the red, purple, black and green berets of the Israeli security forces. Soldiers and police guarded the five miles of roadway from Jerusalem to Bethlehem, and hundreds stood around the square. All visitors to Manger Square had to pass through metal detectors. Armed soldiers watched from atop the Church of the Nativity. Security was especially heavy because of a wave of stabbing attacks on Israelis by Arabs following the Oct. 8 Temple Mount riot in which Israeli police killed 17 Palestinians. Army curfews kept 15,000 Arabs at home in three nearby refugee camps. Gabriele Beitz, a tourist from Heidelberg, Germany, was visiting with her husband and 11-year-old daughter, and said she found the situation in Bethlehem ``very, very fearful.'' ``We are very depressed about the place and about the whole political situation here,'' she said. ``For us, Christmas is an event of peace, and here you cannot feel peace.'' In Manger Square, Sabah was greeted by the Israeli military governor of Bethlehem, Dudu Mufaz, in a tradition that extends back to the 19th century when Palestine was ruled by the Ottoman Turks. Sabah, the first Palestinian to head the Roman Catholic Church in the Holy Land, wore purple robes. He was led by hundreds of altar boys carrying candles as he went to pray in the grotto. As a holiday gesture, the military announced it was releasing 217 Palestinian prisoners arrested during the uprising. Bethlehem's Palestinian mayor, Elias Freij, told reporters he was praying for ``peace on earth and good will toward all people, and peace in the Holy Land between Israelis and Palestinians, and peace amongst all the Arabs.'' Freij blamed the lack of tourists on U.S. State Department warnings for Americans not to travel to the Middle East. The 25,000-strong Arab Christian community of Nazareth, meanwhile, opened Christmas celebrations Monday with a traditional parade through the Galilee town. Boy scouts from the town's different religious communities led the march along a 1.2-mile route to the Roman Catholic Basilica of the Annunciation.

DOC.HEAD: US Rebuts KGB Chief, Calling Rhetoric ``Inflammatory''
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Adds 6 grafs at end with details on U.S. aid and other information
DOC.TEXT: The State Department dismissed as ``unfounded and inaccurate'' on Monday allegations by the Soviet KGB chairman that Western countries are attempting to weaken and subvert the Soviet system under the guise of offering assistance. ``We are concerned that such a senior Soviet official would turn to this kind of outdated and inflammatory rhetoric, which can only be described as inconsistent with the improvement that has taken place in both the substance and the atmosphere of U.S.-Soviet relations,'' deputy spokesman Richard Boucher said. On Saturday, KGB chairman Vladimir A. Kryuchkov gave a speech to the Soviet Congress in which he warned that closer Soviet links to the West posed hidden dangers for his country. ``There are attempts from abroad to exert overt and covert pressure on the Soviet Union and to impose doubtful ideas and plans to pull the country out of the difficult situation,'' Kryuchkov said. ``All these efforts often screen a desire to strengthen not so much us but their own position in our country.'' Specifically, he accused the West of stimulating a brain drain and of sending contaminated grain. In reply, Boucher said, ``The allegations made the KGB chairman are completely unfounded and inaccurate ... The Soviet Union's internal difficulties, as senior Soviet officials themselves have readily admitted, are the result of policies adopted in the past by the country's leaders. They can only be solved with fundamental political and economic reforms.'' Kryuchkov's speech occurred nine days after President Bush approved U.S. credit guarantees for Soviet purchases of up to $1 billion in American commodities. He also proposed other ways of helping the Soviets head off economic collapse, including expertise in food distribution. In addition, he waived legislative restrictions on Soviet access to U.S. government credit programs. Bush said U.S. policy is to ``help the Soviet Union stay the course of democracy and to undertake market reforms.'' Germany and other West European nations along with Japan also are sending food to the Soviets to help overcome growing shortages. Kryuchkov also generated concern here in his speech when he said that bloodshed may be required to restore order to the Soviet Union. Senate Majority leader George Mitchell, D-Me., said Sunday a Soviet crackdown along the lines threatened by Kryuchkov could lead to a cutoff of U.S. assistance to the Soviets. ``I don't think we should be providing any assistance if there is a crackdown and a return to authoritarian rule,'' Mitchell said.

DOC.HEAD: Parachutist from London Killed
DOC.TEXT: A skydiver was killed when her parachute failed to open after she jumped from 12,000 feet, police said Monday. Denise Lyell, 33, of London, died Sunday. Ms. Lyell, who had made more than 200 jumps and was visiting for the holidays, landed in a field a half-mile from Zephyrhills Parachute Center, said Pasco Sheriff's spokesman Jon Powers. He said the investigation has been turned over the Federal Aviation Authority. The Zephyrhills area is about 25 miles northeast of Tampa.

DOC.HEAD: Text of Statement by Salman Rushdie
With AM-Britain-Rushdie, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Following is the text of a statement by Salman Rushdie released Monday by Dr. Hesham el-Essawy, president of the Islamic Society for the Promotion of Religious Tolerance in the United Kingdon: ``In the presence of his excellency the Egyptian secretary of state for endowment and head of the Supreme Council of Scholars of Islamic Affairs, Dr. Mohammed Ali Mahgoub, and a group of Islamic scholars: ``1. To witness that there is no God but Allah, and that Mohammed is his last prophet. ``2. To declare that I do not agree with any statement in my novel ``The Satanic Verses'' uttered by any of the characters who insults the prophet Mohammed, or casts aspersions upon Islam, or upon the authenticity of the holy Koran, or who rejects the divinity of Allah. ``3. I undertake not to publish the paperback edition of ``The Satanic Verses'' or to permit any further agreement for translations into other languages while any risk of further offense exists. ``4. I will continue to work for a better understanding of Islam in the world, as I have always attempted to do in the past.''

DOC.HEAD: Ban On Swearing Criticized
DOC.TEXT: A new ban on profanity has brought this reaction from the American Civil Liberties Union: good luck in making it stick. ``They're flirting with danger,'' state ACLU Executive Director John Roberts said of the ordinance approved on Dec. 17. The ordinance forbids obscene or profane language in any public place and outlaws loitering. Violators could be fined $100. ``All I can say is with the language people use today, they better be ready to fill their jails up,'' Roberts said. That doesn't deter Mayor James A. Sheets. ``I come out of this building after work ever night, and I have to listen to this profanity and vulgarity being screamed from one side of Hancock Street to the other,'' Sheets said. ``People in the city have a right to expect that they can bring their families downtown and not be subjected to the kind of profanity I've been hearing.'' Council President Theodore DeCristofaro, a supporter of the ordinance, said most reactions he's heard have been favorable. ``Yes this will be difficult to enforce, but it's worth it,'' he said. Sheets said the ordinance is part of his program to revitalize Quincy Square. Asked if the ordinance violates the First Amendment, Sheets invited a challenge. Roberts said the ACLU had no immediate plans to do so.

DOC.HEAD: Special Investigator Orders Papandreou to Testify in Scandal
DOC.TEXT: A special investigator on Monday issued a warrant ordering former Socialist Premier Andreas Papandreou to testify in connection with a $210 million bank embezzlement scandal. But legal sources said Papandreou would not be arrested if he did not comply. They said the warrant was a formality allowing investigator Spyros Spyrou to close his inquiry before handing it to a special court. Papandreou, who governed from 1981 to 1989 and heads the opposition Panhellenic Socialist Movement, last month refused to testify. He says his indictment by Parliament last year is the work of his political rivals. On Monday, his party said the warrant ``offers itself to obvious political exploitation by those who consider the process of a `cleanup' an exercise in political persecution and the elimination of their political rivals.'' Spyrou said last week that Papandreou's refusal to testify left the former premier in contempt of court, media reported. The warrant issued Monday ordered that Papandreou be forced to testify. Such warrants usually lead to a witness or a suspect being arrested if he does not comply. Vyron Polydoras, spokesman for the conservative leadership, said the government had nothing to do with the warrant. He said it was probably only a formality. A conservative-Communist coalition government indicted Papandreou and four senior Cabinet ministers in 1989 on charges of authorizing and participating in an embezzlement scandal involving the privately owned Bank of Crete. Their trial date has not been set. Two conservative parliamentarians and a leftist lawmaker are acting as prosecutors in the case. For the warrant to be carried out, they must agree unanimously. But one said in an interview published Monday in the Athens newspaper Eleftherotypia that he did not support the warrant. Asked whether he thought the warrant would be carried out, Nikos Galanos of the Coalition of the Left and Progress said, ``I consider it implausible.''

DOC.HEAD: LA Times Editor Named Editor of The Quill
DOC.TEXT: Brian L. Steffens of the Los Angeles Times has been named editor of The Quill, the magazine of the Society of Professional Journalists. Steffens replaces Mike Moore, who chose not to make the move when the group moved from Chicago to Greencastle. Moore had been Quill editor since 1985. Ira D. Perry, executive director of the society, said Steffens was chosen from among 53 applicants. Steffens said he plans to update the magazine's format with more tips and practical advice for journalists. Steffens has been news editor of the daily View section of the Los Angeles Times' Orange County edition, supervising production. He previously was graphics editor of the LA Times' Orange County edition, and from 1984 to 1987 he was assistant managing editor for graphics at The San Diego Union.
