Steffens also has served as publisher of the Society of Newspaper Design's Design Journal, Deadline Mac newsletter and its other publications since 1988. The Society of Professional Journalists was formed in Greencastle in 1909 and was based almost 50 years in Chicago before returning to Indiana.

DOC.HEAD: Writers Fear Wider Effects on Profession
With AM-Britain-Rushdie, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Fellow authors supported Salman Rushdie on Monday but worried about their profession after he promised not to authorize a paperback version of his novel, ``The Satanic Verses.'' Rushdie has been in hiding under police guard since February 1989, when Iranian leader Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini said the writer deserved death as a blasphemer and Iran offered a $1 million bounty. His decision not to bring out a paperback edition, and not to authorize any more translations, was announced Monday in London. Novelist Hilma Wolitzer said she was ``very sympathetic with a man who wants his life back.'' ``I'm very sad about the tyranny that made him have to go into hiding and that makes him withdraw his book. The freedom to write has been diminished,'' she said. Faith Sale, a book editor and co-chair of the Freedom to Write Committee of PEN, the writer's organization, said the author's decision on paperbacks does not change the novel. ``What he wrote stands. But if there is some way that he can regain his life as a normal human being, I have to support it,'' said Sale, an acquaintance of Rushdie. ``This was one of the most horrendous things that's ever been visited on a writer,'' she added. ``Pragmatism has to prevail here. It's unfortunate if the publishing arrangements have to be affected, but he's already managed to reach an extremely wide audience with that book.'' ``The Satanic Verses'' has sold more than 1 million copies in English - almost three-quarters of those in the United States. It has been translated into 15 languages and banned in more than 20 countries. Phones went unanswered Monday at offices of Viking-Penguin, Rushdie's U.S. publisher, and its lawyer. Most publishing houses were closed until after Christmas. Novelist Allan Gurganus said by telephone from Chapel Hill, N.C., that the Rushdie episode has been a setback for writers ``at a time when the First Amendment is under siege from every quarter.'' ``Since every minority group has a subject that they find taboo, to allow any group to exercise suppression is to suppress every subject, since there is a group waiting to be offended by every interesting subject,'' Gurganus said. ``It's easy to judge Rushdie in the abstract,'' he said. ``My sense is that if you're going to hide forever, you might as well hide for a reason. But I can't second-guess his motivation. The truth is always unpopular in some ways.''

DOC.HEAD: Christmas Vignettes From Around the Nation
DOC.TEXT: Christmas isn't just Christmas for Vera Wilcox. It's also the birthday of her daughter, Terry Ann. And daughter Jean Marie. And daughter Karen Loraine. All were born on Dec. 25 - of 1951, 1954 and 1960, respectively. And now there's news from the youngest, Karen Loraine Hynes. ``She said she was pregnant and the doctor said that our 14th grandchild was due on Christmas,'' Mrs. Wilcox said. ``I said, `Oh my gosh, wouldn't that be something?''' That, Mrs. Wilcox, would be something. The three Christmas sisters are among Mrs. Wilcox's six children, another of whom came tantalizingly close to a Christmas birth. That's Mary Ellen, born Dec. 20, 1966. Brothers Jim (Nov. 18, 1952) and Lyle Jr. (Jan. 23, 1959) were further off the mark. Some people might feel sorry for Terry, Jean and Karen. After all, they went through childhood not only having to share their birthdays with each other but, one might surmise, receiving gifts on only one day a year. But in fact, their mother says, the sisters didn't even celebrate their birthdays on their birthdays. They celebrated on Mary Ellen's birthday, Dec. 20. Mrs. Wilcox said that improved the girls' chances of getting birthday gifts as well as Christmas gifts. --- TAMPA, Fla. (AP) - A Florida National Guard unit in Saudi Arabia is celebrating Christmas in the desert with presents from strangers who know what it's like to be on the front lines, far from home. An American Legion post adopted the 810th Military Police Co., and for a month the veterans worked like elves packaging batteries, soap, razors and other items for the 160 MPs. With help from the ladies' auxiliary and the post office, an estimated 400 pounds of goodies were in Saudi Arabia waiting to be distributed Monday and Tuesday to the Tampa-based troops, scattered across 100 miles of sandscape as part of Operation Desert Shield. The men and women of the 810th have already sent back a letter of thanks. They included a poem, written by Spec. Murray N. Smith, that reads in part: ``We will not be home for Christmas, Not with the ones we love. Whiskey, rum, beer and wine, Not one of the above... ``I shed a tear of sorrow, I feel the twists of pain. I wish for many things to be. I even wish for rain. ...'' --- VICKSBURG, Miss. (AP) - Mary Louise Caldwell Solomon of Vicksburg and Jessie Lee Johnson Coon of Arcadia, La., are ending a 48-year Christmas tradition this season. The two friends have exchanged the same Christmas card - now yellowed and tattered - on alternate years since 1942. But this year, Solomon received a phone call from Coon asking her to keep the card, and not return it to Arcadia. ``She has been in poor health,'' Solomon said. ``She is afraid something will happen and the card will be lost at her house.'' Solomon said Coon does not have any children. ``I guess she feels like my children will keep it and cherish it after we are all gone because they have an idea of what it has meant to us through the years,'' Solomon said. The first trip for the card occurred when Coon's husband, Leo, purchased it at Gowen Air Force Base in Boise, Idaho. It went from the Coons to the Solomons in 1942; then from the Solomons to the Coons in 1943. From then until now, the Coons and the Solomons have exchanged the same card every Christmas. ``It makes me a little sad to think we won't be sending the card any more,'' said Solomon, who has known her friend since the second grade. ``I can understand how she must feel. We are both 76 years old. You can't help but think about the end after a certain age.'' --- MILWAUKEE (AP) - Albert Rosen has been robbed at gunpoint, reduced to tears by critics and teased about his Jewish heritage during the 21 years he has volunteered as a substitute worker for Christians on Christmas. But neither the negative experiences nor advancing age can stop the 72-year-old retire housewares salesman from continuing the work that has earned him the title ``Jewish Elf.'' Rosen relishes the idea of gift-giving at Christmas. He proudly recounts some of the thanks he has received. Those he has helped tell him ``you are truly the spirit of Christmas because you are giving of yourself rather than giving something material that doesn't have much value anyway,'' he said. Rosen's efforts earned him nationwide recognition in 1977 when NBC aired a Hallmark Christmas special about his work entitled ``Have I Got a Christmas for You.'' But Rosen is quick to dispel thoughts that thanks and recognition are his motives. ``Brotherhood should be practiced as simple as buying a cup of coffee,'' he said. ``It should not require any recognition.'' Rosen's volunteerism during past holiday seasons has landed him in such jobs as a bartender, television news reporter, gas station attendant, mail clerk, security guard and hotel bellhop. This year, Rosen mulled retiring as a Christmas elf. He figured his efforts had promoted goodwill and his message had been spread. But then his wife of 51 years, Sylvia, stepped in and changed his mind. ``There's never a time when it's not important to help someone,'' Mrs. Rosen reminded her husband. --- POMPEY, N.Y. (AP) - All Terry and Ann Christmas wanted for Christmas was ... another Christmas. The suburban Syracuse couple - so named because Terry's Italian grandfather literally translated his last name, Natale, into English after immigrating to the United States - usually celebrates Dec. 25 in a big way. They send their Christmas cards via Christmas, Fla., or Christmas, Mich., for the postmark, and they have a Christmas license plate on their car. But something had been missing for the Christmases. For the past five years, the infertile couple have been futilely trying to adopt a healthy infant. But by early Saturday that miracle was completed as the Christmases brought home a baby boy from Romania - 7-week-old Adam Christmas. ``We couldn't ask for a better present,'' said Ann, 34. ``Once we had the baby we wanted to be home by Christmas. ... I go to church every week. I believe this was meant for us.''

DOC.HEAD: GIs and Families to Communicate Through Moon
DOC.TEXT: A Marine's mother has a plan to form a Christmas Day link between U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia and their families back home using the radio and the moon. Anne Schiller of Chicago says she got the idea for Project Monbeam shortly after her 21-year-old son, Brian, left for the Gulf on Oct. 30. She said she was unable to reach him for about a week. ``I was so upset,'' she said. ``But I was comforted by the fact that no matter where he was, he could look up at the same moon I was looking at. So when I finally talked to him again I told him that everytime he looks at the moon to let it remind him of all the love he has from home. ``It really does make us both feel better,'' she said. Schiller says she wants friends and families of U.S. troops to join in singing Christmas carols when the moon is visible in the United States and in the Gulf - at 3 p.m. EST. ``This is such a lonely time for them,'' said Schiller, 44. ``These kids are really down, and I really think this might brighten their spirits.'' In case moonbeams don't transmit the families' messages to the Gulf, the Armed Forces Radio and Television Network will air a recording of about 200 relatives and friends of GIs overseas humming Christmas carols. At the same time, about 5,000 affiliates of five U.S. radio networks will play a recording of the same group singing carols. Armed Forces radio will play the hummed carols so Saudis aren't offended by the religious lyrics. About 80 percent of the soldiers in the desert should be able to hear the braodcast at 11 p.m. Saudi time. Armed Forces radio has been advertising the simultaneous sing-a-long and encouraging soldiers to look at the moon when it airs, said Lt. Col. Ray Shepherd, operations officer for the Armed Forces network, based in Alexandria, Va. ``Being a soldier away from home, no matter where, it's nice to know someone's thinking about you,'' Shepherd said.

DOC.HEAD: Rushdie Embraces Islam, Won't Seek Paperback `Satanic Verses'
LaserPhoto LON16
DOC.TEXT: Salman Rushdie said Monday that he has embraced Islam and has given up his push for paperback publication of ``The Satanic Verses,'' the book which brought him a death sentence from Iran nearly two years ago. He also pledged, in a statement released by a local Islamic leader, that he would permit no further translations of the book. However, Rushdie defended his book as a ``moral fable'' about a character who ``has lost his mind because he has lost his faith.'' Rushdie has been in hiding under police guard since February 1989, when Iranian leader Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini sentenced him to death for blasphemy. Iran offered a $1 million bounty for Rushdie's death, and Iranian authorities reconfirmed the death sentence and the bounty earlier this month. Rushdie's statement was released by Dr. Hesham el-Essawy, president of the Islamic Society for the Promotion of Religious Tolerance. He said Rushdie typed the statement himself following a meeting with Islamic scholars. In his statement, the author declared that he did ``not agree with any statement in my novel `The Satanic Verses' uttered by any of the characters who insults the prophet Mohammed, or casts aspersions upon Islam, or upon the authenticity of the holy Koran, or who rejects the divinity of Allah.'' Rushdie said in a telephone hookup with a news conference that it is up to Iranian leaders whether to withdraw the death sentence. But he added, ``I feel a lot safer tonight than I felt yesterday.'' Many Moslems worldwide objected to Rushdie's use of the names of the Prophet Mohammed's wives for the prostitutes in his novel and the implication that Mohammed wrote the Koran, Islam's holy book, instead of receiving it from God. El-Essawy said Rushdie now had a ``clean slate'' with the Moslem world because he had only now professed his belief that ``there is no God but Allah and that Mohammed is his last prophet.'' In addition to el-Essawy, Rushdie met with two imams from the Regent's Park Mosque - Dr. Zaki Badawi, principal of the Moslem College in Britain and Dr. Hohammed Ali Mahgoub, Egypt's secretary of state for endowment and head of the Supreme Council for Islamic Affairs, as well as Yousef el-Sharkawy, second secretary at the Egyptian Embassy. Rushdie's statement was welcomed by other Moslem leaders, who nonetheless demanded that the book be withdrawn entirely from circulation. ``Until the book is completely removed our campaign goes on,'' said Sher Azam of the Council for Mosques in Bradford, where the book had been publicly burned. Iqbal Sacranie, joint convener of the United Kingdom Committee on Islamic Affairs, said Rushdie's statement was a positive step, but also called for ``the withdrawal from circulation of this blasphemous book.'' El-Essawy argued that Rushdie could not be sentenced to death as an apostate because he had not been a believing Moslem when he wrote the novel. He characterized Rushdie as a ``convert,'' and quoted the author as saying, ``There is no difference between Rushdie and Islam.'' ``This is the community that is close to my heart,'' Rushdie told the news conference. ``To come closer to it has given me a great deal of joy.'' He said he would not permit any further translations of the book ``while any risk of further offense exists,'' and added that he would ``continue to work for a better understanding of Islam in the world, as I have always attempted to do in the past.'' No one was available for comment Monday at Viking Penguin, publishers the hardback book. However, the publisher had previously shown no enthusiasm for a paperback, a position that had drawn criticism from Rushdie. If there was no paperback, he said in an interview in January with the Independent on Sunday newspaper, ``in a few years the book simply won't be there for anyone who wants to read it. It will, in all practical terms, have been suppressed.'' ``The Satanic Verses'' has sold more than 1 million copies in English - almost three-quarters of those in the United States - and was on the Sunday Times of London's best-seller list for nearly a year. It has been translated into 15 languages and banned in more than 20 countries. Rushdie, born in Bombay, India, and now a naturalized British citizen, has been in hiding since Feb. 14, 1989. His native country was the first to ban the book, in October 1988. In September 1989, a trade survey found booksellers in England divided on the question of stocking any paperback edition. Forty percent said they would not handle it, 44 percent said they would, according to Publishing News.

DOC.HEAD: US Disagrees With Chinese Attack on Rights Policy
DOC.TEXT: The State Department on Monday rejected charges by China's Communist Party that the United States is using its human rights policy to subvert the Chinese system of government. Responding to an editorial in the party organ People's Daily, deputy spokesman Richard Boucher said the United States merely wants China to live up to internationally accepted human rights standards. The harsh tone f the editorial contrasted sharply with the generally friendly reception given in Beijing last week to Richard Schifter, the assistant secretary for human rights. Boucher said, ``Needless to say we disagee with its (the People's Daily's) assessment of our human rights policy ... We don't seek to undermine the Chinese government nor to interfere in its internal affairs.'' Rather, he said, the United States tries to point out to Chinese authorities where they violate international human rights standards and to advise China of the likely consequences in terms of U.S. policy. Boucher said the United States tries ``to persuade the Chinese government to modify its practices to conform to international law.'' The People's Daily editorial made sarcastic references to what it called the U.S. ``guardians of human rights.'' ``Everyone can see clearly that `human rights' clamored for by these guardians have been used to suppress the masses, interfere in others and protect the hegemony of rule by the bourgeoisie and dollar imperialists,'' the editorial said. After Schifter left China last week, a Foreign Ministry spokesman indicated a new openness to discuss rights issues. Schifter and U.S. Embassy officials said they detected a distinct thawing of Chinese attitudes on such questions. Schifter submitted to Chinese officials a list of 150 Chinese prisoners believed held for political or religious activities, and asked for a detailed description of their status. Schifter indicated that China's softer attitude suggested they were anxious about the possibility Congress might strip some trade benefits that China receives from the United States. China's economy has deteriorated, and some analysts believe the country has become increasingly reliant on its trade with the United States, which reportedly shows a $10 billion surplus in China's favor. U.S. officials also have said that American support for Chinese loan applications at international financial institutions is contingent on China's human rights performance. Despite the evidence last week of a more flexible Chinese attitude on human rights, Schifter said he would not recommend an easing of the remaining sanctions on China. Those sanctions were imposed after the massacre of pro-democracy demonstrators at Tiananmen Square 18 months ago. Among other sanctions, the United States no longer permits large ceremonial visits by Chinese and American delegations to each other's capital.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Briefed by Defense Secretary Cheney, Gen. Powell
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS grafs 2-4 to update with Cheney's returning to Pentagon and edits throughout to add background
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon's top civilian and military officers brought President Bush up to date on the tense situation in the Persian Gulf Monday in a briefing at the president's mountaintop retreat at Camp David. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Gen. Colin L. Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, returned to Washington from a five-day visit to Saudi Arabia on Sunday and helicoptered Monday to the camp about 60 miles north of the capital in western Maryland. Neither the White House nor the Defense Department gave any details of their talks and Cheney made no comments to reporters when he returned to the Pentagon. In Saudi Arabia, Cheney and Powell met with senior commanders and some of the nearly 300,000 American troops stationed in and around the desert kingdom. The United Nations has set a Jan. 15 deadline for Iraq to withdraw from neighboring Kuwait, which the Iraqis invaded on Aug. 2 and later annexed. Cheney said during his Mideast trip that the refusal of Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein to withdraw as the deadline draws closer increases the likelihood of war. ``Each day that goes by, each week without signs of an Iraqi withdrawal, moves us that much closer to the point at which we and other members of the coalition may have no other choice,'' Cheney said during a stopover Sunday in Cairo. In the final days of their visit, Cheney and Powell toughened their rhetoric against Saddam, apparently to counter statements made a U.S. military official early in the trip that American ground forces might not be ready for comment until after the mid-January deadline. ``If I were Saddam Hussein, I would take very seriously what the president said,'' Cheney said on the flight home. ``That is that we are deploying the military capability to implement the U.N. resolutions and to force him out of Kuwait should that be necessary.'' Cheney also said during the visit, in response to a sailor's question, that he was confident the allies ``that really count'' would not abandon the multinational military force if Iraq withdrew only partly from Kuwait. He specifically mentioned the Saudis, Egyptians and British. On the flight home, he said he was not trying to imply that Syria and France were hedging their commitment to support their allies. Both Cheney and Powell said there was no timetable for attack by U.S. forces, which include Marines stationed 50 miles from the Iraqi border. The defense secretary described the trip as ``enormously successful'' but gave no details of his meetings, some of which even most of his top aides were not allowed to attend. After his return from Camp David, Cheney left for Wyoming for a family vacation in his home state. He is expected back in Washington right after New Year's Day.

DOC.HEAD: Eastern Germans Share Christmas With Soviet Soldiers
DOC.TEXT: A home-cooked meal, a little gift, a tour of the big city. On Christmas Eve, such simple gestures of good will captured not only holiday spirit, but historic times. Eastern Germans opened their doors to the Soviet soldiers who once occupied the former nation. The once-feared Red Army paid a holiday visit, bearing not arms but good tidings. ``It's heart-to-heart contact, people to people,'' said Klaus Wuest. ``The old regime was based on suspicion and hatred. Now we can be friendly.'' Wuest said he contacted the Soviet command last week and asked if it would allow a Soviet soldier to spend Christmas Eve with him, his wife, Liane, and their 5-year-old son, Willi. Monday morning, 19-year-old Nikolai showed up in uniform at the door of their home in Bernau, a small city just north of Berlin. Nikolai, from the Ukraine city of Lvov, spoke only a little German. The Wuests spoke no Russian. Yet they toured downtown Berlin, lingering a bit by a large memorial to the Soviet soldiers who died while conquering Nazi Germany. ``Not too long ago, neither of us could have come to this place,'' said Wuest, a window washer. The memorial, a large statue of a helmeted Soviet soldier, stands in what used to be West Berlin, a short walk from where the Berlin Wall once kept Wuest and his countrymen under Soviet domination. ``Even though Soviets lived in our city, we had very little contact with them,'' said Wuest. ``Now we can see how hard it will be for these young men.'' The family members said they were concerned about the unstable situation in the Soviet Union and they and Nikolai did not want to reveal his last name. ``Even though his commander said it is OK (to join the family), he could have a new commander tomorrow who says it's not,'' Wuest said. This was one of several such meetings during the holidays. Two nationalities with a long tradition of animosity stopped and shared a moment as they hurtle in opposite directions. Eastern Germans are experiencing tough times as they move to a radically different economic system, but they face a brighter future as part of wealthy West Germany. Soviet soldiers are preparing to return to a homeland also in turmoil. Unlike Germany, however, the Soviet Union's very existence is uncertain. Earlier this month, a German friendship society, the German Community, urged eastern Germans to invite Soviet soldiers home for the holidays. The society said late last week that it had received thousands of responses. Germany has been aggressive in collecting money and food to ship to the Soviet Union to help offset dire food distribution problems in the nation. Most of that aid has emanated from former West Germany, however. Many eastern Germans still resent the fact that the Soviet Union imposed the Communist system on their nation and kept 360,000 troops on their soil. But good will does exist in eastern Germany. Brandenburg state has sent gift packages of food to Soviet bases. News programs have shown young soldiers, some looking a little embarrassed, accepting them. The images touched the members of the Kiesov family. They are expecting a Soviet soldier Christmas Day. ``Our children are grown now and I saw these young men, 18, 19, on television,'' said Siegfried Kiesov, 58, from the town of Klein Machnow outside Berlin. ``We had a lot of sympathy.'' Kiesov said he was alarmed by the overt hostility toward Soviet soldiers after East Germans threw off communism last year and began to freely express themselves. ``The situation is hard, there are a lot of people with nothing under the Christmas tree,'' he said. ``But it is harder for these soldiers. We can be optimistic about our future, but I don't know if they can.''

DOC.HEAD: Jury Convicts Man of Murder, Other Charges
DOC.TEXT: A jury has convicted an alleged gang leader of murder and 17 other charges for crimes committed during a spree to celebrate his birthday. James Walker, 24, was found guilty Friday of premeditated murder, aggravated kidnapping and rape in the beating death of Roseanna Johnson. Her battered body was found in July in a park. Walker also was found guilty of aggravated kidnapping, aggravated sodomy, aggravated robbery, aggravated battery, three counts of aggravated burglary, two counts of rape, two counts of theft, battery, attempted aggravated criminal sodomy and aggravated assault. Prosecutors said Walker and some other people got drunk and went on the crime spree to celebrate his birthday. Defense attorney Richard Ney had urged the jury to acquit Walker, saying he was too drunk to know what he was doing and is mildly retarded. The jury is to return Wednesday to recommend a sentence. Walker could be sentenced to 15 years to life in prison.

DOC.HEAD: Halfway House Walkaways Charged in Cabin Slayings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf, `The sheriff's ...' to CORRECT call to sheriff to Saturday afternoon, sted early Saturday; Picks up 9th graf, `The two-story ...'
DOC.TEXT: Two parolees who walked away from a halfway house were charged Monday in the slayings of a woman and her daughter who were shot to death during a botched burglary at a remote mountain cabin. The women apparently interrupted a burglary at their cabin in Weber Canyon, about 45 miles east of Salt Lake City, where they were staying during a holiday gathering. Von Lester Taylor, 25, and Edward Steven Deli, 21, each were charged with two counts of first-degree murder, one count of attempted first-degree murder and two counts of aggravated kidnapping. They also were charged with aggravated assault, theft, arson and failure to heed a police signal to stop. Taylor and Deli are accused of killing Beth Harmon Tidwell Potts, who was in her mid-70s and from Murray, Utah, and her 51-year-old daughter, Kay Tidwell Tiede, of Humble, Texas. The two women died at the scene of Saturday's shooting. Mrs. Tiede's husband, Rolf, 51, was shot in the face and was flown to the University of Utah Medical Center in Salt Lake City, where he was in good condition Monday, a nursing supervisor said. Taylor and Deli allegedly kidnapped two daughters of the Tiedes', ages 20 and 17. The younger women, whose names were not released, were rescued unharmed after police forced the suspects' car off a road during a chase, the Summit County Sheriff's Department reported. The sheriff's office was notified Saturday afternoon by a caller who reported hearing shots and seeing two men fleeing with the sisters. The two-story cabin was set afire before the suspects fled, police said. A deputy saw the suspects' car headed southbound and gave chase. The pursuit lasted nearly 10 miles. The deputy was joined by a police officer from nearby Kamas, who fired two shots at one of the men after he jumped out of the car and pulled a gun, authorities said. Both shots missed the suspect, who threw down his weapon and surrendered, authorities said. The other suspect, who was in the car, also surrendered. Taylor and Deli are recent Utah State Prison parolees who had been staying at Salt Lake City's Orange Street Community Center until they failed to return from job hunting on Dec. 14, said Dave Franchina, a Department of Corrections spokesman. He said Taylor was paroled Oct. 23 and moved to the Ogden Community Corrections Center. He stayed there until Nov. 23, when he transferred to the Orange Street halfway house. Deli was paroled Nov. 27 and went directly to the halfway house, Franchina said. Deli was imprisoned Sept. 6, 1989, on a zero-to-five-years arson sentence. Taylor was serving one to 15 years for aggravated burglary. Third Circuit Judge Floyd Gowans ordered Taylor and Deli held without bail pending a Jan. 8 preliminary hearing.

DOC.HEAD: Soldier Injured In Training Accident Dies
DOC.TEXT: One of five soldiers injured in a training accident last week has died, bringing the death toll in Operation Desert Shield to 81, the U.S. military's Central Command announced Monday. The soldiers from the 3/320th Field Artillery of the 101st Airborne Division were participating in a training exercise Thursday when a 105mm howitzer exploded, the military said. One of the soldiers, who had been in a coma, died Sunday, the military said. His name was withheld pending notification of next of kin. The cause of the accident is under investigation. Two sailors from the aircraft carrier USS Midway also died Sunday when their tour bus overturned on a liberty excursion, the military's Joint Information Bureau announced Monday. Five other sailors were injured, two seriously, in the accident 50 miles south of al-Dhafra airbase in Abu Dhabi. On Saturday in the Mediterranean, a chartered Israeli ferry carrying U.S. sailors capsized while returning to the USS Saratoga from the Israeli port of Haifa, killing 21 sailors.

DOC.HEAD: USS Saratoga Sailors Remembered in Memorial Service at Homeport
DOC.TEXT: The 21 sailors from the USS Saratoga killed in a ferry boat accident in Israel were remembered Monday by 500 mourners at the ship's North Florida homeport. ``The unanticipated tragedy in Haifa harbor has refocused us, and the loss is immense,'' said Capt. Peter A.C. Long, commanding officer of Mayport Naval Station. ``We grieve for them. We grieve for their families.'' ``Our purpose today is simple and sad - to remember and pay tribute to our shipmates,'' Long said. ``For some of us today, we grieve for family. For others of us, we grieve for lost shipmates who died serving their country.'' Loud sobbing broke out in the Mayport Naval Station Chapel as Alicia Cuebas, a Saratoga ombudsman, read aloud the names of the 21 dead. After each name was read, a bell chimed. The chapel had been decorated for Christmas. Cmdr. G.C. O'Connor, command chaplain at Mayport, said people ask him why the accident happened at this time of year. ``We're on God's calendar, he's not on our calendar,'' O'Connor told the mourners, about half of whom were dressed in Navy uniforms. After the Christmas Eve service, Lt. Cmdr. Dennis E. Spangler, another chaplain, said ``We are all grieving ... This could have been our sons.'' Relatives of Delwin Delgado and Philip Wilkinson, two of the sailors killed Saturday, attended the service. Delgado's birthday was last Friday, O'Connor said. At the front of the chapel was a bouquet of red and white flowers from the crew of the USS Lexington, a training carrier based in Pensacola, and a wreath of yellow daisies, daffodils, and chrysanthemums. At a service Sunday aboard the Saratoga, crewmen bade a tearful farewell to their 21 comrades. The accident occurred as sailors returned from liberty in Haifa, Israel. It was the deadliest accident involving U.S. servicemen in Operation Desert Shield. Nineteen bodies were recovered Saturday, including six pulled by Israeli divers from the sunken, two-deck ferry. Another was found Sunday. On Monday, the Navy called off a search for one soldier whose body was never retrieved. Aviation Ordnanceman 3rd Class Anthony J. Fleming, 25, of Buffalo, N.Y., is presumed to have died in the ferry accident. A military transport jet carrying the 20 bodies landed at Dover Air Force Base Monday afternoon. A Navy honor guard and color guard stood silently under a sunny sky as the bodies of their fallen comrades arrived. Deputy Chief of Chaplains Rear Adm. David White said a brief prayer. He said the dead sailors presented themselves before God's grace in pursuit of peace. He quoted from the Bible: ``Blessed are the peacemakers for they shall be called the sons of God.'' The remains will be prepared for burial at the base mortuary before being transferred to the next of kin. The Saratoga task force, based at Mayport Naval Air Station in Florida, includes the destroyer Sampson, the cruiser South Carolina and the combat stores ship Sirius. It has a crew of 6,200 men. The Saratoga and its escort ships had come from the Red Sea where they joined in the naval buildup in the Persian Gulf that began when Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Two Israeli investigations and one probe by the U.S. Navy into the ferry sinking are underway.

DOC.HEAD: Closed-Flap Religious Services, Subdued Festivities on Christmas Eve
LaserPhotos DHR3,4,8,7
DOC.TEXT: U.S. soldiers, on heightened alert against terrorist attacks, displayed their trees and sang ``Silent Night'' behind closed tent flaps in Christmas Eve ceremonies muffled to avoid offending Moslems. Protestant and Roman Catholic chaplains, renamed morale officers so as not to disturb Saudi sensitivities, began celebrating Midnight Mass more than 12 hours early for small groups of soldiers. ``We had Midnight Mass at noon,'' said Coast Guard Petty Officer 2nd Class Ron Sauers, 44, of Rochester, N.Y., who dressed as Santa, using toilet paper for a beard and wearing a red stocking cap sent to a fellow reservist. `The priest had already done three Masses. You take it when you get it.'' He spoke at a steak barbeque with colleagues from the 301st Port Security Unit in eastern Saudi Arabia. The news media were barred from all religious observances, except on the Navy hospital ship Mercy, in international waters in the Persian Gulf. Reporters who visited one Marine camp were told they could not write about or photograph any religious ceremony if they saw one, which they didn't. On the Mercy, Santa and his reindeer arrived before an ecumenical service. Protestant Chaplain, Lt. Cmdr. Doug Weadick, 40, of Hornell, N.Y., said his Christmas message would concentrate on ``being able to relinquish your life to the powers that be.'' For many of the 280,000 U.S. troops in the Persian Gulf, not only was it Christmas away from home, but Christmas in an alien culture where all religions except Islam are banned. The U.S. military has said the religious needs of all troops will be met, but privately. ``I'm pretty disgusted with it but what are you going to do,'' Coast Guardsman Bill Degnan, of Youngstown, N.Y., said as he cooked steaks for his colleagues. Pentagon spokesman Army Lt. Col. Steve Roy said in Washington, ``We are conducting religious services, and they are being conducted with regard to the sensitivities of our hosts.'' ``I don't know that I'd classify that as secrecy,'' he said. For many soldiers, homesickness and anxiety were heightened by the higher state of alert, just three weeks before the U.N. Jan. 15 deadline for Iraq to withdraw its troops from Kuwait. Military sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the alert was ordered because of fears of a terrorist attack over the Christmas holidays. Servicemen and women celebrated the holiday in a variety of ways: -Hundreds of desert-weary soldiers boarded the cruise liner Cunard Princess on Christmas Eve for a recreation tour. A woman dressed as Santa Claus greeted them as they hurried up the gangplank shortly after the ship docked off Bahrain. The Pentagon leased the ship for six months as a floating hotel for the troops, at a cost of $31 million. -In a tent in the middle of the desert, two young Navy hospital corpsmen who sing under the name Fried Brains sang Christmas carols for the Marine Combat Service Support Detachment 111. The songs included ``Silver Bells,'' ``Winter Wonderland,'' and in apparent violation of rules against singing religious songs in public, ``Silent Night.'' -In the Saudi capital, Riyadh, Bob Hope performed in a U.S. military compound, keeping a tradition of entertaining U.S. troops at Christmas that dates to 1941 for him. But the 87-year-old comedian left Marie Osmond and the Pointer Sisters - part of his show - in Bahrain, again not to offend the Saudis with women entertainers. Hope's travel itinerary was not disclosed for security reasons, but his spokesman, Frank Liberman, said on Monday that Hope and his troupe will be performing non-stop in the Persian Gulf, hopping from ship to sand to entertain Operation Desert Shield troops. Also scheduled to be in the troupe were Hope's wife Dolores, actress Ann Jillian, country music singer Aaron Tippin, former Cincinnati Reds catcher Johnny Bench and actress Khrystyne Haje of the TV comedy ``Head of the Class.'' French Defense Minister Jean-Pierre Chevenement canceled a meeting with the Saudi defense minster after the kingdom refused to let rock star Eddy ``Schmoll'' Mitchell entertain troops in the desert, a French Embassy spokesman said. For many soldiers it was just another working day, though some had light duties and slept late. There were a few fun runs in the desert, carol concerts and merrymaking. All the Navy ships had real Christmas trees and so did the Coast Guard, sent by well-wishers from home. But out in the desert the trees were mainly of the small, plastic variety. Coast Guard Petty Officer 3rd Class Gary Kmetty, 39, of Alsip, Ill., took a ham, sent from home, out on his patrol boat for Christmas Eve dinner. Ham - banned by Moslems - is also on the menu for Tuesday's Christmas dinner along with turkey and roast beef. ``To me, it's just another day,'' said Kmetty. ``I quit watching the calendar.'' At the Coast Guard barbeque, another Santa, Machinist Technician 1st Class Bob Miller from Rochester, N.Y., had an automatic rifle slung across his shoulder instead of the usual bag of presents. Asked if he had a present for Saddam Hussein, Miller smiled through his beard and said: ``I got one round in here with his name if I ever see him.''

DOC.HEAD: Constitutional Change Removed From California's Prop. 115
DOC.TEXT: The state Supreme Court on Monday stripped a prosecution-sponsored crime initiative of its most ambitious provision, a narrowing of many constitutional rights in criminal cases. The court ruled unanimously that a portion of Proposition 115, approved by state voters last June, made such a fundamental change in the structure of California government that it amounted to a revision of the state Constitution, which cannot be done by initiative. The court upheld the rest of the measure on a 6-1 vote. Dubbed the Speedy Trial Initiative by sponsors, Proposition 115 contained numerous changes aimed at shortening court proceedings in criminal cases, including restrictions on pretrial hearings, continuances and questioning of prospective jurors. It also requires defense lawyers to disclose evidence to prosecutors before trial. One provision required state courts in criminal cases to follow U.S. Supreme Court rulings in applying a long list of constitutional rights, many of which have been interpreted by state courts as giving broader protection for defendants than federal rulings. The court, in an opinion by Chief Justice Malcolm Lucas, declared the constitutional changes to be a ``revision'' rather than a valid constitutional amendment. A revision can be submitted to voters only by the Legislature or a constitutional convention. California courts would lose power to interpret fundamental rights, and ``ultimate protection of criminal defendants from deprivation of their constitutional rights would be left in the care of the United States Supreme Court,'' Lucas wrote. The ruling keeps California ``at the forefront of the movement among state supreme courts across the country to give independent meaning to their state constitutions,'' said Gerald Uelmen, dean of the University of Santa Clara Law School, one of three lawyers who filed suit against Proposition 115. Chief Assistant Attorney General Richard Iglehart, whose office defended the measure, said procedural changes remaining in the measure, such as new time limits on hearings and trial-setting and the conduct of preliminary hearings, are already quickening the pace of criminal cases around the state. Under Proposition 115, preliminary hearings, the sometimes-lengthy sessions to determine whether a defendant should be held for trial, are abbreviated. The hearings are eliminated when a grand jury issues an indictment. The measure also requires judges rather than lawyers to question prospective jurors; requires pretrial disclosures of evidence by the defense, formerly required only of the prosecutor; requires defense lawyers to be prepared for trial in 60 days;, and makes it harder for the defense to get separate trials for multiple crimes. The measure also allows 16-year-olds convicted of capital murder to be sentenced to life without parole, establishes penalties for a newly defined crime of torture, and expands the death penalty.

DOC.HEAD: Western Hostages Spend Sixth Christmas In Captivity
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS last graf, `The other ...' with 2 grafs to ADD names of other hostages; no pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BEI2
DOC.TEXT: Iranian officials and Lebanese Shiite Moslem fundamentalists have said for months that Western hostages would be freed before the year's end, but as the days dwindle, so do hopes. Five hostages held by pro-Iranian extremists were freed during the year. But 13 remain in captivity and there is no indication they will be released by Jan. 1. Hopes that all hostages might be freed this year followed improvements in Iran's relations with the West following the death of revolutionary patriarch Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini in June 1989. American educators Robert Polhill and Frank Reed were freed 10 days apart in April. Swiss Red Cross workers Emanuel Christen and Elio Erriquez as well as Irishman Brian Keenan were released in August. That was a record for hostage releases in a single year since 1983, when Shiites launched their campaign of anti-Western kidnappings, suicide bombings and aircraft hijackings. Many hoped there would be more releases ``to close the file of the hostages by the end of 1990,'' as many Iranian and Lebanese Shiite officials have said. But Hussein Musawi, reputed mentor of hostage-holding factions, said U.S. military intervention in the Persian Gulf following Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait hurt the chances for freedom for the six remaining American hostages. Musawi heads a pro-Syrian wing in Hezbollah, or the Party of God, Iran's main ally in Lebanon and the umbrella organization of the Shiite fanatical groups holding most of the Westerners. The longest held is American journalist Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press. He was kidnapped on March 16, 1985. For Anderson, of Lorain, Ohio, and fellow American hostage Thomas Sutherland, this Christmas is their sixth in captivity. It is the fifth for two other Americans, Joseph Cicippio and Edward Austin Tracy, and for British journalist John McCarthy. Anglican Church envoy Terry Waite and American professors Alann Steen and Jesse Turner have spent four Christmases in captivity. American and British relatives and friends sent Christmas greetings for publication in Beirut newspapers, hoping the captors would convey them to the hostages. The messages included one from Anderson's sister, Peggy Say, and from his daughter Sulome, 5, whom he has never seen. She was born four months after his abduction. Sulome on Monday visited for the first time her father's office at the AP bureau in Beirut. The office has been left as it was when Anderson, now 43, was kidnapped. She sat on Anderson's desk and held his telephone. His pictures in captivity hung on a board behind her. ``I want to talk to daddy. I want to kiss him,'' Sulome said. Anderson's abduction has been claimed by Islamic Jihad, or Islamic Holy War, believed made up of pro-Iranian Shiite zealots. The same group claims it holds Sutherland, 59, dean of agriculture at the American University of Beirut, who was kidnapped on June 9, 1985. ``I don't really have any words left,'' said Sutherland's wife, Jean, who has continued to live on the university campus. ``I wish them all the merriest Christmas and can't stop hoping they will be out this year.'' Waite, 51, disappeared on Jan. 20, 1987, after leaving a Beirut hotel for a rendezvous with Anderson's and Sutherland's captors. No group has claimed it is holding him. Steen, 51, and Turner, 43, were kidnapped four days later from the campus of the U.S.-affiliated Beirut University College. A group calling itself Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine claimed responsibility. Cicippio, 60, of Valley Forge, Pa., was acting comptroller of the university when he was kidnapped on Sept. 12, 1986. The Revolutionary Justice Organization claimed responsibility for his seizure. Tracy, 60, of Burlington, Vt., a writer, was abducted on Oct. 21, 1986, and the same group that seized Cicippio claimed responsibility. McCarthy, 34, a London-based television journalist was kidnapped on April 17, 1986, while driving to Beirut airport to catch a flight for home. No group has claimed responsibility. Recently freed hostages Reed and Keenan said McCarthy was held with them by Shiite captors. The other Western hostages in Lebanon are Italian businessman Alberto Molinari, 71, kidnapped on Sept. 11, 1985, retired British pilot Jack Mann, 76, and Germans Heinrich Struebig, 49, and Thomas Kemptner, 29. Briton Alec Collett disappeared in 1985. A group that claimed to be holding him released a videotape purporting to show Collett hanged, but his death has never been confirmed.

DOC.HEAD: $20,000 Donated to Survivors of Fatal Fire
DOC.TEXT: More than $20,000 has been donated to survivors of a fire last weekend that killed a man and six of his nine children, officials said Monday. ``It's coming in faster than we can count,'' said Tom Keilman, chaplain for the Canton Township Police Department in Wayne County. ``We have conservatively at this time over $20,000 in donations,'' he said. Keilman said the fund gave more than $2,000 in cash to Debbie Dell'Orco and her three surviving children for their immediate needs. The rest of the donations will be issued to her in a check, he said. ``They've got some incredible expenses,'' he said. ``(She is) still distraught. She seems to be doing a little better than she was yesterday.'' On Monday, Fire Chief Melvin Paulun said the Saturday night blaze was still being investigated. It apparently was ignited by a fallen Christmas tree. Killed in the blaze were Martin Dell'Orco, 38, and his children, Bonnie, 12; Sara, 9; Katie, 8; twins Megan and Michael, 5, and Robert, 4. Dell'Orco at first escaped the blaze, but he died after re-entering the burning house. Mrs. Dell'Orco, 36, and a son, Adam, 6, escaped. Two other children, Jimmy, 16, and Kelly, 14, were not at home. In addition to money, an attorney has volunteered his services and people have offered rent-free houses and apartments, Keilman said. ``People are opening their hearts and giving forth,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: ``Our purpose today is simple and sad - to remember and pay tribute to our shipmates. For some of us today, we grieve for family. For others of us, we grieve for lost shipmates who died serving their country.'' - Capt. Peter A.C. Long, commanding officer of Mayport Naval Station, homeport of the USS Saratoga, eulogizing 21 sailors killed in a ferry boat accident off Israel. --- ``We are conducting religious services, and they are being conducted with regard to the sensitivities of our hosts.'' - Pentagon spokesman Army Lt. Col. Steve Roy on the celebration of Christmas in Saudi Arabia. --- ``The sacrifices you make will never be forgotten. America is behind you. The world is behind you and history is behind you.'' - President George Bush in a Christmas message to the troops in the Persian Gulf.

DOC.HEAD: Waiting List Grows for Families Offering Holiday Homes to Troops
DOC.TEXT: So many families offered to invite soldiers to their homes on Christmas Day that organizers of the holiday Adopt-a-Soldier program at Fort Sill had to start a waiting list, an Army spokesman said Monday. About 400 soldiers of the 2nd Battalion, 80th Field Artillery, who can't go home because they are training for service in the Persian Gulf, will spend the holiday with volunteer Oklahoma families, said post spokesman Bill Orndorff. Brad Allen wanted to ``adopt'' four soldiers, but he's only getting two. Allen said he plans to serve them a turkey dinner on Christmas Day. ``I told them they were free to do whatever they wanted after the meal. And guess what? They like football,'' Allen said. ``So we're going to watch the games.'' Diana Mercado, a former soldier married to one of the battalion's drill sergeants, helped arrange the holiday homes-away-from-homes for the soldiers earlier this month. ``Something needed to be done more than cookies and egg nog in the rec room,'' she said at the time. Some soldiers who live in Oklahoma are being allowed to make brief trips home for Christmas, Orndorff said. But soldiers who live outside the state can't go home. The soldiers Allen will host are from Texas and West Virginia. ``It's my understanding these are young men and women preparing for possible duty in the Persian Gulf and they're in a situation where they can't go home for Christmas,'' Allen said. ``Helping them out is a way we can show our love and appreciation to them.''

DOC.HEAD: Oregon Slaying Suspects Recognized in Montana, Captured in Wyoming
DOC.TEXT: Two suspects in a Christmas Day 1985 slaying in Oregon were arrested Monday in Wyoming after people in Missoula, where the two had been living, saw the pair's pictures on a television crime show. Raymond Mitchell and Susan Peterson were wanted on charges of murder and attempted murder in the fatal shooting of Peterson's estranged husband and the wounding of another person five years ago in Portland, Ore., said Missoula County Sheriff's Lt. Don Morman. He said Missoula authorities received two calls early Monday from people who saw an account of the slaying on the Fox network program ``America's Most Wanted'' late Sunday and recognized Mitchell and Peterson. The callers said the pair had been living under assumed names at a local trailer park. Deputies went to the trailer court and learned that the couple had moved to Cheyenne, Wyo., Morman said. He said Missoula authorities forwarded descriptions of the suspects and their vehicle to the Laramie County Sheriff's Department in Cheyenne. Sheriff Rudy Restivo said his deputies found Mitchell, 34, and Peterson, 27, living at a Cheyenne trailer park. The two were arrested Monday without incident. Two children with the couple were placed in the custody of Wyoming child-welfare authorities.

DOC.HEAD: Saudi King Fahd Asks Saddam To Avert Disaster for Iraqi People
DOC.TEXT: King Fahd of Saudi Arabia appealed to Iraqi President Saddam Hussein on Monday to withdraw his forces from Kuwait and avert a disaster for the Iraqi people. Saddam would find his Persian Gulf neighbors ready for reconciliation if he left Kuwait, Fahd said in what appeared to be an eleventh-hour appeal to Iraq to avert war. ``We wish that ... (Saddam), who was to us a brother, friend and ally, know that the curtain is not yet drawn on the scorching war and that he ... can spare himself and his people its horror,'' Fahd said in a statement distributed to his five allies in the Gulf Cooperation Council, gathered in Doha for their annual summit. Others attending were Sultan Qaboos of Oman, and sheiks Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah of Kuwait, Zayed bin Sultan Al Nahyan of the United Arab Emirates, Khalifa bin Hamad Al Thani of Qatar and Prime Minister Khalifa bin Salman Al Khalifa of Bahrain. Fahd advised Saddam, ``It is braver to opt for peace than for war,'' warning him that ``you and your people would be the first casualties of the horror of war.'' The Saudi monarch's desert country is now site for a huge multinational force assembled after Iraq captured Kuwait in a lighting invasion on Aug. 2. U.S. troops comprise the greater part of the force. U.S. leaders, who along with Fahd will decide whether and when to launch a war on Iraq, have been warning Saddam the hours are ticking away if he does not evacuate Kuwait peacefully by the Jan. 15 U.N. Security Council deadline. Fahd's address was made available to reporters at the news center near the summit's hotel meeting site. Fhd pledged to ``put the gulf house in order,'' and urged his allies to ``unite politically, build the gulf common market, accelerate the pace toward economic integration, and achieve collective defense.'' The leaders of the richest Arab states are discussing pooling funds to acquire sophisticated weapons to arm a unified defense force for the region. Officials said the leaders also talked about establishing a joint military industry and studied a $15 billion aid program for Arab nations hurt by the crisis. The gulf leaders opened the conference Saturday seeking ways to devise a strategy for liberating Kuwait and preventing similar aggression in the future. One official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Iran was invited to attend parts of the summit sessions. Qatar Foreign Minister Mubarak al-Khater told reporters Iran would be included in any Gulf Cooperation Council security arrangement. The Persian Gulf sits on two-thirds of the world's oil reserves, with about 40 percent controlled by the desert sheikdoms. Kuwait's government-in-exile has indicated that after an Iraqi withdrawal, it would discuss the oil, money and border dispute that Saddam raised two weeks before the invasion. However, it has insisted it would not cede any territory.

DOC.HEAD: Damages Awarded To Families Of Pilots Killed In 1987 Mid-Air Collision
DOC.TEXT: A judge ordered the federal government Monday to pay more than $700,000 to survivors of two pilots killed in a mid-air collision over a suburb in 1987. Survivors of the four pilots killed in the Jan. 15, 1987, collision - two in each aircraft - sued the federal government, claiming negligence on the part of air traffic controllers at Salt Lake International Airport. The pilots were among 10 people killed in the accident. U.S. District Judge Thomas Greene ruled that controllers were 51 percent responsible for the crash and that the government should pay damages to the families of Chester Baker and Paul Lietz, pilots of the smaller, private plane. Controllers are federal employees. Greene awarded the Baker family $387,000 and the Lietz family $377,000. The survivors of the SkyWest pilots settled with the government for an undisclosed amount in October. In a 37-page ruling, Greene said Baker and Lietz were partially responsible because they had entered restricted airspace moments before the crash. The judge also concluded the controller in charge of a SkyWest Metroliner, which was on its final approach into the airport, should have seen the smaller plane on the radar scope and alerted the Metroliner. The U.S. Attorney's Office was closed Monday and officials could not be reached for comment.

DOC.HEAD: Pipe-Wielding, Bible-Toting Attacker Was Paint Sniffer, Police Say
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `The victims...' to UPDATE with all victims released from hospital; Pickup 5th graf, `Police were...'
DOC.TEXT: A man who attacked six elderly people at the Golden Acres Home for Jewish Aged apparently has no affiliation with any hate groups but has emotional problems, police said. ``Indications are that he has a mental health history,'' said Deputy Chief Ray Hawkins. ``He is just a drug addict who was acting irrationally. He is a guy who, by his own admission, is a paint sniffer and drug addict.'' William Dudrow, 22, allegedly attacked five women and one man with a 4-foot pipe Saturday night. He was arrested at the home and remained in custody Monday in lieu of $40,000 bail on a burglary charge. The victims of the attack ranged in age from 76 to 90. All six were treated at Baylor University Medical Center and released, hospital officials said. Police were told that Dudrow entered the nursing home by smashing a glass door, carrying a one-inch-thick pipe in one hand and a Bible in the other. Witnesses said Dudrow said, ``I'm God. Do you believe in God?'' as he walked off an elevator into a second-floor recreation area. Witnesses said he told the group not to be afraid of him, but began hitting people with the pipe. Then, Dudrow sat down and waited for police to arrive, residents said. Police were told that he said: ``I did it. I'm sorry. I'm on drugs. I need help.'' Golden Acres has been open for 37 years and has 255 residents.

DOC.HEAD: Salvadoran Leftist Rebels Agree to Extend Holiday Truce
DOC.TEXT: El Salvador's leftist rebel organization announced Monday that at the urging of the United Nations and the Mexican government it had extended a holiday truce through Jan. 1. Earlier, the rebel organization had said it would suspend operations only in San Salvador on Monday and Tuesday, and on Dec. 31 and Jan. 1. But a news release issued by the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, or FMLN, said the guerrillas would suspend all attacks and economic sabotage in the country throughout the eight-day period that began Monday night. The FMLN said it was taking this step in response to ``proposals made by U.N. Secretary General (Javier Perez de Cuellar) ... and the Mexican government,'' despite the ``hypocritical attitude'' adopted by El Salvador's rightist government toward the holiday season. It accused President Alfredo Cristiani's administration of talking peace during the holidays while the army was invading guerrilla areas. ``On one hand they talk about it and on the other they have undertaken great invasion operations in our territory,'' the news release said. About 800 soldiers from the Salvadoran army's elite Atlacatl infantry battalion are leading an operation against rebels holed up in the mountainous areas of northern Chalatenango province. The rebels had begun an offensive earlier this month after the latest of a series of peace talks with Cristiani's U.S.-backed government became deadlocked. The Mexican government applauded the FMLN's decision to extend the truce, saying in a communique Monday, ``The Foreign Ministry congratulates the Salvadoran insurgents for declaring a truce in the desired terms.'' The Bush administration accused the FMLN of planning to intensify its offensive when the truce is over. ``Instead of negotiating to bring peace to El Salvador in 1990, the guerrillas have chosen to bring death and destruction to their country and its people,'' State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said in Washington. ``While professing to observe a truce, they are preparing for more war.'' Five Central American presidents concluded a three-day summit in Costa Rica last week with a statement condemning the FMLN offensive and calling for an immediate cease-fire. Cristiani said last week that the guerrilla's first truce offering fell far short of what people expected. ``What the Salvadoran people want and need are not two 2-day truces but a definitive end to the war,'' he said. Maria Marta Valladares, a guerrilla commander also known as Nidia Diaz, responded that the Salvadoran government must treat the war's underlying problems of economic and social injustice before the rebels will put down their guns. ``It does not make sense to call on us to abandon the armed struggle as long as the causes that gave rise to the armed struggle are not overcome,'' she said. The Salvadoran government had no immediate comment on the latest truce announcment. Leaders of El Salvador, Nicaragua, Honduras, Guatemala, and Costa Rica are scheduled to meet with Mexican President Carlos Salinas de Gortari on Jan. 10-11 to explore ways of achieving peace in Central America through increased trade and economic development. The foreign ministers of Venezuela, Colombia and Spain have been invited to attend the summit in the southern Mexico city of Tuxtla Gutierrez.

DOC.HEAD: Bid For Election Postponement Denied in Albania
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 5 grafs with Greece claiming Albanian border guards killed ethnic Greeks.
DOC.TEXT: Albania's Communist authorities on Monday refused a request by the country's first opposition party to postpone elections scheduled for February, the state ATA news agency reported. The new Democratic Party of Albania presented its request to the parliamentary presidium Monday. It was turned down on the grounds that the urgency of reforms required quick elections and the rapid formation of a parliament, ATA reported. Sihat Tozaj, secretary of the parliamentary presidium, told a representative of the Democratic Party there was ``no objective reason to justify the postponing of elections,'' ATA reported in a dispatch monitored in Vienna. He rejected opposition claims the Feb. 10 election date left the new party insufficient time to organize against the powerful Communists, who have ruled unchallenged for 46 years. The opposition sought to postpone the elections until April or May. ``There are 40 days from today to February 10,'' Tozaj was quoted as saying. Candidates are to be registered no later than 15 days prior to the elections, ``therefore the time at their disposal is enough,'' he said. The opposition had no immediate reaction to the refusal. Democratic Party spokesman Genc Pollo, reached by telephone in Tirana, said the party might have a statement Tuesday. Under a new electoral law adopted last month which allows more than one candidate to compete for the 250 parliamentary seats, candidates must collect at least 300 signatures from eligible voters in any voting district to run. The Democratic Party was founded less than two weeks ago. It faces numerous obstacles in making its program and candidates known. The Communists have used their power over official media to limit information on the new party, meaning it must rely on word of mouth to propagate its cause in a backward nation with poor communications. The party has announced plans to publish an opposition newspaper, but it was unclear where it would get the equipment or funding for the project. Albanian President and Communist Party leader Ramiz Alia began introducing cautious reforms this year. Student protests over slum-like housing led two weeks ago to demands for democracy and helped force the ruling Communists to permit the existence of other parties. The Balkan nation of 3.2 million is the last in Europe to begin reforming hard-line Communist rule. The Greek government charged Monday that Albanian border guards had slain three ethnic Greeks who tried to cross into Greece. Government spokesman Vyron Polydoras, in a statement in Athens, accused Albania of ``extermination in the most revolting fashion.'' The Athens daily Eleftheros Typos claimed Monday that Albanian border guards shot and killed three ethnic Greeks on Dec. 12. One of the victims was decapitated and the head paraded around a village, the newspaper said. The report couldn't be verified and it wasn't clear if the victims were the ones Polydoras was talking about. Albanians have been trickling into Greece over recent weeks, including 100 over the weekend, according to Greek police. Ethnic Greeks from Albania are automatically granted asylum.

DOC.HEAD: Missing Lion Found Shot in Cattle Barn After 2 Weeks Roaming Ozarks
DOC.TEXT: A female lion that roamed the Ozarks for more than two weeks was found in a cattle barn 25 miles from home, wounded and trying to keep warm between two bales of hay. ``It's like an early Christmas present,'' said Kurt Falkenbach, of Branson, owner of 2-year-old Teasha. The lion was hit in the face with shotgun birdshot shortly after it escaped, Falkenbach said. Stone County authorities said no charges would be filed against the person who shot the lion because they had acted out of fear. The lion was found Sunday by the barn's owner; a birdshot pellet was wedged in one eye. Falkenbach, an animal trainer, said the lion was generally in good health but had lost 50 or 60 pounds. Teasha weighed about 250 pounds before taking flight. The lion had been missing since Dec. 6, when it apparently went through a hole in the pen's 8-foot fence. Falkenbach said this was the second time Teasha escaped. The first time the lion broke out to chase some dogs, but Falkenbach was able to get the big cat back into its pen that time.

DOC.HEAD: Drizzle, Army Deployment Mark Christmas Eve in Bethlehem
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with patriarch's prayer for gulf peace, Palestinian leaflets. Picks up 10th graf, Sabah, wearing ...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto JRL1-3
DOC.TEXT: Under the watchful eye of Israeli soldiers, an unusually sparse crowd of worshipers celebrated Christmas Eve at the site of Jesus' birth. A choir from Jerusalem sang holiday carols in Manger Square under a light drizzle. The festivities were subdued because of fears of violence raised by the 3-year-old Palestinian uprising and the Persian Gulf crisis. German tourist Gabriele Beitz, who came with her husband and 11-year-old daughter, said the atmosphere in Bethlehem was ``very, very fearful.'' ``We are very depressed about the place and about the whole political situation here,'' she said. ``For us, Christmas is an event of peace, and here you cannot feel peace.'' Bethlehem's Palestinian town officials canceled Christmas celebrations in solidarity with the uprising against Israeli occupation. Uprising leaders had distributed leaflets prohibiting Palestinians from celebrating publicly, and ordering shops and restaurants to close for the day. The town boasted few decorations. The Roman Catholic patriarch of Jerusalem, Michel Sabah, led a traditional procession to Bethlehem before leading prayers at midnight Mass in neighboring St. Catherine's Church. Sabah prayed for a peaceful resolution of the gulf conflict. Jesus ``shows u the way of love we need today on the eve of a world war, especially under these circumstances, we need peace,'' he said in Arabic and French. ``Our sins will be great if we are not brothers, if our sons from both sides are brought up in hatred and violence. We must build justice, there must be a change.'' About 2,000 Palestinians and European diplomats attended the midnight Mass, which opened a holiday season in the Holy Land featuring three celebrations of Jesus' birth. The others are the Greek Orthodox Christmas on Jan. 7 and the Armenian Orthodox celebration Jan. 19. Hundreds of soldiers and police guarded Bethlehem as white-robed priests earlier led Sabah, the first Palestinian to head the Roman Catholic Church in the Holy Land, into the Church of the Nativity, built over a grotto where tradition says Jesus was born. Sabah, wearing purple robes, was greeted in Manger Square by the Israeli military governor of Bethlehem, Dudu Mufaz. The tradition dates to the 19th century, when Ottoman Turks ruled Palestine. Altar boys carrying candles then led Sabah to pray in the grotto of Jesus' birth. This year only one foreign choir performed in Manger Square on Christmas Eve, that of the First United Methodist Church of Oklahoma City. The 19 singers wore green robes and sang ``Gloria,'' ``Silent Night,'' and ``Oh Bethlehem,'' as people in the crowd held lit candles. Nick Harris, senior pastor of the church, said not all the group came on the trip because of menacing news from the Middle East. Because of the gulf crisis and the uprising, only a few dozen tourists wandered through Manger Square during the day, though the crowd swelled to several hundred after nightfall. In past years the square swarmed with people and was awash in colorful lights. On Monday most of the color was in the red, purple and green berets of the Israeli security forces standing guard around the square. Father Wally Anthony, a Catholic priest from Flint, Mich., now with the church in Rome, said of the scene: ``Sometimes when you read the Scriptures, you read about the soldiers there in the times of 2,000 years ago, and you can identify with that same kind of environment.'' Mayor Elias Freij, a Palestinian, told reporters he was praying for ``peace on earth and good will toward all people, and peace in the Holy Land between Israelis and Palestinians, and peace amongst all the Arabs.'' Freij blamed lack of tourists on a U.S. State Department advisory warning Americans not to travel to the Mideast or go to the occupied territories. Security was especially heavy because of a wave of Arab attacks on Israelis after the Oct. 8 Temple Mount riot in which Israeli police killed 17 Palestinians. As a Christmas gesture, the military announced it was releasing 217 Palestinian prisoners. Most had less than a month to go in their sentences. But curfews kept 15,000 Arabs inside their homes in three nearby refugee camps. In the nearby Hebron district, soldiers fired on two Arab suspects who resisted detention, killing one and wounding another, an army spokesman said. The slain man, not identified, was suspected of killing an Arab woman and shooting at Israeli soldiers, the spokesman said. The national Itim news agency said both men carried knives. The death raised to 779 the number of Arabs killed by Israelis in the 3-year-old uprising. An additional 323 were slain by fellow Arabs, most as alleged collaborators with Israel, and 57 Israelis also have died.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Hails Christmas and Wealth of the Human Spirit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with details from Mass. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II proclaimed the ``good news'' of the birth of Christ and the wealth of the human spirit in a Chistmas Eve Mass broadcast in 50 countries, including the Soviet Union. The pope, in golden robes embroidered with black, celebrated the Midnight Mass in St. Peter's Basilica before more than 15,000 Romans, pilgrims, nuns and priests and a television audience in 50 nations, Vatican officials said. He quoted from the Apostle Paul, declaring that Christ ``has appeared for the salvation of all men.'' ``This salvation shapes human life in this world, and gives it a form which is divine ... It also gives human existence on Earth its definitive meaning, directing our life to future glory in Jesus Christ.'' This message, John Paul said, may be especially needed in today's world. ``Amid all the achievements of the progress of material civilization, is this not what they lack most?'' The Vatican said it expected the midnight Mass to be telecast to some 50 countries, and that about 60 countries were to carry the pope's Christmas Day Mass and his traditional message ``Urbi et Orbi'' - Latin for to the city and the world. The list of countries included the pope's native Poland, Romania and the Soviet Union, which have all established diplomatic ties to the Vatican in the past 18 months. Thousands of Albanians were also believed to have watched the religious services, since Italian television reaches the tiny Balkan Communist state. Albania has been officially atheist since 1967 but unprecedented protests recently prompted the relaxation of restrictions on religion and political pluralism. ``I bring you good news of a great joy ... for to you is born this day ... a Savior, who is Christ the Lord,'' John Paul declared, quoting from the Gospel according to St. Luke. Among the petitions read at the Mass was one in Arabic asking that God ``illuminate the minds of the leaders of nations so that they may be builders of peace.''

DOC.HEAD: Continued Cold Bursting Water Pipes, Death Toll Rises
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 2 grafs after the 5th, ``Temperatures stayed ...'' to UPDATE with more detail on cold, records; Picks up 6th graf pvs, `The end ...'; Deletes unnecessary 15th graf, ``The record.''
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Cold-Crops
LaserPhotos CX6; LA3
DOC.TEXT: The week-old arctic deep freeze ran utilities and plumbers ragged Monday with complaints of burst water pipes, and California navel orange growers said their crop had been devastated by the cold. The cold wave's advance brought an abrupt end to record balmy weather along the East Coast, with some cities reporting record highs during the morning followed by plummeting temperatures. The number of deaths blamed on the weather since the record cold snap began rose to at least 79 by Monday. Most were traffic deaths blamed on slippery roads. Others were killed by hypothermia, tornadoes and fires started by overworked heaters. In Alabama, where heavy rain fell in advance of the cold air, rescuers in boats ferried shivering residents from flooded houses Monday as river and creeks continued rising after more than 1 foot of rain from Friday night into Sunday. Hundreds of people had been evacuated there and in parts of Tennessee. Temperatures stayed low Monday, including a record 16 below zero at Burns, Ore.; 34 below at Roosevelt, Utah; 27 below at Richfield, Utah; a record 33 below at Alamosa, Colo.; and 32 below at Big Piney, Wyo. Casper, Wyo., warmed to 14 by midday, but the wind chill was minus 21. The wind chill early Monday in northern Indiana was 40 below. Readings of 20 below zero or colder were reported in Idaho, Montana, Wyoming, Colorado, New Mexico, Utah and Nevada. Sixteen cities in Colorado, New Mexico, California, Idaho, Oregon and Nevada reported record lows Monday. The low of 19 at Bakersfield, Calif., equalled the city's all-time record - which was set Sunday. The low of 23 at Sacramento, Calif., broke a record that had been on the books since 1879. The end of 85 hours of subzero temperatures Sunday in Denver allowed a slight thaw that unleashed a flood of broken-pipe calls as the ice that plugged and broke the pipes melted and let the water flow. Boulder County firefighters found they were ``running about five to six times our normal call loads, and most of them are broken pipes,'' Fire Chief Chuck Boyes said. The San Francisco Fire Department stopped responding to reports of frozen pipes after receiving 500 calls Sunday. Scores of Utah residents were without running water and numerous fire alarms were activated when water lines to indoor sprinkler systems snapped. ``I'm insane. We've had non-stop calls all morning,'' said Eric Yost, a Salt Lake City Public Utilities dispatcher. ``Basically, people don't believe that if you leave a little water running in a tap, the line won't freeze.'' He said one caller said he left his water running all night, but turned off the tap at 7 a.m. Within an hour, the water line froze. ``There's busted pipes, frozen pipes, frozen sewer lines ... any type of pipes you want to think of,'' said Juli Bingham, a Rescue Rooter dispatcher in Salt Lake City. In Oregon, firefighters evacuated 59 residents of a Willamette Valley retirement home Sunday when a cracked fire sprinkler flooded the building. A ruptured gas main shut off service to 12,000 customers from Sunday through Monday at Tupelo, Miss., while freezing rain and snow flew in the area. The arrival of the cold air in the East had temperatures flip-flopping. Atlanta had a record high Sunday of 73, but at 4 a.m. Monday the temperature was 33 and by 9 a.m. it was 26. New York City had a record high Monday of 63 - but that was at 6:10 a.m. and five hours later thermometers read 43 with the mercury continuing downward. California's navel orange crop was in trouble after temperatures in the San Joaquin Valley citrus region dipped below 20 degrees from Friday night through Sunday night. Navel oranges begin to show damage if the temperature falls to 25 or 26 degrees and stays at that level or below for at least four hours, reported Cliff Holland of California Citrus Mutual, a grower organization. ``Yesterday, we cut these oranges in half. ... It was just like cutting through a Popsicle,'' Bakersfield-area grower John Slikker Jr. said Monday. ``Basically, I have written off the crop that is on the tree,'' said Chris Caviglia, a Tulare County grower. ``What I'm concerned about now is the crop for next year. I could very well lose it as well if the trees aren't protected.'' ``Last night was the killer night,'' said Richard Berberian, a grower in the Fowler-Sanger area. ``The navel is gone. The Valencias are gone, the Minneolas are gone, the lemons are gone.''

DOC.HEAD: Man Freezes to Death During Walk to Get a Meal
DOC.TEXT: A 70-year-old man evidently froze to death during a one-mile walk to his rural mailbox where a charity delivered meals, authorities said. The body of Julius Skrede was discovered Monday at the farm where he lived alone. Crawford County Coroner Jan Lund said Skrede apparently collapsed Thursday. He had walked a half mile to the mailbox and was almost back to his house when he fell and was unable to get up, she said. Ms. Lund said Skrede, who had arthritis, had asked that the Meals on Wheels program place food in the mailbox. A volunteer who delivered Friday's meal discovered Monday it was still in the box and investigated.

DOC.HEAD: Prime Minister Karami Forms New Cabinet
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 10 grafs to ADD names of 2 other warlords, CLARIFY which appointees are warlords, picks up 11th pvs, `The group ...' ^By RODEINA KENAAN
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Omar Karami formed a 30-man Cabinet of pro-Syrian politicians and warlords Monday to try to end Lebanon's civil war. But its mission was imperiled by a right-wing Christian boycott. An official statement said President Elias Hrawi decreed the formation of the half-Christian, half-Moslem government during a five-hour meeting with Karami and Parliament Speaker Hussein Husseini. The new Cabinet includes seven militia chieftains as state ministers without portfolio - an apparent effort to get their approval for a plan to disarm and disband all private armies in Lebanon. Among them were Druse warlord Walid Jumblatt, whose Progressive Socialist Party fielded the strongest Moslem militia in the nearly 16-year-old civil war, and his Maronite Catholic foe, Samir Geagea. Jumblatt accepted his post, apparently under Syrian pressure, despite earlier public criticism of Hrawi for alleged corruption and favoritism. But Geagea's Lebanese Forces, the Christians' main militia, said in a statement that Geagea would not take up his Cabinet post because the new government is heavily tilted toward Syrian-backed leftists. George Saadeh, also a Maronite who heads the Phalange Party - the nation's largest right-wing political force - rejected his post as minister of telecommunications on the same grounds, a Phalangist statement said. The post of foreign minister in the new Cabient went to Hrwai's son-in-law, Fares Bweiz. With Jumblatt and Geagea, the other warlords in the Cabinet were Nabih Berri, head of the mainstream Shiite Moslem Amal militia; Elie Hobeika, a Maronite who heads a breakaway faction of Geagea's militia; Assaad Hardan of the Syrian Social Nationalist Party; Suleiman Franjieh of the pro-Syrian Marada militia in north Lebanon; and Abdulla al-Amin, leader of the small al-Assad battalion, named after Syrian President Hafez Assad.
