It was the first time that Hardan's Nationalist Party - a leftist Lebanese faction allied with Syria - has been brought into a Lebanese government since Lebanon gained independence from France in 1943. The group advocates the merger of Lebanon, Syria, Jordan, pre-Israel Palestine, Iraq, Kuwait and Cyprus into a greater Syria. The rightist Christian boycott cast doubt on the new government's ability to disband all militias. Geagea's 6,000-strong, heavily armed militia pulled out of Beirut's Christian districts last month to allow Hrawi's government to unite the capital and its environs in a militia-free ``greater Beirut.'' But Geagea's men are entrenched in the Kesrouan and Byblos provinces - about 75 percent of Lebanon's Christian hinterland north of Beirut. Hezbollah, or Party of God, Iran's main Shiite fundamentalist ally in Lebanon, was excluded from the new Cabinet. Hezbollah, which controls one of Lebanon's three strongest militias, had rejected the new government in advance, saying ``it is certain to lack the vision and minimum degree of harmony required to resolve the nation's woes.'' Karami's government succeeds that of outgoing Prime Minister Salim Hoss, who resigned with his 14-man Cabinet on Wednesday to make way for a broad-based government of national reconciliation. Karami said his Cabinet would strive to bring about a lasting peace, disarm all militias and launch a reconstruction campaign to shore up the country's shattered economy. ``We believe that all concerned will eventually join the government in order to achieve these national objectives,'' said Karami, a Sunni Moslem.

DOC.HEAD: Sri Lanka Landmine Blasts Ambulance Convoy, Kills 21
DOC.TEXT: A landmine exploded under an army ambulance convoy Monday, killing 18 soldiers and three civilians in northern Sri Lanka, where the army is fighting Tamil secessionists, the military and police said. Officials said the mine detonated in a marshy jungle near Horowapatana village, where sick and wounded soldiers were being taken for treatment. Village police said the blast blew up an army bus carrying 10 soldiers, two Sinhalese women and a male civilian, killing all of them. Eight soldiers in a jeep behind the bus were killed and six others badly hurt, police said. A police officer, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the civilians had hitched a ride in the army vehicle. Horowopatana lies 130 miles northeast of Colombo in the Polonnaruwa district, a predominantly Sinhalese region. It borders the multi-ethnic Trincomalee district, where the Tamil separatist war has been especially intense. Forty-two soldiers have been killed since Wednesday, when the army renewed offensive operations against the Tamil Tigers, who are fighting for independence for the Tamil minority in the northern and eastern parts of the island state. The military says 131 rebels have been killed and 22 captured in the offensive. More than 14,000 people have died in the Tamil war since 183. Tamils, who make up 18 per cent of Sri Lanka's 16 million population, say they are discriminated against by the Sinhalese, who comprise 75 per cent.

DOC.HEAD: Families Send Christmas Messages to Gulf Via Satellite
DOC.TEXT: A satellite link with Saudi Arabia gave U.S. servicemen and women a chance to see and speak with relatives back home on Monday. Several excited family members gathered at Boston's Lafayette Hotel for the electronic rendezvous. The soldiers spoke from a hotel in Dhahran, Saudi Arabia. Lori Curtin of Woburn was emotional as she reminded her husband, Paul Curtin, that he asked her to marry him four years ago on Christmas Eve. ``I feel so lucky to be able to talk to him today,'' Mrs. Curtin said. The conversations were brief, lasting only a couple of minutes each. One soldier, William Waters, donned a red Santa Claus hat while talking to his family. ``He looks so great, so healthy,'' said his wife, Cathy Waters, of Bedford. ``This was a really good Christmas pick-me-up. It's a sad day, but this helps.'' The project, sponsored by the City of Boston, the Lafayette Hotel, the Boston Herald, WHDH radio and television, and the Downtown Crossing Association, included a radio link with the USS John F. Kennedy, an aircraft carrier stationed in the Gulf.

DOC.HEAD: Bangladesh President Says News Violence Threatens Elections
DOC.TEXT: Skirmishes between secular and Islamic fundamentalist student groups have left two people dead since the weekend, police said Monday. Acting President Shahabuddin Ahmed said the violence in this southeastern port city was jeopardizing parliamentary elections planned for Feb. 27. It was the first fighting among the rival student groups since they united to lead the campaign that ousted President Hussain Muhammad Ershad on Dec. 6. Ershad and several of his former ministers are under house arrest as Bangladesh prepares for the elections. The clashes on Saturday and Sunday were between the fundamentalist Islamic Students Organization and the All-Party Student Unity, a coalition of secular students with various political views. One of the 37 badly injured students, Farukur Zaman of the secular group, died Monday. Later Monday, All Party organized a protest march to mourn the death. Police said protesters grabbed a 40-year-old man and stabbed him to death. The Islamic Students Organization identified the victim as a member of its group, Syed Ahmed. The protesters also rampaged through central Chittagong, damaging stores believed owned by fundamentalists, said police officials, speaking on condition of anonymity. They said the univeristy was closed indefinitely. The original clash Saturday began when fundamentalists attacked students who ignored their call to boycott classes to press for removal of a university official appointed by Ershad. United News of Bangladesh said Ahmed warned that the violence was ``creating obstacles'' in holding the elections. It quoted him as telling a delegation of fundamentalist students he received in the capital Dhaka, ``You must exercise tolerance and avoid violence if you want a peaceful election.'' Ershad handed over power to Ahmed's caretaker government this month following seven weeks of street protests against his rule. Ershad, a former army general who seized power in 1982, is likely to stand trial on corruption charges. Sultan Hossain Khan, the chief election commissioner appointed by Ershad, resigned Monday under opposition pressure. The caretaker government appointed Supreme Court judge Mohammad Abdur Rouf to replace him, state TV reported.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Counters Saddam Threat; Iraq Recalls Ambassadors
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, So far ... to UPDATE to 81 dead, with death Monday of soldier injured last week. Picks up 6th graf, The readiness ...; INSERT one graf after 13th graf, Saudi Arabia's . .. to EXPAND Fahd quote. Picks up 14th graf, Egyptian President . ..
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto DHR3
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein reportedly threatened to make Tel Aviv his first target if war breaks out in the Persian Gulf, and Israel on Monday promised swift and terrible retribution for any Iraqi attack. Three weeks before the United Nations deadline for Iraq to withdraw its armies from Kuwait or face a possible military strike, the Baghdad government recalled its ambassadors to the United States and some European nations for urgent consultations, diplomats said. No details about the talks were disclosed. In the sands of Saudi Arabia and the waters of the Persian Gulf, hundreds of thousands of U.S. troops marked Christmas Eve with muted celebrations and a heightened state of alert. Underscoring the somber holiday mood among U.S. forces, the bodies of 20 of the 21 U.S. servicemen who died in the weekend sinking of an Israeli ferry were flown back to the United States on Tuesday. The ferry capsized as it was transporting crewmen to the aircraft carrier USS Saratoga after shore leave. So far, 81 U.S. servicemen have died in Operation Desert Shield, launched after Iraq's takeover of Kuwait nearly five months ago. The readiness of U.S. forces to fight was the topic as Defense Secretary Dick Cheney met Monday with President Bush. Cheney, returning a day earlier from a five-day trip to the Middle East, said American troops would be ``prepared today, if we were ordered today, to take military action.'' Saddam's newest threat against Israel came in a Spanish television interview to be broadcast Wednesday. The journalist who spoke with the Iraqi leader in Baghdad on Saturday said Saddam told him ``Tel Aviv would receive the first blow in the case of a gulf war,'' whether or not Israel joined any multinational strike against Iraq. Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir responded to the reported threat by telling Israel radio that Iraq ``will be harmed in a most serious way'' if it attacks Israel. The new threat against Israel appeared to be a fresh bid by Saddam to divide the anti-Iraq coalition, which includes some Arab nations traditionally hostile to the Jewish state. A senior official of the Palestine Liberation Organization, Israel's most implacable enemy, indicated in an interview published Tuesday the PLO would side with Saddam if war broke out. ``We have coordinated our plans to fight with Iraq in one trench,'' PLO Chairman Yasser Arafat's chief political adviser, Hani Al-Hassan, told the Iraqi daily newspaper Al-Jumhuriya. Other Arab leaders, however, appealed to Saddam to give up Kuwait before it is too late. Saudi Arabia's King Fahd, at a meeting of the Gulf Cooperation Council in Qatar, said ``it is braver to opt for peace than for war.'' Fahd said Saddam would find his gulf neighbors ready for reconciliation if he left Kuwait, urging that Saddam ``know that the curtain is not yet drawn on the scorching war and that he ... can spare himself and his people its horror.'' Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak told reporters in Cairo that Iraq would be the big loser if war breaks out. ``A very large number of Iraqi people will die,'' he said. ``The decision of one man will lead to the death of hundreds of thousands.'' The Baghdad government, meanwhile, has been holding urgent consultations on the gulf crisis with Iraq's ambassadors to 10 Western countries, Iraqi officials said. The Iraqi Embassy in Washington said the Iraqi envoy to the United States, Mohamed Al-Mashat, and Baghdad's envoy to the United Nations, Abdul Al-Anbari, were among those summoned. Iraqi envoys to a number of European nations were also recalled for talks, officials said. It was unclear how many were involved. In Saudi Arabia, a Moslem country that forbids the practice of other religions, U.S. troops planned a subdued Christmas. Soldiers were to receive a special holiday meal of turkey, roast beef, cranberry sauce and other traditional dishes. President Bush taped a Christmas message to American soldiers worldwide, which was being broadcast Monday. ``The sacrifices you make will never be forgotten. America is behind you. The world is behind you and history is behind you,'' he said. In other developments: -Conservative Soviet lawmakers submitted a resolution to the parliament on Monday demanding a vote before any Soviet troops are sent to the region. The resolution seeks a special legislative session held on the topic Jan. 14, the day before the U.N. deadline for an Iraqi withdrawal. -French Defense Minister Jean-Pierre Chevenement called off a meeting with his Saudi counterpart after the Saudis refused to allow a French rock 'n' roll star to perform for troops camped in the desert, a French Embassy spokesman said. Eddy ``Schmoll' Mitchell's 1950s-style music apparently offends the country's strict Moslem tenets.

DOC.HEAD: Polish Primate Appeals for Reconciliation After Elections
DOC.TEXT: Cardinal Jozef Glemp asked Poles in his Christmas message Monday to put aside any anger left over from the country's first popular presidential election campaign. The message from the leader of Poland's Roman Catholic Church, broadcast on national TV Christmas Eve, came two days after Lech Walesa became president. Walesa won a bruising three-month battle for the nation's highest office, but Solidarity now is split into rival camps, one loyal to Walesa and the other to Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki. Glemp cautioned that ``politics is not man's only life's breath. Political moods change very quickly ... but the heart that is hurt by hostility and prejudice remains scarred for a very long time.''

DOC.HEAD: Temperature Records Smashed East and West
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 4-7, bgng, `Other record ...,' to CORRECT spelling of Gallup, UPDATE low there to 32 below, UPDATE lowest temperature in Lower 48 to 38 below in Dulce, N.M.; Picks up 8th graf, `Bitter cold ...'
DOC.TEXT: It was another bone chilling morning across much of the West on Monday. Subzero readings were reported across most of the northern Plateau, the Great Basin and the Rocky Mountain region. Readings of 20 degrees below zero or colder were reported in Idaho, Montana, Wyoming, Colorado, New Mexico, Utah and Nevada. Sixteen cities reported record low temperatures for the date this morning. The low of 19 degrees at Bakersfield, Calif., equalled their all-time record which was established Sunday morning. Other record lows for Christmas Eve included Albuquerque, N.M., with 2 below zero; Reno, Nev., at 11 below; Fresno, Calif., at 22 degrees; Gallup, N.M., with 32 below zero; and Big Piney, Wyo., with 32 degrees below zero. Midday temperatures were still below zero across parts of the northern Plateau, the Great Basin and the Rockies. Temperatures were above the freezing mark along the Pacific Coast and in the desert Southwest, while readings warmed into the 50s along the coast of southern California. Monday morning's low temperature for the Lower 48 states was 38 below zero in Dulce, N.M. Bitter cold continued in the center of the nation with morning lows generally in the single numbers or below zero from the High Plains to the lower Ohio Valley and the upper Great Lakes. Readings dipped below zero across most of the upper Mississippi Valley and upper Michigan. Subzero readings were also reported in the northern and central Plains, the mid-Mississippi Valley, and the lower Ohio Valley. Temperatures were still in the single numbers or below zero at midday in the upper Mississippi Valley, as brisk westerly winds warmed readings into the 20s across the northern Plains. Another frigid Arctic air mass hovered over southern Canada, poised and ready to spill into the north central part of the United States as low pressure and a trailing cold front move southeastward out of southern Saskatchewan. A winter storm watch has been posted for northwest lower Michigan and parts of upper Michigan near Lake Superior for possible heavy snow on Christmas Day. Clouds, blustery winds and scattered light snow showers fell throughout the north central United States while sunny skies prevailed across the south central states. Record high readings were set ahead of the the Artic front that moved relentlessly eastward. Some of the records established included New York City at 63, Allentown, Pa., at 62, Philadelphia at 64 and Miami hit 84. Strong northwesterly winds ushered in much colder air and by midday readings had already dropped into the 30s and 40s. Snow prevailed behind the cold front as it crossed coastal New England. Strong northwesterly winds behind the front produced snow squalls in the upper Great Lakes. Rain and gale force wind ahead of the cold front prevailed along the New England coast.

DOC.HEAD: Six People Die in Collision of Two Minivans on Interstate in Indiana
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `Three adults ...,' to ADD 3 grafs to UPDATE with new details of crash, injuries; No pick up ...
DOC.TEXT: A collision between two minivans on Christmas Eve left six people dead and at least five people injured, authorities said Monday. The accident occurred on Interstate 94 near Michigan City, about two miles southwest of the Michigan state line. One of the vans crossed the median strip into oncoming traffic, said state police Sgt. David Sylvester but further details were unvailable. The road was dry at the time. The identities of the victims were not immediately available, said David Heise, a LaPorte County Sheriff's deputy. The six who died were in the van that crossed into oncoming traffic, police said. One person in that vehicle suffered bone fractures and was listed in stable condition at Memorial Hospital. The two adults and two children in the other van, all members of the same family, were treated for cuts and bruises at Memorial Hospital and released, said nursing supervisor Lauretta Hapke. The interstate's westbound lane was closed to traffic for four hours after the mid-afternoon accident.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Briefed by Defense Secretary Cheney, Gen. Powell
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 4th graf: ``However, ABC-TV,'' report of Gen. Waller's view relayed to Bush
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon's top civilian and military officers brought President Bush up to date on the tense situation in the Persian Gulf Monday in a briefing at the president's mountaintop retreat at Camp David. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Gen. Colin L. Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, returned to Washington from a five-day visit to Saudi Arabia on Sunday and helicoptered Monday to the camp about 60 miles north of the capital in western Maryland. Neither the White House nor the Defense Department gave any details of their talks and Cheney made no comments to reporters when he returned to the Pentagon. However, ABC-TV said Monday night, and The New York Times said in Tuesday editions, that Bush was told senior officers shared the view of Lt. Gen. Calvin Waller, deputy U.S. commander in Saudi Arabia, that it would be late February before the troops would be ready to attack Iraqi forces. In Saudi Arabia, Cheney and Powell met with senior commanders and some of the nearly 300,000 American troops stationed in and around the desert kingdom. The United Nations has set a Jan. 15 deadline for Iraq to withdraw from neighboring Kuwait, which the Iraqis invaded on Aug. 2 and later annexed. Cheney said during his Mideast trip that the refusal of Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein to withdraw as the deadline draws closer increases the likelihood of war. ``Each day that goes by, each week without signs of an Iraqi withdrawal, moves us that much closer to the point at which we and other members of the coalition may have no other choice,'' Cheney said during a stopover Sunday in Cairo. In the final days of their visit, Cheney and Powell toughened their rhetoric against Saddam, apparently to counter statements made a U.S. military official early in the trip that American ground forces might not be ready for comment until after the mid-January deadline. ``If I were Saddam Hussein, I would take very seriously what the president said,'' Cheney said on the flight home. ``That is that we are deploying the military capability to implement the U.N. resolutions and to force him out of Kuwait should that be necessary.'' Cheney also said during the visit, in response to a sailor's question, that he was confident the allies ``that really count'' would not abandon the multinational military force if Iraq withdrew only partly from Kuwait. He specifically mentioned the Saudis, Egyptians and British. On the flight home, he said he was not trying to imply that Syria and France were hedging their commitment to support their allies. Both Cheney and Powell said there was no timetable for attack by U.S. forces, which include Marines stationed 50 miles from the Iraqi border. The defense secretary described the trip as ``enormously successful'' but gave no details of his meetings, some of which even most of his top aides were not allowed to attend. After his return from Camp David, Cheney left for Wyoming for a family vacation in his home state. He is expected back in Washington right after New Year's Day.

DOC.HEAD: Publishers
Editors
Managing Editors
DOC.TEXT: A summary of developments in the news industry for the week of Dec. 17-23:
DOC.HEAD: Inquirer Recants Controversial Editorial
DOC.TEXT:
The Philadelphia Inquirer apologized publicly for an editorial that had been attacked as racist because it linked a new contraceptive to efforts to reverse poverty. The apology was contained in an editorial in the newspaper's Dec. 23 edition. The newspaper took the unusual step in response to criticism of a Dec. 12 editorial that suggested the contraceptive Norplant, recently approved by the federal government, could help solve the problem of poverty among blacks. ``The earlier Norplant editorial undercut our credibility and our efforts to be a thoughtful, responsible and compassionate voice on the complex issues of poverty,'' the newspaper said. ``We apologize to those we hurt and offended.'' The apology said the newspaper's own reporters, editors and editorial board members were among those incensed by the original editorial. It was printed alongside five letters to the editor, containing both praise and criticism. The original editorial discussed two stories in the previous day's newspaper. One was about Norplant, which prevents pregnancy through implants of tiny rods under the skin and stays effective for years, and the other was about a research finding that nearly half of black children live in poverty and the situation is growing worse. --- Here is the text of the editorial, headlined ``An apology'' and subtitled ``The editorial on `Norplant and poverty' was misguided and wrong-headed.'':
It's rare that we regret publishing an editorial from almost the moment it appears in print. And it's rarer still that we feel the need to apologize to our readers for a misguided and wrong-headed editorial opinion. But such is the case with the editorial that appeared in this space on Dec. 12 entitled ``Norplant and poverty.'' Great pain, anger and controversy have resulted from that editorial, and we deeply regret our decision to print it. Among the people who were incensed by the editorial were many of the Inquirer's own reporters, editors and members of the Editorial Board. In the days since it appeared, we have been doing a lot of listening and soul-searching. We realize now that we hastily and foolishly juxtaposed two news items that appeared in the Inquirer the previous day - federal approval of the long-term contraceptive Norplant and the release of a research group's report that said nearly half of black children are living in poverty and that the situation is getting worse with time. The editorial posed the question of whether encouraging women who are on welfare to use Norplant could help reverse this bleak trend. Where did we go wrong? Let's begin with the headline, which asked whether contraception could ``reduce the underclass'' and thus aroused people's fears of something far worse than promoting birth control. Later, we used the word ``eugenics'' as a way of explaining what we didn't mean, but it only inflamed matters more. Most fundamentally, in linking the issues of race and contraception, we left too many people with the impression that our cure for poverty was to reduce the number of black people. Although that certainly was not what we meant to suggest, the fact that so many people interpreted it that way is a clear indication that the editorial was fatally flawed. Therefore we failed in our effort to provoke thoughtful discussion on the issue of birth control and poverty. It's true that many single young women lessen their chances of escaping poverty by having children too early in life. But it'salso true that the very hopelessness of their circumstances often underlies the decision not to postpone child-bearing. Creating hope where none now exists must be the main tenet of any effective war on poverty. In the previous editorial we said that women on welfare should be encouraged, but not compelled, to use Norplant. We suggested incentives, such as an additional benefit of some kind. Our critics countered that to dangle cash or some other benefit in front of a desperately poor woman is tantamount to coercion. They're right. We still believe that this new form of reliable birth control, which is likely to have wide appeal to middle-class women, should be equally available to poor women who want to use it. But we also realize - and should have been even clearer about it - that this has to be a matter of personal choice. We don't seek to limit the options of poor women, but to empower them. We remain committed to a whole host of strategies for reducing poverty - from better schools to job training to radical welfare reform. We think education about birth control is important, and if Norplant lives up to its advance billing, it could be helpful to many women. And we wish we had said it that way to begin with. The earlier Norplant editorial undercut our credibility and our efforts to be a thoughtful, responsible and compassionate voice on the complex issues of poverty. We apologize to those we hurt and offended.
DOC.HEAD: Boston Globe To Trim Work Force Through Attrition
DOC.TEXT: Citing declines in advertising, The Boston Globe announced it will reduce its work force by 100 full-time positions through attrition over the next five years. The 100 positions represent about 5 percent of the full-time staff at the Globe, which employs 2,075 full-time and 500 part-time workers. ``We are experiencing the same economic forces affecting other companies,'' said William O. Taylor, publisher of the Globe and chairman of the newspaper's parent company, Affiliated Publications Inc. ``Advertising is down significantly this year, and the outlook is cautious at best,'' he said. ``We think this is the least painful way to address the need to be as cost-effective as we can for the future.'' The attrition program is another step in an overall cost-cutting effort at the Globe, which began with budget cuts in the spring of 1988. It has also included reductions in department expenditures and in hours of some part-time staff. Taylor earlier said he expected earnings to be down significantly at Affiliated Publications, and that the company planned to raise the price of the Globe from 35 cents to 50 cents in April in areas 30 miles outside the city.

DOC.HEAD: FNN Owner Says It Can't Repay $20.7 Million Loan
DOC.TEXT: Infotechnology Inc., the cash-strapped owner of Financial News Network and United Press International, said Dec. 22 that it could not repay a $20.7 million loan that was called in early. The lenders, Security Pacific National Bank and MidLantic National Bank, now have the right to foreclose on Infotechnology's 46 percent stock interest in FNN, a cable television network. The FNN stock was placed as collateral for the loan, which originally was due next July. The banks did not say why they called in the loan early and would not say whether they would exercise their foreclosure option. An Infotechnology spokeswoman said the company did not believe the banks would foreclose on the loan and it would continue seeking buyers for its media subsidiaries to raise cash. The development was the latest blow to Infotechnology, whose FNN subsidiary reported on Dec. 18 that it lost $72.5 million in its 1990 fiscal year. UPI, a news wire service, reportedly has been losing as much as $2.5 million a month. Last month, UPI union and management employees agreed to a 35 percent pay cut for 90 days to give the news service time to find a buyer. UPI has changed ownership three times in eight years. FNN provides stock quotes, business and financial news, and sports information on a cable TV network to more than 35 million homes served by 3,500 in the United States and Canada. FNN said its loss stemmed primarily from accounting changes totaling $65 million. FNN said said the changes regarded improperly documented lease transactions, new product development costs and payments to UPI. FNN said it was in the process of revising its quarterly reports for the first three quarters of 1990 to reflect a review conducted by FNN and its new accountants, Coopers & Lybrand. In October, FNN dismissed C. Steven Bolen, chief financial officer, for improper financial dealings. The FNN financial report said an investigation concluded Bolen had payments made to himself totaling $794,061 that were ``not properly authorized and not properly identified on (FNN's) books.'' ``Through his counsel, Mr. Bolen claimed that such payments were earned by him as incentive compensation for arranging financing for the company,'' the filing stated. FNN said it was considering suing Bolen to recover the money.
DOC.HEAD: St. Petersburg Times Discloses Some Terms of Bass Settlement
DOC.TEXT: After settling a shareholder suit with Texas billionaire Robert M. Bass and others, the Times Publishing Co. has emerged with $8.1 million cash and a healthy balance sheet, newly disclosed documents show. The settlement reached in August specified that neither side would reveal any details, but Times Publishing released some information Dec. 18 to satisfy requests from the state of Florida. The disclosure gave several details about the privately held company that publishes the St. Petersburg Times. But the amount the company paid Bass to drop his suit was not reported. Under the terms of the settlement, Times Publishing agreed to buy back a 40-percent stake owned by the Bass group. The group had purchased the stake in August 1988 for about $28 million and had offered to buy the rest of the company for $270 million earlier this year. The documents released Dec. 18 show total bank debt for the newspaper company as of Nov. 30 was $9 million. ``The company is strong and vital and we can go on to other things,'' chief executive and editor Andrew Barnes said. According to treasurer Catherine Heron, the company's cash position ``would cover the majority of existing bank debt.'' The $9 million debt will be paid off by 1995, she said. The documents were released to the Florida attorney general's office, which was concerned that the shareholder settlement could adversely affect the Poynter Institute for Media Studies in St. Petersburg. The institute is the chief shareholder of Times publishing. After acquiring its stake, the Bass partnership had sued Times Publishing over dividend payments, the bulk of which support the institute's educational programs. Under the settlement, Times Publishing agreed to buy back the Bass stake and redeem an issue of non-voting stock, which paid healthy dividends to the institute. At the time of the settlement, the company claimed the agreement would not hurt the institute. It said the preferred shares held by the institute would be replaced by debt, which would pay more in annual interest than the preferred stock once paid in dividends. The company said the institute also could expect to receive dividends from the common stock it holds. The latest disclosures show the institute eventually will own all of the Times Publishing common stock. Robert Lanzillotti, dean emeritus of the University of Florida's graduate business school, was hired by the institute to independently review the Bass settlement. He said it ``will make possible substantially greater financial support for the institute's operations and growth over the long run.'' In addition to the St. Petersburg newspaper, one of the largest and most prominent in the South, Times Publishing runs Congressional Quarterly, Florida Trend and Georgia Trend magazines.
DOC.HEAD: Daily News Sues Unions Over Interference With Dealers, Advertisers
DOC.TEXT: The Daily News accused its striking unions of violating federal labor law by using a ``campaign of violence'' against the newspaper's dealers and advertisers. The allegations were contained in a lawsuit filed Dec. 17, the second filed by the News against the unions in U.S. District Court in Manhattan since the strike began Oct. 25. The first lawsuit was brought under the civil racketeering statute and accused the nine striking unions of coordinating a violent conspiracy to force a favorable labor settlement or the sale of the newspaper. The new complaint claims the unions violated the Labor-Management Relations Act, which prohibits unions from interfering with the business of parties not involved in a labor dispute. ``The defendants and agents acting on their behalf have mounted a campaign of violence and intimidation against the News' dealers and advertisers in an effort to disrupt the publication and sale of the newspaper,'' the lawsuit said. The lawsuit asks for more than $50 million in losses that the News claims it incurred as a result of the campaign, which it said included ``many hundreds'' of incidents of arson, assault, vandalism, threats and harassment. Theodore Kheel, a labor attorney and adviser to the unions, denied the allegations. He cited recent testimony by senior police officials who said investigations found the violence was committed by individuals and was not part of a coordinated conspiracy. Kheel said the News' lawsuits against the unions constituted ``harassment.'' The News has published every day during the strike, but the majority of the city's 12,000 newsstands and vendors have stopped selling the paper and major advertisers have pulled their accounts. Before the strike, it was the nation's third-largest metropolitan daily, with circulation of 1.09 million. Circulation has dropped to about 600,000.

DOC.HEAD: Detroit Papers Raise Home Delivery Rates
DOC.TEXT: The Detroit News and the Detroit Free Press announced a home delivery increase of 25 cents a week to cover the cost of rising newsprint, labor and fuel. Seven-day home delivery of the News will increase to $2.25 and the Free Press to $2.50 in the metropolitan area, and home delivery of both papers will cost $3.35 a week elsewhere in the state, the Detroit Newspaper Agency said. Newsstand and coin box prices in the Detroit area will remain the same at 25 cents, but daily editions of both papers will rise to 35 cents from 25 cents elsewhere in the state. The combined Sunday edition will cost $1.25 statewide, up from $1. Joseph Ungaro, president and chief executive officer of the newspaper agency, which administers combined operations of the two papers, said the cost of newsprint will rise 11 percent over the next six months, and fuel costs have gone up for the company's delivery trucks, which drive more than 124,000 miles a week.
DOC.HEAD: New York Times Boosts Price of National Edition
DOC.TEXT: The price of The New York Times' national edition will go up to 75 cents in the Midwest and Southwest on Jan. 14. The Times had been charging 50 cents for daily copies of its national edition in the Midwest and 60 cents in the Southwest, spokeswoman Nancy Nielsen said Thursday. The higher price reflects the newspaper's higher production and distribution costs, she said. The price for the national edition in the Southeast was raised to 75 cents last September. It still costs 50 cents on the West Coast. The daily paper costs 50 cents in the Northeast, except in the tri-state area near New York where it is 40 cents.
DOC.HEAD: The National To Boost Cover Price to 75 Cents
DOC.TEXT: Despite falling short of circulation goals, The National is planning to boost its cover price by a quarter to 75 cents on Jan. 21. In addition, the sports newspaper said Dec. 21 that it would test a $1 daily price for one or two of its 10 metropolitan editions. Specific editions have not yet been selected for the test, spokesman Stephen Hammond said. The move comes as the 11-month-old newspaper is trying to prove there are enough readers to sustain the first all-sports daily in the United States. It also comes when the weakest advertising market in 15 years is driving newspapers to find alternate methods of generating more revenue. Two weeks ago, The National told advertisers it was reducing its circulation guarantee by 27 percent to 200,000 copies. The admission that it was not making its guaranteed average of 275,000 followed a review that resulted in elimination of its Sunday edition, the dismissal of the circulation manager and two other top executives and layoffs of 18 other employees. The paper is now publishing five times a week, Monday through Friday. The National has editions in New York, Chicago, Los Angeles San Diego, San Francisco, Dallas, Detroit, Boston, Miami-Fort Lauderdale and Baltimore-Washington, D.C. It is scheduled to expand next year with editions in Philadelphia, Atlanta, Denver and Seattle, insiders said.
DOC.HEAD: S.F. Mayor Will Sign Landmark VDT Law, Aides Say
DOC.TEXT: Businesses will have up to four years instead of two to provide safer equipment and working conditions for video display terminal users under a compromise Mayor Art Agnos has agreed to sign, his aides say. What was hailed as the nation's toughest VDT law won final approval from the city Board of Supervisors on Dec. 17, but Agnos wouldn't commit to signing it until he talked to business and labor groups about its impact and cost. After a weekend meeting with Agnos, the two sides agreed Dec. 22 to several amendments, one of which would extend the compliance period from two years to as many as four years, the mayor's aides said. The compromise, which Agnos plans to sign Dec. 27, must go back to the supervisors for approval. ``This is an example of what happens when both sides come to the table. And we now have something that both sides can live with,'' said Claude Everhart, deputy mayor for government operations, who mediated the negotiations. The compromise measure still calls for frequent work breaks, proper lighting, anti-glare screens, adjustable computer furniture and equipment to make VDT use safer. Among the problems associated with regular work at a computer keyboard are nerve damage to the wrists and fingers, back and neck strain, eye strain, sleep disturbances, chronic headaches, nausea and fatigue. Labor leaders hope the VDT law will be a model for other cities and counties in California and for the state and other states nationwide. Business groups have consistently opposed efforts to pass such legislation because of its expense and because some doubt VDT use causes health problems. City budget analysts estimate businesses will spend as much as $76.5 million and the city as much as $6 million to comply with the law.
DOC.HEAD: Dallas Times Herald Seeks New Trial in Antitrust Suit
DOC.TEXT: The parent company of the Dallas Times Herald asked a state appeals court Dec. 19 to order a new trial of its antitrust lawsuit against The Dallas Morning News. The dispute grew out of a deal in which the Times Herald lost 26 features and comics, including Doonesbury and Dear Abby, to its larger rival. The Times Herald Printing Co. unsuccessfully sued the Morning News and its parent company, A.H. Belo Corp., for $33 million. The Times Herald claims in its appeal that state district Judge David West erred when he told the jury to ignore potentially anti-competitive behavior by the Morning News if it could be shown that the Morning News also was pursuing a legitimate business goal. The appeal also says West should have granted the Times Herald's motion for a new trial. Michael J. McCarthy, Belo senior vice president-secretary and general counsel, said he thought the judge acted correctly. In the lawsuit, the Times Herald accused the Morning News and Belo of violating state antitrust laws in a transaction reached with Universal Press Syndicate in August 1989. The lawsuit accused the Times Herald's larger rival of trying to force it out of business through the deal with Universal, which stripped the Times Herald of the features and comics. During the trial Belo and the Morning News said the main reason for their deal with Universal was to create a joint venture to develop television programming based on Universal comics and features. Belo attorneys argued it made no sense for the joint venture to promote features appearing in a competing paper. Belo and the Morning News have 25 days to respond to the appeal. Oral arguments could be held as early as June, with no final decision likely before next December.

DOC.HEAD: Financial Columnist on McDonald's Board
DOC.TEXT: A columnist and TV commentator who reports on financial news says there is no ethical conflict between her work and her appointment to the McDonald's Corp. board of directors. ``This won't be a problem,'' said Terry Savage, who writes a weekly financial news column for the Chicago Sun-Times and Dallas Times Herald, and who appears regularly on Chicago station WBBM. Savage, 46, the first woman named to the company's board in 20 years, will receive $24,000 a year from McDonald's plus $2,000 for each board meeting attended. Officials at the newspapers and TV station said Savage promised to stay away from any issues that could be construed as conflicting with her role on the McDonald's board. ``We will make sure she does not write about the food industry, and McDonald's in particular,'' said Jim Frisinger, Times Herald business editor. But George Harmon, who teaches business writing at Northwestern University's graduate school of journalism, said it would be hard to avoid the apperance of a conflict because McDonald's influences so much of the business world. He said Savage could be restricted from reporting on the beef, potato and recycling industries and even the stock market because McDonald's is among the 30 companies whose performances are reflected in the Dow Jones industrials average. ``If somebody wanted to restrict Terry from reporting on McDonald's and be very strict about that, it would restrain her considerably,'' he said.
DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Guild Pickets Journal-Bulletin
DOC.TEXT: More than 100 members of the Providence Newspaper Guild picketed The Providence Journal-Bulletin on Dec. 19 to protest stalled wage talks. ``We're dealing with one of the wealthiest corporations in Rhode Island,'' said Tim Schick, the Guild's local administrator. ``They have only seen fit to put 2 percent on the table for '91.'' R. Barrie Schmitt, the newspaper's personnel and labor relations director, declined to comment, saying the negotiations are under the jurisdiction of a federal mediator. The local Guild represents 510 reporters, editors, advertising salespeople and support staff. Schick said the union contract calls for negotiations to be reopened on wages for 1991, the final year of the agreement. But the company has concentrated instead on trying to negotiate a completely new three-year contract, he said. The company offered wage increases of 4 percent in the first year of a new agreement, and 3 percent and 2 percent in the subsequent years, the union said. If the union is unwilling to go with a new contract, increases would only be 2 percent each year, Schick said. The union is seeking wage increases of $48 a week across the board, which would be an average increase of 7.5 percent. Reporters earning top-level wages are paid $756 a week and editors at the same seniority earn $830.
DOC.HEAD: Cox Sells Two Texas Papers
DOC.TEXT: American Publishing Co. has bought the Port Arthur News and The Orange Leader from Cox Newspapers, the companies said Dec. 17. Wes Plummer Jr., editor and publisher of the Crookston (Minn.) Daily Times, was named publisher in Port Arthur. Belinda Gaudet will remain publisher in Orange.
DOC.HEAD: Federal Courts Set TV Experiment for Eight Courts
DOC.TEXT: Americans' first televised look at federal judges at work likely will occur next year in appeals courts in New York or San Francisco or a trial court in one of six states. ``The courts have been selected. Now, it's a matter of the news media requesting coverage in particular cases,'' David Sellers, a spokesman for the policymaking U.S. Judicial Conference said Dec. 21. The conference, composed of 27 federal judges and headed by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, approved the three-year experiment in September. Individual courts then were invited to volunteer. Those selected are federal appellate courts based in San Francisco and New York City and U.S. district courts in Indiana, Massachusetts, Michigan, New York, Pennsylvania and Washington. Beginning in July, broadcast and photographic access will be allowed in civil cases in the selected courts. Judges will have broad discretion to reject requests for coverage. Cameras and radio equipment have been banned from federal courts since 1937, but 45 states allow some form of broadcast or photographic coverage of proceedings in their courts. The federal experiment, to run through June 1994, will be monitored by the Federal Judicial Center, a study group for the federal courts.
DOC.HEAD: Bolles Murder Case Revived
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors have decided to retry the two men whose murder convictions in the 1976 car bomb slaying of newspaper reporter Don Bolles were overturned a decade ago. Contractor Max Dunlap was charged Dec. 19 with the murder of the Arizona Republic investigative reporter. Former plumber James Robison was charged again in 1989. John Harvey Adamson, who was the prosecution's chief witness at the 1977 trial, and then refused to testify after the convictions were overturned, has been offered a deal and will take the stand once more, Attorney General Bob Corbin said. Corbin said this time he has a stronger case, but he wouldn't say what evidence he has or why Adamson, whom he once derided as no longer a credible witness, was working with authorities again. But a criminal complaint filed Dec. 19 also accuses Dunlap and Robison this time of conspiring with others to obstruct justice and influence witnesses in the original case. According to the complaint, Dunlap and Robison were overheard talking about payments made to Robison and Adamson to keep them quiet over the last 14 years. Bolles died in 1976, 11 days after a radio-controlled bomb ripped through his car as he backed out of a hotel parking lot. Adamson testified that he planted the bomb under Bolles' car and Robison triggered it on orders from Dunlap. He said Dunlap wanted to ingratiate himself with land and liquor magnate Kemper Marley, who had been the target of several critical stories by Bolles. Marley died earlier this year. Bolles had won acclaim for his exposes on land fraud, dog racing and organized crime. Robison and Dunlap were convicted of murder and sentenced to death, but the state Supreme Court reversed the convictions in 1980, saying the defense had been unfairly prevented from asking Adamson certain questions. Adamson, a greyhound breeder and tow-truck operator, was originally allowed to plead guilty to lesser charges and sentenced to 20 years in prison in exchange for his testimony. After the convictions were thrown out, he refused to testify again unless authorities paid for his children's education. Corbin said that destroyed Adamson's credibility, and he was then charged with murder. He was convicted and is serving life in prison. In exchange for his testimony this time, his sentence will be reduced to a maximum of 20 years.

DOC.HEAD: No More Jail for Reporter Who Refused To Testify
DOC.TEXT: A reporter threatened with jail for refusing to testify in a homicide case got off the hook Dec. 19 when prosecutors decided not to call her to the stand. A jury recommended the death sentence for Jermarr Arnold in the 1983 killing of a jewelry store employee. Prosecutors earlier wanted Corpus Christi Caller-Times reporter Libby Averyt to testify about unpublished details of her interview with Arnold, during which he showed no remorse for the killing. But in testimony during the penalty phase of the trial after he was found guilty, Arnold himself said that he had no remorse or apologies for the killing. ``You'd be making a very correct decision by sentencing me to death,'' he told the jury. Ms. Averyt was jailed Dec. 7 for refusing to answer questions about unpublished information from her interviews. She was released two days later but remained under subpoena until the trial ended.
DOC.HEAD: Philadelphia Inquirer Asks Judge To Throw Out Libel Verdict
DOC.TEXT: The Philadelphia Inquirer asked a judge Dec. 17 to dismiss a $6 million libel verdict a state Supreme Court justice won after the paper allegedly defamed him. ``The verdict was against the evidence (and) improper, contrary to law and fact,'' according to a motion for a new trial by Philadelphia Newspapers, Inc., which owns the Inquirer. Attorney William Hangley filed the motion, which went to Common Pleas Judge John Lavelle of Carbon County. There was no indication when Lavelle would rule or set a hearing. Inquirer reporter Daniel Biddle wrote a 1983 series of articles that questioned the ethical conduct of members of the state's highest court. Justice James T. McDermott filed two lawsuits against the newspaper, one for the original series, and one for the reprint which went to the 1984 conference of the American Judicature Society. The jury decided on Dec. 7 that Biddle's original series was not libelous but that portions of a February 1984 reprint were false. The reprint contained the same text as the original series but was accompanied by an introduction, two editorials and two cartoons that had not appeared with the original series. ``There was no evidence that anyone at the AJS meeting actually read the articles in reprint form at the seminar or anywhere else,'' Hangley said in the motion. Hangley argued a new trial was warranted because the award of compensatory and punitive damages ``is so excessive as to shock the conscience.'' ``The jury's verdicts were inconsistent and irreconcilable,'' the motion said. ``The court should correct and set aside such a verdict.'' The ruling was the second libel judgment against the paper in a year. In May an attorney won a record $34 million finding against the paper for a 1973 story criticizing his handling of a homicide case while he was assistant district attorney. The paper is appealing that ruling as well.
DOC.HEAD: Libel Suit Against Herb Caen Dismissed
DOC.TEXT: An appeals court has dismissed a libel case against San Francisco Chronicle columnist Herb Caen, saying his item about a deputy sheriff's arrest on violence and drug charges was not libelous because it was true. The state Court of Appeal on Dec. 18 dismissed the libel suit by former San Francisco sheriff's deputy Robert Heimbaugh. Caen wrote in January 1987 that Heimbaugh had been ``booked at city jail on charges of brandishing a gun, beating his live-in lady friend and possessing drug paraphernalia. The district attorney's office wants to prosecute but is in a quandary because the allegedly battered nonbride will not testify against him. Heimbaugh is out on bail and on medical leave.'' The appeals court said the deputy had indeed been arrested 10 days before the column appeared on charges of ``corporal punishment of a cohabitant, brandishing a weapon, and possession of narcotics paraphernalia.'' Therefore, the lawsuit was without merit, the court ruled. The charges against Heimbaugh were later dropped. Caen has written a daily short-item column featuring gossip, jokes and tales about San Francisco and its people for 52 years. In a footnote, the court characterized Caen as ``the journalistic equivalent of the Golden Gate Bridge.'' Heimbaugh did not dispute the facts in the item, but argued that the column was untrue because the charges were later dropped and his bail was canceled. The court ruled that those developments did not make the published item libelous. Heimbaugh resigned from the sheriff's department and works as a cab driver and bartender in San Francisco. He also has worked as a legal researcher. He said that although he had not yet seen the court's opinion he intended to appeal.
DOC.HEAD: Judge's Defamation Suit Dismissed
DOC.TEXT: A circuit judge dismissed a lawsuit filed by a Colombian judge who was relocated to the Detroit area because of death threats. Wayne County Circuit Judge Edward M. Thomas on Dec. 20 dismissed a suit by Judge Consuela Sanchez-Duran and her husband, Augusto Sanabria. The couple filed suit in 1989 against The Detroit News, Detroit Free Press and television stations WJBK and WXYZ after they reported she was living in the Detroit area. The judge called the reports ``unnecessary and dangerous, recklessly placing them and the general public in a position of harm.'' The media reported Sanchez-Duran's whereabouts as part of a story on her being relocated by U.S. officials after her life was threatened. The death threats came after Sanchez-Duran ordered the arrest of Pablo Escobar, alleged head of the Medellin cartel South American cocaine ring. Thomas said the reports were on a matter of public interest and caused no invasion of privacy, defamation or intentional or negligent infliction of emotional distress. Thomas noted the judge had used her own name while working in the Colombian consular office in the Detroit area, as well as in renting apartments, shopping and eating out. Sanchez-Duran's attorney, Cyril Weiner, said he would appeal.
DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Refuses To Publish Guilt Ads
DOC.TEXT: A judge who ordered a dozen people found guilty of drunken driving, shoplifting and other misdemeanors to advertise their crimes changed his mind when The Pensacola News Journal refused to go along. County Judge William White ordered the offenders to buy space to publish their pictures, charges and sentences. ``The newspaper as a matter of policy does not wish to become a vehicle for court-ordered public humiliation,'' Publisher Kenneth Andrews said Dec. 19. ``The advertising columns of the newspaper are open for free and voluntary expression within reasonable bounds of propriety, and if the ads ordered by Judge White are accepted, other courts may consider involuntary newspaper advertising as a potential method of punishing defendants.'' The court order called for an ad at least one column wide and 2 inches tall. White said he considered the measure harsh, but said it would help deter the holiday season rise in drunken driving, theft and the spread of AIDS.

DOC.HEAD: TV Station Surrenders Taped Interview to Police
DOC.TEXT: A television interview with a man whose wife has been missing since Dec. 8 was seized by police who got a search warrant to obtain the tape from KTWO-TV, managing editor Charles Brown said. The woman's husband had complained in the interview that police were spending too much time treating him like a suspect when they should be searching for his wife. On Dec. 18, police seized the taped interview, saying it ``constitutes evidence.'' Brown said the station decided not to challenge the warrant, in part because the husband had approached KTWO on his own. Additionally, station officials didn't think the interview contained any comments that the man hadn't already made to police, he said. ``Our position was we take this on a case-by-base basis,'' Brown said. ``I think it just ought to be on a case-by-case basis. I don't think you should turn stuff over voluntarily, but responding to a search warrant is different.'' According to an affidavit that accompanied the warrant, police wanted the tape because it contained statements made by the husband that they believe show he concealed a stolen gun and military equipment found when officers searched the couple's house after she disappeared. Michael Krampner, a lawyer working with the Wyoming Press Association, said KTWO already had broadcast a portion of the interview and so there was little argument for confidentiality of the tape. ``As the law now is in Wyoming, journalists are no different from any other citizens,'' he said. ``If they receive a subpoena to come to court and tell what they know, they're just like any other citizen, they have the obligation to respond to that. If a court issues a valid search warrant ... obviously they have to stand aside and let them search for it just like any other citizens.''
DOC.HEAD: Arkansas Court Says Records Open
DOC.TEXT: The Arkansas Supreme Court ruled Dec. 17 in support of Donrey Media Group in a Freedom of Information case involving a failed incineration project in the city of Fayetteville. Donrey, owner of The Morning News in Springdale, sued to gain access to records produced in connection with the incinerator. The city said the documents wouldhelp opponents who filed suit challenging the payout of public funds for the $7 million debt remaining on the project. ``We are grateful the Supreme Court affirmed what we believed the law to be,'' said David Olive, a Donrey attorney. ``We hope that this puts this matter at an end and that the City of Fayetteville promptly complies with the request to turn over the information.''
DOC.HEAD: Dukakis Signs Bill Easing Secrecy of Criminal Records
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis on Dec. 17 signed into law a bill to reduce the secrecy of the state's criminal records, ending a three-year struggle to overhaul the Criminal Offender Records Information law. The revised law is a compromise between those who wanted the records opened completely and those who wanted the secrecy maintained. It will keep records open from one to three years, depending on the crime and prison sentence. As passed in 1972, the law kept virtually all criminal records secret. The drive to change it began in the wake of the Willie Horton case that became a major issue in the presidential campaign between Dukakis and George Bush. The records law was little known to the public until Horton, a convicted first-degree murderer from Lawrence, escaped from his 10th prison furlough and went on to rape a young Maryland woman and stab her fiance repeatedly in March 1987. Citing the law, state correction officials refused to say why they gave Horton weekend passes after he had been sentenced to life in prison without parole for the slaying of a teen-ager. Horton's records were released only after the Lawrence Eagle-Tribune sued.
DOC.HEAD: Almanac Accuses New York Magazine of Stealing its Cover
DOC.TEXT: The Old Farmer's Almanac, the folksy, old-fashioned American tradition, has taken on New York Magazine, the trendy chronicle of life in the big city. The 199-year-old Farmer's Almanac filed a trademark infringement lawsuit Dec. 19 accusing New York Magazine of imitating the almanac's distinctive cover design on the cover of its Dec. 3 issue. The almanac's publisher, Yankee Publishing Inc. of Dublin, N.H., said the covers were so similar that readers might be led to believe that the almanac authorized or in some way sponsored its use by New York Magazine. The lawsuit further claimed that New York Magazine, by imitating its trademarked cover, had ``impaired the value of Yankee's cover design and the goodwill symbolized by it.'' New York Magazine had no immediate comment. The disputed cover in dispute, titled ``The 1990 Christmas Gifts Almanac,'' promotes a story of gift suggestions for the holidays. It is illustrated in a similar design as used by the almanac. The lawsuit, filed in U.S. District Court in Manhattan, seeks an order barring New York Magazine from using the cover design in the future and unspecified damages.
DOC.HEAD: Charges Refiled Against Former Newspaper Editor
DOC.TEXT: Authorities in Bucks County on Dec. 17 refiled charges of impersonating a public servant and harassment against Theodore N. Beitchman, former editor-in-chief of The Tribune-Democrat. The same charges were dismissed in November after a judge ruled that the state had insufficient evidence. The charges allege that Beitchman, posing as a state deputy attorney general, made threatening telephone calls to a couple whose son had been involved in a traffic accident with Beitchman's brother. Prosecutor Ted Fritsch said more evidence had been uncovered, but he declined to elaborate.
DOC.HEAD: Report Finds 1990 Unhappy Year for Journalists
DOC.TEXT: The year 1990 was an unhappy one for journalists, with some of the most serious setbacks coming where hope had been strongest, the International Press Institute reported. The institute's World Press Freedom Review paid particular attention to press difficulties in Romania, Yugoslavia, South Africa, Turkey, Kenya, Uganda, Nigeria, Chile, Colombia and Iraq. ``There has been an increase in attacks on the media, and they most galling aspect of all is that they are occurring in countries where we had been given good reason to hope for dramatic changes for the better,'' IPI Director Peter Galliner wrote in the report released Dec. 14. Galliner said one of 1990's most gruesome incidents was the execution in Iraq of Farzad Bazoft, an Iranian-born journalist working for The Observer newspaper of London. Bazoft was accused of spying. Iraq's invasion of Kuwait silenced about 40 Kuwaiti publications, the report noted. ``Ironically, one consequence of Saddam Hussein's move has been the opening ... of the Saudi media, which have been obliged to tell the population the truth, at long last, faced with the evidence all around them,'' Galliner wrote. ``But the Arab media, as a whole, remain shackled and subservient to the political line of their respective governments.''

DOC.HEAD: Der Spiegel Reporter Suspected of Spying for East Germany
DOC.TEXT: Der Spiegel did a 13-page cover story on allegations that one of its reporters was a spy for Communist East Germany. The allegations concerning Diethelm Schroeder surfaced in a television expose and Spiegel did its own story in the Dec. 17 issue. The Hamburg-based newsweekly left Schroeder's name on te roster of its Berlin bureau, but noted he was ``on leave.'' Spiegel showed the drubbing it took from other German publications: a headline in the mass-circulation daily Bild asked if Schroeder was ``a traitor.'' A cartoon republished from the Rheinische Post showed a Spiegel sleuth following a spy's tracks - in a circle that became Spiegel's own trail. ``I have to live with this story,'' Schroeder said in a telephone interview, denying he had worked for the East German secret service or done anybody any harm. The 60-year-old native of eastern Germany, a military specialist who worked in The Associated Press' German-language service for five years in the Sixties, said his Spiegel colleagues had explained that they had done major stories on other spy allegations ``and now we have to write a story about you.'' ``I think it's correct,'' Schroeder said, adding with a laugh, ``I would have had more fun if it was another story, I think.'' ARD television named Schroeder as having worked from 1964 to 1987 for the Stasi, as the now-defunct East Germany's Ministry for State Security is called. Prosecutors confirmed that Schroeder was under investigation, though there was no word on how serious a case he might face. Conviction for passing state secrets can bring life in prison, while a lesser charge of passing information to a foreign espionage agency carries a maximum 10-year prison term. As Germany works to clear up the decades of cross-border spying, prosecutors have already issued 61 arrest warrants this year. Spiegel, which grew up with postwar West Germany, has been hitting the espionage issue hard along with other issues facing newly united Germany. Only a week earlier, Spiegel had a scoop revealing evidence that East Germany's first and only non-Communist prime minister, Lothar de Maiziere, had a Stasi past. De Maiziere denies cooperating with secret police but quit as deputy head of the governing Christian Democratic Union while prosecutors look into the evidence.
DOC.HEAD: Medellin Cocaine Cartel Frees Journalist
DOC.TEXT: A television news cameraman abducted by the Medellin cocaine cartel and held 110 days was freed Dec. 17 in what looked like another step toward a peace deal with authorities. Orlando Acevedo was the fourth journalist freed by drug traffickers in a month. Five other reporters are still held. A taxi left Acevedo in front of the offices of the Medellin daily newspaper El Colombiano. He appeared to be in good health, witnesses said. Acevedo carried a statement from the drug lords denying responsibility for recent terrorism in Medellin. They blamed the police and the Cali drug cartel for massacring 12 persons in a Medellin tavern and for exploding a bomb that injured 10 people over the weekend. The attacks were designed ``to create confusion and damage our sincere efforts for peace,'' the cartel's statement said.
DOC.HEAD: Israeli Interior Minister Sues Newspaper
DOC.TEXT: Interior Minister Aryeh Deri sued a leading Israeli daily for libel Dec. 23 for suggesting he may have exploited his position to purchase four apartments. The article, which was published by the Yedioth Ahronoth daily six months ago, preceded the opening of a police investigation of Deri and his aides on suspicion of fraud and mishandling public funds. Deri's ultra-Orthodox Torah Guardians faction is a key member of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's governing coalition, which relies heavily on smaller religious parties for majority support in the 120-member Parliament. In the suit filed in Tel Aviv District Court, Deri asks for $500,000 in damage, state radio and television said. The newspaper is one of Israel's most widely read dailies. It had not yet filed a defense statement with the court, the national Itim news agency reported. No trial date was set.
DOC.HEAD: If U Cn Rd Ths, U Owe Me $125
DOC.TEXT: At Success magazine, an editor's mistakes are costly: $25 for a mispelling (er, misspelling). Another $25 for poorly-placed hyphens. A whopping $500 for getting somebody's name wrong. For the past two months, sloppy copy has meant surrendering cold cash at Success. Gleefully plundering inattentive editors is Editor in Chief Scott DeGarmo, who says he grew tired of making the same complaints to the same people about the same errors. ``When my people see a typo anyplace, I want them to step on it like a roach,'' DeGarmo said Dec. 19. But taking money for mistakes? Isn't that a little extreme? ``No! If you asked the average guy on the street, he would say of course an editor should know how to spell,'' DeGarmo said. ``If a bricklayer made a crooked wall, or an accountant couldn't add, people would be angry. But editors think it's nothing to not know how to spell.'' The wallet-lightening approach to achieving good grammar began Nov. 5 at the monthly magazine, when DeGarmo fired off a memo to his six senior editors. Errors would no longer be tolerated; fines would be levied. DeGarmo, in the course of his job, would check all copy handed in by his senior editors. If he caught any grammatical or typographical errors, the person responsible would pay: $25 for spelling mistakes, the same for hyphens after words ending in -ly (highly-sought, for example). The fines would come from the money budgeted for their raises. ``The editors? They were appalled and astounded,'' DeGarmo recalled. ``But all the so-called positive reinforcement hadn't worked.'' How serious was DeGarmo? Ask senior editor Michael Maren, who had a $600 lesson in how to spell epitaph, guerrilla and prestigious, among other words. After watching DeGarmo take a big bite of his money, Maren was apologetic. ``We probably didn't check things as carefully as we should have,'' he told The Wall Street Journal. DeGarmo's approach has paid off in more than one way. In addition to collecting $625, he has not seen a glitch in copy since Nov. 29. ``It's not enough to ask people to do their best,'' DeGarmo said. ``You've got to tell them what you want; in my case, it was perfection.''

DOC.HEAD: Tourism Group Takes Aim at Newspaper
DOC.TEXT: A tourism group wants to expel the La Crosse Tribune from its membership because the paper wrote a series of articles that reflected badly on the agency's image. Barbara Donna, president of the La Crosse Area Convention and Visitor Bureau said the Tribune also violated the organization's bylaws by not adhering to a bureau goal of strengthening community and business involvement. The bureau said it would hold a hearing Jan. 10 to consider expelling the newspaper from the group. The Tribune had reported earlier that a former bureau executive director had received $2,000 for a convention trip he did not take and that an advertising executive had done $200,000 worth of business with the bureau while sitting on its board.
DOC.HEAD: AP Stringer Honored by Federal Judges
DOC.TEXT: Longtime reporter and Associated Press stringer Milt Sosin was honored Dec. 19 by federal judges who named the courthouse press room after him. A plaque and a framed newspaper profile of Sosin were unveiled at a surprise ceremony led by Chief U.S. District Judge James Lawrence King. King said Sosin had pestered the judges for a press room so often when the courthouse was under construction that they threatened to name the office after him - and 18 years later finally did. Judges and editors told stories from Sosin's career, which has spanned nearly 60 years, including covering the African theater in World War II, the first manned U.S. space flights, the Cuban revolution, the assassination of President Kennedy, including an eyewitness view of the shooting of Lee Harvey Oswald, and most recently Manuel Noriega's drug case. Along with working for the AP as a staff member in New York and a stringer in Miami, Sosin spent much of his career writing for The Miami News. He won't say his age. Former News columnist John Keasler recounted the story of an editor who was preparing an elaborate plan to deploy the staff for major news events and asked Sosin's then-editor Howard Kleinberg how he would handle a hurricane. ``Give Sosin a roll of quarters for the pay phone and send him where the wind is,'' Kleinberg responded. U.S. District Judge Eugene Spellman remembered a reporter complaining about the pope's first visit to Miami because the news media couldn't get close enough to the podium to ask questions. ``Then the pope stepped to the microphone and when he stepped aside, Milt was right behind him,'' the judge said. Sosin said the dedication ceremony caught him by surprise. ``It's the first time I've ever been scooped,'' he joked.
DOC.HEAD: NBC News Links Up With Japanese Network
DOC.TEXT: NBC News and Nippon Television Network agreed Dec. 17 on a joint newsgathering venture, the third agreement this year between a U.S. network news division and a Japanese broadcaster. NBC News will have exclusive U.S. rights to all Japanese and international news material of NTV, Japan's largest private broadcast network, NBC said. In return, NTV, with which NBC has had a working relationship for almost 40 years, will get exclusive rights to news material from the NBC News Channel, the 24-hour affiliates' news service that NBC will start on New Year's Day. The Japanese network will be the News Channel's first overseas affiliate, NBC said. The agreement comes at a time when NBC, CBS and ABC's news divisions are trying to reduce costs of their overseas news operations by sharing the costs and coverage with foreign broadcasters or selling them news material. Their efforts have been given fresh impetus by high costs of the Persian Gulf crisis and a flat advertising market this fall. Last September, CBS News and Tokyo Broadcasting System said they would combine their resources and technology for worldwide newsgathering, starting in April. The deal gives TBS exclusive rights in Japan to CBS News material. In October, ABC News and Worldwide Television News, a London-based television news agency in which ABC has an 80 percent interest, signed a non-exclusive agreement to provide Fuji TV with U.S. and international news. Under the CBS-TBS agreement, that Japanese network also got exclusive rights to some news programs, among them the ``CBS Evening News.'' Under the agreement between NBC and Nippon, the Japanese network can continue excerpting reports from the ``NBC Nightly News'' and the ``Today'' show, said Peggy Hubble, a spokeswoman for NBC News. The two programs are distributed internationally by Visnews, another London-based TV news agency in which NBC has an interest of nearly 38 percent.
DOC.HEAD: Canadian Network Facing Hard Times
DOC.TEXT: Pink slips go out next month for about 1,000 employees of the Canadian Broadcasting Corp., the government-owned network many see as the glue that holds together this vast and diverse nation of 26 million people. The bad news comes from budget-cutters who are slashing 10 percent of the corporation's staff, closing television stations and reducing services. Their goal is to make up a projected shortfall of $91 million in next year's $935 million budget. Declining advertising revenues, reduced government funding and rising TV production costs have hurt the network deeply. About 75 percent of production costs comes from the government. Angry public protests have occurred from Newfoundland to Ontario to the Gaspe Peninsula of Quebec over what many feel are cuts in one of the few things that make Canadians really different from Americans. The CBC will cut 1,100 of its nearly 11,000 permanent positions, effective April 5. In announcing the cutbacks and closures Dec. 5, CBC President Gerard Veilleux said they were permanent and would not be reversed even if there is a turn in the 54-year-old corporation's economic fortunes. A major element in the cost-saving program was closure of three television stations entirely and reducing eight others to small news reporting bureaus feeding their reports into regional and national centers. The CBC also announced it no longer will operate the parliamentary channel, which broadcasts debate in the House of Commons, or Radio Canada International, the shortwave service that broadcasts in 14 languages abroad. Iqbal Rahemtulla, a spokesman for the corporation, said the House of Commons may take over the funding of the parliamentary broadcast and the Ministry of External Affairs, because of international ramifications, is considering ways to maintain Radio Canada International's services. If all that wasn't bad enough, the CBC's projections show that there will be another shortfall of about $42 million in the 1992-93 budget. Emerging relatively unscathed, except for a 1 percent budget reduction, is CBC Radio, broadcasting in both French and English to every Canadian in this gigantic country. The radio, which carries no advertising, features news, current events, talk shows and music to a wide range of audiences on both AM and FM. Its Northern Service also broadcasts in English, French and eight native languages and dialects.

DOC.HEAD: CNN Scrambling Transmission to Central, South America
DOC.TEXT: Some satellite dish owners in Central and South America no longer will get Cable News Network for free. Turner Broadcasting System said Dec. 20 that it will begin scrambling its CNN feed south of the border next month. The company said it will make the switch when it begins beaming the Turner Network Television movie channel to the region on a scrambled signal. TBS said the dish owners were receiving the news service illegally for two years. TBS feeds its 24-hour news channel to about 35,000 hotel rooms and 250,000 homes in the region and sells its signal to about 35 broadcast clients, TV stations and networks. South American satellite dish owners who want to continue receiving CNN would have to buy a receiver and decoder from an equipment company, at a cost of about $1,300, and then enter a contract with CNN to unscramble the feed. Although CNN does not now contract with individuals, spokeswoman Kitsy Riggall said the company would ``certainly work with anybody who wants to receive it.'' TBS said it was concerned about ``weak copyright laws in the region.'' It has been scrambling its signal in the United States for five years. The company said it has no plans to scramble CNN's signal to the rest of the world.
DOC.HEAD: Man Who Appeared on `Geraldo' Sues Show for $28 Million
DOC.TEXT: A man who appeared on ``Geraldo'' sued the host, Geraldo Rivera, and a producer Dec. 20 for $28 million, claiming they revealed his identity after promising not to do so. Carl J. Ober said in his lawsuit that he appeared on a segment of the syndicated television show titled ``Telephone Terror,'' with women who were victimized by telephone harassment. Ober, from Albany, appeared as an alleged telephone harasser under a written and verbal agreement with Rivera that his identity would not be revealed, the lawsuit said. On at least two occasions during the show, Rivera called him ``Carl'' and on at least two other occasions referred to him as Carl Ober, the lawsuit said. The show aired Feb. 15, 1990. The lawsuit said Rivera disclosed Ober's occupation and place of residence and identified a psychologist who is treating him. The lawsuit said that on at least four occasions, Ober's face was shown with the words, ``Made obscene phone calls,'' and Rivera called him a ``sick person'' who ``verbally raped'' women. The show had no immediate response to the lawsuit. Named as defendants in the lawsuit are: Rivera; a producer, Marilyn Kaskel; and the Investigative News Group Inc., Rivera's production company. The lawsuit said Ober suffered ``ridicule, embarrassment, vexation, humiliation, mental and emotional distress.''
DOC.HEAD: Home of `60 Minutes' Source Is Apparently Firebombed
DOC.TEXT: The mobile home of a man who appeared on ``60 Minutes'' to expose odometer tampering by used car dealers was apparently firebombed while he was away, authorities said. The explosion and fire early Dec. 19 destroyed the home of Charles Vance, a construction company owner and former used car dealer who went to CBS along with a business partner with allegations of fraud by Houston wholesalers. ``It's retaliation for the odometer segment,'' Vance said. ``I would have done the same thing again. I believe it was something that needed to be done.'' Vance told authorities he had been getting death threats even before the story aired Dec. 9. Shots were fired at the trailer Oct. 31, said ``60 Minutes'' spokesman Roy Brunett. Vance said he has been moving his family from the home frequently to make it appear people were living there. He said the family stayed there the night of Dec. 17 but stayed elsewhere the next night. ``We're happy that he's safe and we're thankful that no one was hurt,'' Brunett said.
DOC.HEAD: NBC Insiders Speculate Couric Will Replace Norville
DOC.TEXT: Less than a year after Deborah Norville succeeded Jane Pauley on NBC's ``Today'' show, network sources are speculating that national correspondent Katie Couric will replace her, a published report said. Don Browne, executive vice president of NBC News, denied the rumors, saying it's too soon after Ms. Norville's arrival to change the show's co-hosts. Ms. Couric is scheduled to substitute for Ms. Norville when she goes on maternity leave in the spring. ``She's no substitute - she's the successor,'' an unidentified source told TV Guide in its Dec. 29 issue. ``Deborah's a bright woman, but she doesn't come across that way on camera. She comes across as plastic. Katie's real.'' Ms. Couric joined NBC in 1989 as deputy Pentagon correspondent. She has filled in several times as weekend anchor of ``NBC Nightly News'' and is scheduled to substitute for ``Nightly News'' anchorman Tom Brokaw on New Year's Eve.
DOC.HEAD: Public Television News Magazine Renewed After Protests
DOC.TEXT: Public television station KCET reversed itself Dec. 18 and decided to renew ``South Africa Now'' after a conservative media group that fought the show filed papers challenging the station's license. The station's decision came one day after the Committee on Media Integrity asked the Federal Communications Commission to deny renewal of KCET's license and a request for a new transmitter.
