DOC.HEAD: Stacks of Cash Bolster Both Sides in Forest Fight
DOC.TEXT: Behind the pleas to save the trees and loggers' cries for saving jobs, millions of dollars are being wagered on a congressional fight for control of the nation's oldest forests. The timber and paper products industry contributed nearly $5 million to presidential and congressional candidates over the last eight years, including more than $775,000 to current members of the Senate and the House from five northwestern states, according to federal records. Environmental groups countered with just over $2 million in the same period, according to the records. ``Today, politics is part of doing business,'' says Ned Massee, manager of government relations for Westvaco Corp., one of the country's largest producers of paper products. The New York-based owner of 1.1 million acres of U.S. timberlands led the industry with $716,700 in political action committee contributions from 1983 through 1990, records at the Federal Election Commission show. Ali Webb of the League of Conservation Voters said, ``We lost several elections this year because we couldn't help challengers with sufficient resources.'' Both sides seem likely to continue pressing their cause as Congress struggles to decide on the best use for the country's forests. The two sides deny partisan preference in their political contributions. Yet, 73 percent of the timber money went to Republicans and 93 percent of the environmental contributions went to Democrats, according to election commission records. Envirnomentalists favor cutbacks in logging to protect the northern spotted owl and other threatened creatures, to slow degradation of soils and streams and to enhance wilderness recreation. Industry says such a break from traditional timber practices would cripple logging communities, cost tens of thousands of jobs and sharply raise prices for wood products. The northern spotted owl has become the most visible symbol of this struggle, with the Bush administration working to develop a plan that can save the owl while limiting the loss of jobs in the lumber industry. In a federally mandated effort to protect the threatened owl, logging is expected to drop in the Pacific Northwest by about 20 percent next year. Environmentalists have enlisted dozens of legislators in support of even broader forest-protection proposals, which would cut harvests at least in half. This year, President Bush also signed into law toughened restrictions on exports of unprocessed logs from federal and state lands. Several members of Congress want a similar ban on exports of raw logs from private lands as a way of boosting jobs for domestic processors. Sen. Slade Gorton, R-Wash., is the industry's favorite recipient of contributions, with a total of $103,413. Sen. Mark Hatfield, R-Ore., is next with $68,980. Neither could be reached for comment. Gorton's press secretary, Kraig Naasz, said the money has not influenced Gorton's voting. ``I think our level of contributions from the timber industry is more reflective of Slade's devotion to timber communities and their livelihood,'' Naasz said. Reps. Jim Clarke, D-N.C., Jim Jontz, D-Ind., and Les AuCoin, D-Ore., were the financial champions of the environmental lobbyists. Clarke had contributions of $44,331; Jontz, $31,992; AuCoin, $31,896. AuCoin is one of five legislators who received at least $10,000 from each side. The others are Sens. Wyche Fowler, D-Ga., and John Chafee, R-R.I., and Reps. John Miller, R-Wash., and Richard Stallings, D-Idaho. Since January 1983, industry donations have gone to four in five of the current members of the Senate and more than two-thirds of the current members of the House, election commission documents and Common Cause reports show. Aside from Westvaco, other heavy hitters include International Paper Co., Union Camp Corp., Weyerhaeuser Co., Georgia-Pacific Corp., Boise Cascade Corp. and the National Forest Products Association. ``When you analyze a company like Boise Cascade and the various businesses we are in, the impacts that state and federal government can have on us are immense,'' said Kirk Sullivan, a vice president for the company in Boise, Idaho. The company owns or controls 6.2 million acres of timberlands and manufactures and distributes paper and paper products and building materials. The Sierra Club tops the contributor list for environmental groups, spending $1.2 million over the last eight years. The League of Conservation Voters is next with $701,271. Eight other environmental groups registered with the FEC spent a total of less than $300,000 since January 1983. More than 40 forest and paper industry PACs are on file. Industry contributions have increased steadily in each of the last four two-year election cycles, from $1 million in 1983-84 to $1.4 million in the last cycle, the records show. Environmentalists spent about $425,000 in 1989-90, according to the records. Their peak period was $734,143 in 1983-84 - about one-third of it directed against the re-election of President Reagan. More than 50 senators have received at least $10,000 from the industry; 20 received more than $30,000. Of the 435 House members, 68 got at least $10,000 from the industry and 18 pulled in more than $30,000. Forty-one senators and four in 10 House members picked up checks from environmental groups. Ten senators and 18 House members received more than $10,000.

DOC.TEXT: Consider the California condor, the Arabian oryx, the Guam rail, the blue poison dart frog. They are among the endangered species that have been successfully bred in captivity as zoologists take the offensive to save many forms of wildlife from extinction. Such conservation programs have now spread to more than 150 zoos and aquariums. ---

No longer mere display cases for nature's creatures, the nation's zoos and aquariums are taking a more active role in trying to save species that are rapidly disappearing from the wild. The American Association of Zoological Parks and Aquariums headquartered in Bethesda, Md., coordinates a captive-breeding program for more than 50 endangered species at more than 150 zoos and aquariums. ``It's not the same old zoo anymore. It's not the little guy with a mustache pushing a broom around,'' says Dick George, spokesman for the Phoenix Zoo in Arizona. ``We have a responsibility to face up to in the next decade. It looks like we are going to be perpetual hosts to these animals.'' For example, in steamy cinderblock rooms next to the Rain Forest exhibit at the National Aquarium in Baltimore, curator Jack Cover heads the breeding of the threatened blue poison dart frog. Herpetologists at the aquarium in 1988 became the first to breed the species. Their success came after they spent five years carefully re-creating the frog's natural environment, only to find the tiny creatures prefer the bottom of a plastic 2-liter soda bottle. However, the progeny have never lived up to their name. The captive-born frogs, whose parents were found in the wild in isolated pockets of jungle in Suriname, have never produced the deadly poison researchers want to study. Many zoologists fear that they may become curators of living museum pieces that won't have a home to return to in the wild. One of the biggest enemies of endangered species has been habitat destruction, but overhunting, pollution and introduced predators - those brought by man - have also taken a toll. ``When you cut down a rain forest, you're not just cutting down trees,'' Cover says. ``You're cutting down the environment for thousands of species.'' To avoid extinction, an estimated 2,000 species of large invertebrates will need to be bred in the next two decades, says Michael Hutchins, director of science and conservation for the zoos and aquariums association. However, only 900 species can be bred using current facilities, he says. ``Space is extremely limited. Decisions we make now will probably doom some species to extinction and save others,'' says Hutchins, who oversees the group's Species Survival Plan. ``The same kind of decisions will have to be made for wild animas. ``Some estimates are that 1 million species of animals and plants could go extinct in the next two decades. We don't know what kind of impact that is going to have.'' Zoos may need to maintain captive populations for as long as 200 years, until world population growth can be controlled and native habitats restored, some biologists say. In addition, zoologists may be forced in the future to move animals in the wild from place to place to maintain genetic diversity, and veterinarians may need to make jungle calls to keep wild populations healthy, Hutchins says. ``I tell people that zoos are going to have to change as much in the next 10 years as they have in the past 100 if they are to fulfill their role in conservation,'' Hutchins says. To be selected for the Species Survival Plan, a species must be endangered and must be abundant enough in captivity to form a viable gene pool. Computer records are kept of every animal and its lineage to prevent inbreeding. The aim of the program, which began in 1981, is to create a self-sustaining captive population for each species. The goal is to reintroduce the animals to the wild. The Phoenix Zoo works with 14 species in the Species Survival Plan and has successfully reintroduced the Arabian oryx, similar to an antelope, to the deserts of Oman and Jordan. The Point Defiance Zoo in Tacoma, Wash., and the Wild Canid Survival Center near St. Louis have reintroduced red wolves to a North Carolina wildlife refuge.

DOC.HEAD: AGENCIES AND RADIO OUT
BALTIMORE: wildlife refuge.
DOC.TEXT: The Philadelphia Zoo has bred the Guam rail, a small tropical bird that resembles a sandpiper. The Cincinnati Zoo implanted an embryo from an endangered Indian desert cat into a surrogate mother - a domestic house cat that nursed the kitten as if it were her own. At the aquarium in Baltimore's redeveloped Inner Harbor, still one of the most polluted areas of the Chesapeake Bay, a collection of crickets, wax worms, fruit flies and other insects are kept in rows of bottles on a shelf in a cramped, pungent work area behind the rain forest exhibit. Above the bottles is a sign reading, ``Time flies like an arrow, fruit flies like a banana.'' What blue poison dart frogs like is a diet high in calcium and phosphorous, humidity and privacy. The three-quarter-inch, blue-and-black frog is so-named because it secretes a deadly alkaloid similar to curare, which South American Indians use to make poison darts. ``In the wild they lay their eggs under large jungle leaves,'' Cover says. ``We've found the bottom of 2-liter soda bottles are a real good breeding hut. We put a plastic leaf in a petri dish and put the bottle over the top. ``The male does a courtship dance. The female, if receptive, follows him in and does an elaborate courtship dance with all kinds of stroking and spinning. Then she lays her eggs and he'll fertilize them.'' Cover and his colleagues are still working on how to get the frogs to produce the toxin medical researchers want to study. Herpetologists and others have tried several unorthodox methods. Special diets didn't work, nor did daily handling of the frogs. They thought cold baths, which would simulate the dangers of the wild, might be the key. ``We actually tested that hypothesis,'' Cover says. ``But in the wild the frog would already have to have the poison the first time a predator comes down. There wouldn't be a second chance. So, danger doesn't seem like it would stimulate production.'' Perhaps the mostnown endangered species is the California condor, the largest land bird in North America, which has a wingspan of up to 10 feet. There are 40 California condors known to exist and all are in captivity - 21 at the San Diego Wild Animal Park and 19 at the Los Angeles Zoo. The last condor known to exist in the wild was captured in 1987. Before 1985, scientists had hoped to breed them in captivity and in the wild, but between 1984 and 1985, four of the last five breeding pairs in the wild were lost and presumed dead. In 1985, federal officials decided to capture all remaining wild condors in a last-ditch effort to save the species. That effort drew criticism from several environmental groups, but it appears to have been the right choice. ``When we first hatched birds in captivity, it was pretty exciting,'' says Dr. Michael Wallace, curator of birds at the Los Angeles Zoo. ``We were under a lot of pressure from outside groups to release the birds. It's good to see we could not only do it, but do it fairly well.'' Four of the vulture-like chicks were hatched this year at the San Diego park and four at the Los Angeles Zoo. That success has enabled zoologists to consider reintroducing some of the condors into the wild as early as next year, several years ahead of schedule. Despite their successes, zoologists are quick to remind that breeding programs are only part of the solution. ``Zoos are looking at being part of a holistic program,'' Hutchins says. ``If we are going to save species, we just can't save them in zoos. But at least having these populations in captivity provides us with the option of reintroducing them.''

From AP Newsfeatures

DOC.TEXT: For a century and a half the great ships of the Cunard line have been sailing the seas, in war and peace. Today Cunard has seven cruise ships, including the QE2, calling at 240 ports around the world. A reporter who recently took a cruise on the Black Sea in Eastern Europe tells of the line's colorful history. ---

Old Sam Cunard would be delighted to learn that stewards on the steamship line he launched 150 years ago still don immaculate white gloves to serve afternoon tea, that no cabin numbers end in 13 and that the ship's concert survives as the passenger talent show. He would be particularly gratified to learn that when Her Majesty calls, Cunard ships still go off to war, as the QE2 did, with a helicopter pad covering its swimming pool, in the Falkland Islands war. After all, he was knighted for deploying his entire eight-ship fleet to transport troops and horses to the Crimean War. Sir Samuel wouldn't be too upset at finding Cunard's main operations are now centered in New York, and not London or Liverpool. Halifax, Nova Scotia, was his birthplace and home port when the admiralty awarded him the contract ``to convey the mails from a point in England to Halifax and back, twice each month.'' He ordered four steam and sail paddle-wheelers built and began the service in 1850, with Boston at the aft end of what Cunard captains still call the Western crossing. But how in all thunderation did a Cunard ship wind up with a name like the Vistafjord? Or the Sagafjord? Or Seagoddess I or II? In Sam Cunard's day and for almost 100 years all Cunarders had names ending in ia: Saxonia, Media, Parthia, Lucania, Campania, Franconia, Caronia. Nearly 200 of them, all the way from that first paddle-wheeler, the Britannia, to the elegant four-stackers like the Aquitania, the Lusitania and the Mauretania. Then along came the Queen Mary and that legend of how the litany ended. Cunard favored the name Victoria for its first 1,000-foot-long superliner. During a grouse shoot at Balmoral Castle, company director Lord Rydon asked King George V's permission to name the new flagship for ``the most illustrious and remarkable woman who has ever been queen of England.'' Not thinking at all of his grandmother, his majesty replied: ``This is the greatest compliment ever paid to my wife. I'll ask her as soon as I get home.'' A queen's whim altered the name of Cunard's current flagship, which was to have been called the Queen Elizabeth, like its famous predecessor. But at the moment of launching, Queen Elizabeth II impulsively christened her Queen Elizabeth 2, insisting on the Arabic numeral to avoid any thought that she was naming the ship after herself. The former Norwegian American liners Vistafjord and Sagafjord ran up Cunard's familiar ensign of a lion rampant after their purchase in 1983. Most of their officers signed on with the new owners, so that now Cunard's Fifth Avenue headquarters is staffed by a number of Norwegian vice presidents and a couple of Swedes. ``What we call the Scandinavian Mafia,'' laughed Capt. Sverre Brakstad of the Vistafjord who as a boy in Oslo never dreamed of commanding a Cunarder. ``I thought you had to be born on the Clyde or in Bristol.'' Over a century and a half, Cunard's teakwood decks have echoed to the tread of history and heaved and pitched with the waves of ever-passing social change. In Samuel Cunard's lifetime, his ships reduced from six to two weeks the time it took a letter to reach New York from London. They carried the first great waves of Irish and German immigrants and such illustrious passengers as Charles Dickens, Jenny Lind and Mark Twain. Soon Cunard's trans-Atlantic ships doubled and tripled in size. The Sophia was the first to boast ``electric illumination throughout.'' Before the turn of the century, travel posters touted the line's ``floating cities,'' the 600-foot-long Campania and Lucania, with funnels ``as high as the Eddystone lighthouse.'' Marconi conducted wireless experiments aboard the Lucania, enabling the first ship's newspaper to be slipped under cabin doors. In the early part of the 20th century, ``British stately homes went to sea under the names Lusitania, Mauretania and Aquitania,'' as one critic described the luxuriant four-stackers. Then suddenly the Cunard saga was written in grim headlines, not travel brochures: the Carpathia racing to pick up survivors of competing White Star Line's flagship Titanic. The Lusitania going to the bottom in 18 minutes with a loss of 1,198 lives, torpedoed off the Irish coast by U-boat 20 on May 7, l915. Cunard lost 20 ships in World War I but won history's only sea battle between ocean liners when the Carmania engaged the Cap Trafalgar off the Brazilian coast, capsizing the Hamburg South American liner after a deadly exchange between gun crews. Prohibition ushered in the popular ``booze cruises'' with Jazz Age swingers such as Zelda and Scott Fitzgerald sailing off to Havana or Nassau to slake their thirst.

DOC.HEAD: AGENCIES AND RADIO OUT
ABOARD THE MS VISTAFJORD: their thirst.
DOC.TEXT: At John Brown shipyard on Clydeside in Scotland, the Great Depression halted work for two years on hull No. 534, idling more than 3,500 workers, but the Queen Mary, the most-beloved of all Cunard ships, finally made her maiden voyage on May 27, 1936. When the ship reporters came aboard from the pilot boat, there was never a shortage of royalty, real or Hollywood, on the Cunarders. Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia, the Shah of Iran and the Sultan of Jahore favored the Queen Mary, as did the exiled Edward VIII and the Duchess of Windsor, who traveled with 75 trunks in the hold and 70 pieces of luggage in their suite. Film queens from Mary Pickford to Elizabeth Taylor climbed up on the rail, wreathed in a life preserver, for the requisite cheesecake publicity shot. Gertrude Lawrence was ``in the captain's doghouse'' for walking her Pomeranian on the boat deck and not the kennel deck. Liberace, in gold lame jacket, scuttled protocol by insisting that cabin and tourist-class passengers attend his concert. Mae West, who got a life jacket named for her prow, was beloved by the crew for her large tips and the final night party she threw for waiters and stewards who served her. The even-larger Queen Elizabeth, down to two stacks, made her debut in time to don gray livery and go off to war as a troopship. Zigzagging and outspeeding submarines, the Queens delivered millions of British and Commonwealth soldiers to every war zone. Transporting whole U.S. divisions for the Normandy invasion - the Mary once packed 16,683 aboard - the Queens in Winston Churchill's estimation ``shortened the war in Europe by at least a year.'' The U-boats never got close, but there was one tragedy when the Queen Mary in rough seas collided with her escort HMS Curacao, slicing the cruiser in half. Wartime rules did not permit endangering her prime cargo of 15,000 soldiers by picking up survivors. The United States paid Cunard $91 million for deploying 1.6 million GIs on the Queens, a bargain rate of $57 per passenger, considering that teak decks caked with chewing gum (banned too late in the ships' canteens) had to be replaced, along with miles of mahogany railings whittled away by initials, unit numbers and visits from Kilroy. Cunard hit its postwar peak in the '50s, carrying one-third of all trans-Atlantic passengers on 12 liners. But on an October morning in 1958, bridge officers on the Queen Elizabeth saw the first commercial jet roar off from New York's Idlewild Airport, as JFK Airport was then known. Soon the Queens were each losing $1 million a year. When the Queen Elizabeth docked at Hudson River Pier 90 with 900 crew and less than 200 paying guests, the end of the line for liners was gloomily predicted. ``They're always predicting the end of the line for us,'' laughed Capt. Barkstad, during a cruise in the Black Sea. ``Yet more people travel by ship today than ever before. Competition has never been keener. Newer cruise ships holding 2,500 or more are being launched. The airplane has proved to be our best friend. We could never operate cruise schedules around the world without it.'' Cunard has seven cruise ships calling at 240 ports around the world, and the QE2 still keeps up a semblance of trans-Atlantic service with 18 crossings a year. Contrary to an unsinkable legend, Cunard captains throughout the line's history have rarely been called on to perform marriages. Brakstad, who has been a captain for half of his 56 years, has yet to tie any marital knots, but he does have a plaque in his sea cabin that reads: ``All marriages performed by this captain are valid only for the duration of the voyage.''

DOC.HEAD: Welfare State's Future Questioned As Recession Looms
With LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: To some, the welfare systems in northern Europe are the world's most humane. To others, they're a wasteful gravy train, supporting thousands of people who could work if they had to. Now, an economic downturn is threatening the generous systems and some people living off them will feel the pinch. ---
DOC.HEAD: Welfare State's Future Questioned As Recession Looms
With LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Some of Northern Europe's welfare states wonder how to keep their cradle-to-grave safety nets from fraying in the impending recession. In the post-World War II boom years, the Scandinavian countries, the Netherlands and West Germany introduced programs that spend up to a quarter of the gross national product on welfare. Welfare spending now is outstripping the industrial growth that was supposed to pay the bill. With growth slowing in many European countries, some governments are considering cutbacks. With less money available for welfare, government officials complain more loudly about people abusing the system. Dutch Prime Minister Ruud Lubbers says his nation's welfare system, which will cost the government 132.3 billion guilders ($79.6 billion) in 1991, is out of hand. In a recent report, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, citing Holland's high income taxes and generous welfare benefits, concluded that incentives to work are low. The nation has an 11 percent unemployment rate. Dutch authorities recently failed to lure jobless Amsterdam residents to the understaffed flower industry, even after the government offered a car for every four workers to use for commuting, as well as personal use. Denmark spends 40 percent of its budget on the 1.4 million people - 28 percent of the population - who live on welfare. The center-right coalition government of Prime Minister Poul Schlueter hopes it can reduce welfare dependency by stimulating private industry. Denmark has 20,000 people under 40 years of age getting permanent government pensions of 3,709 kroner ($662) a month because of drug or alcohol problems. In Europe, welfare helps the employed as well as the jobless. The system commonly includes free medical insurance, sick pay, disability and old age pensions, and child-care and unemployment benefits. In Sweden, parents can qualify for benefits for taking time off to nurse a sick child. ``The basic thing is that everyone should have basic opportunities to ... take part in all activities within our society,'' said Annchristen Filipson of the Swedish Social Affairs Ministry. Scandinavian taxpayers can hardly be expected to dig deeper in their pockets to pay a greater share of the welfare costs. Their tax rates of more than 50 percent already are highest in the industrialized world. Last October, Sweden's ruling Social Democratic Party made the first cuts ever in a social welfare system now costing 251.39 billion kronor ($45.13 billion), just over one-fifth of the GNP. The government is expected to cut 15 billion kronor ($2.69 billion dollars) from the welfare budget in 1991. The government is also planning to cut sick pay rates from 100 percent to 75 percent of a worker's salary for the first three days in an effort to discourage malingering. Workers take an average 25 days of sick leave a year. The welfare programs are usually funded by taxes paid by employers and employees, and some are getting fed up. Ove Danemar of the Swedish Employers' Federation criticized ``the whole system'' because ``it stimulates people to work less and to take more leisure time. ``The private sector can't bear it any longer,'' he said. ``It's no longer consistent with a modern economy.'' Critics say many of the benefits were begun in good faith but have ended up being abused. During more favorable economic times, the abuse was widely tolerated. But with the Continent entering a recession, there is more clamping down on wasteful spending. Lubbers has vowed to curb Holland's Unsuitability for Work Act, under which nearly 900,000 people get life-long disability pensions of up to 70 percent of their last-earned pay. In the late 1970s, some companies used it by dismissing unproductive employees, passing the social cost on to the government. About one-third of the program's beneficiaries claim psychological reasons for being unable to work. In a recent speech, Lubbers said wryly: ``Looking at the statistics ... one has to admit that ours is a sick nation.'' This spring, the Dutch government is expected to make deep cuts in the housing, education and cultural subsidies that complement the welfare handouts, themselves equal to at least 70 percent of the minimum wage. It has borrowed heavily and diverted money from other programs to cover welfare costs. Only Germany is making large welfare increases, to pay millions of former East Germans who are unemployed. Norway is slightly expanding its 125.8 billion kroner ($21 billion) welfare system, on which almost a quarter of the population depends in some form or other. The Labor government has added about one billion kroner ($166 million) to the bill since coming into office last month and even the right-leaning opposition Progress Party favors the expansion.

DOC.HEAD: Higher Taxes Go Into Effect Tuesday
DOC.TEXT: New federal taxes will raise the price of tobacco, beverage alcohol and some luxuries beginning Tuesday while upper-bracket Americans will have to pay higher income taxes to help reduce the nation's budget deficit. The changes, combined with the 5.1-cent-a-gallon gasoline tax increase that took effect Dec. 1, will raise the average household's federal tax bill by about $215 a year. Congress estimates the average family making less than $50,000 will pay an extra $1 a week. Those with incomes between $50,000 and $100,000 will pay about $278 a year more on the average. The increase for the $100,000-to-$200,000 group will average $839. The richest 600,000 couples and individuals - with incomes over $200,000 - will pay an average of $8,598 more per year. Congress hit top-income earners to correct what many lawmakers perceived as overly generous tax cuts during the 1980s. The new law boosts the top income-tax rate on people at that income level, restricts their itemized deductions, phases out the value of their personal exemptions and subjects more of their wages to Medicare payroll taxes. On the other hand, prior law will give all taxpayers bigger exemptions and other adjustments designed to prevent last year's inflation from raising their income taxes. The new year also brings a major increase in the earned-income tax credit, which benefits low-income working families with children, and expanded tax incentives for energy investment. Here are highlights of the changes: TOBACCO: Taxes are rising by 25 percent, meaning the 16-cent tax on a pack of cigarettes goes to 20 cents. Other levies: as much as $30 per 1,000 large cigars; $1.125 per 1,000 small cigars; chewing tobacco, 12 cents a pound; snuff, 36 cents a pound; pipe tobacco, 67{ cents a pound. ALCOHOL: The liquor tax goes up $1 to $13.50 for a gallon of 100-proof (50 percent alcohol), an extra 20 cents a fifth for 100-proof; 16 cents for 80-proof. The beer tax is doubled to 32 cents a six-pack. The tax on wine is rising, depending on alcohol content. Table wine, now 17 cents a gallon, goes to $1.07; the levy on artificially carbonated wine, now $2.40, goes to $3.30 a gallon. LUXURIES: A new 10 percent tax applies to that portion of the price above $30,000 for cars, $100,000 for boats, $250,000 for aircraft and $10,000 for furs and jewelry. Vehicles, including taxis and cruise ships, used to transport people for hire are exempt. The tax applies only to the first retail sale of an item. However, Coopers & Lybrand accountants note, for example, that if stones from an antique bracelet worth $10,000 were reset into a new piece of jewelry worth $15,000, the tax would be levied against $5,000. TELEPHONE SERVICE: The 3 percent tax on local and long-distance telephone service, which had been scheduled to expire Dec. 31, was made permanent. GAS GUZZLERS: The penalty tax on fuel-thirsty cars is doubled. Any new car bought in 1991 with an EPA rating under 22{ miles per gallon is subject to a tax ranging from $1,000 (for a 21{-mpg model) to $7,700 (less than 12{ mpg). TAX RATES: A quirk in the 1986 law that allowed some top-income people to pay a lower rate on part of their earnings than applied to those with slightly less income has been eliminated. This results in a new top rate of 31 percent, down from 33 percent. The majority of Americans will continue to pay a flat rate of 15 percent on their taxable income. Because of the new law and the automatic inflation adjustments, the new rate structure looks like this: -Single people pay 15 percent of the first $20,350 of taxable income (after exemptions and deductions); 28 percent on the next $28,950 and 31 percent on everything over $49,300. -Couples filing a joint return pay 15 percent of the first $34,000 of taxable income; 28 percent on the next $48,150 and 31 percent on everything over $82,150. EXEMPTIONS: Increased by $100 to $2,150. Once adjusted gross income (AGI) exceeds $100,000 for a single person or $150,000 for a couple, the exemptions are reduced gradually. They are eliminated totally once income tops $222,500 (single) or $272,500 (couple). STANDARD DEDUCTIONS: Go up from $3,250 to $3,400 for singles and from $5,450 to $5,700 for couples. ITEMIZED DEDUCTIONS: Couples and individuals with AGI over $100,000 will be allowed to use only 97 percent of otherwise allowable itemized deductions. The limit does not apply to medical expenses, investment interest or deductions for theft or casualty losses. Costs of cosmetic surgery will be allowed as a deductible medical expense only if the procedure is necessary to correct a deformity arising from a birth defect, accident or disfiguring disease. Ego-boosting tummy tucks and facelifts are out; nobody can yet say for sure whether orthodontic braces will continue to be deductible. SOCIAL SECURITY TAXES: The 10 million workers who earn more than $51,300 a year will pay a higher Social Security tax. The rate remains 6.2 percent but will apply to the first $53,400 earned in 1991 - up from the maximum $51,300 in 1990. The 1.45 percent tax (generally lumped together on paycheck stubs with the Social Security tax) that finances Medicare hospital benefits will apply to the first $125,000 earned in 1991, up from $51,300 in 1990. Workers' Social Security and Medicare taxes are matched by their employers. CAPITAL GAINS: Although higher-income people will pay a tax rate of 31 percent on some of their income, the top rate applying to capital gains, which are profits from the sale of stock and other investments, is 28 percent. MINIMUM TAX: This 21 percent levy, aimed at ensuring that higher-income people pay some tax regardless of how many legitimate deductions they have, goes up to 24 percent. EARNED-INCOME CREDIT: The maximum credit rises to $1,192 for a one-child family and $1,235 for a family with two or more children. There is a new supplemental credit of up to $357 if a child is under the age of 1, and another credit of up to $428 to help low-income families buy health insurance. ENERGY: New tax incentives of about $500 million a year are designed to encourage investment in exploration and production of oil, gas and alternative fuels. These include a 15 percent tax credit for costs of expensive oil-recovery techniques and drilling when world oil prices drop. ART CONTRIBUTIONS: For 1991 only, a high-income person who is subject to the minimum tax may donate an artwork to certain charities and deduct the full market value, rather than just the cost.

DOC.HEAD: The EPA And Smoking: When Science Takes on Big Business
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: For three years, the tobacco lobby has worked hard to influence an Environmental Protection Agency report on the risks tobacco smoke poses to non-smokers. Using the Freedom of Information Act, The Associated Press obtained documents that reveal details of this classic confrontation between science and big business. ---

When the Environmental Protection Agency convened a panel of scientific experts to rule on whether second-hand cigarette smoke causes lung cancer in non-smokers, both sides arrived fully armed. Most of the megatonnage belonged to the tobacco industry, which employed an army of public relations people brandishing bulging reports ebutting everything ever said about the dangers of passive smoking. Anti-smoking scientists and activists, unable to match the industry's fire power, relied on carefully timed press releases and other surgical strikes. But this gathering in Arlington on Dec. 4-5 was just the latest, most visible battle in a war that had gone on quietly in EPA offices and lawyers' conference rooms for three years. Correspondence and memorandums obtained by The Associated Press under the Freedom of Information Act reveal strenuous efforts by the tobacco industry to influence the EPA deliberations on second-hand smoke. The stakes were obvious - and enormous. ``If second-hand smoke is officially listed as a class A carcinogen'' - a known cause of human cancer - ``it is the end of smoking in any public place,'' said Julia Carol of Americans for Nonsmokers' Rights in Berkeley, Calif. ``Certainly this was an important issue to us,'' said Brennan Dawson, a spokeswoman for the Tobacco Institute, the industry's trade group in Washington, D.C. ``What we have tried to do is stay in the process.'' The industry has proven adept at that. It has not only been with the process, but ahead of it. In October 1987, industry lawyers met with Robert Axelrad, director of the EPA's indoor air division, before the EPA's study of passive smoke and cancer had even begun. ``They were correctly guessing we might get into tobacco smoke,'' said Axelrad. ``It was a `get acquainted.''' In a March 18, 1988, letter to the EPA, Samuel Chilcote, president of the Tobacco Institute, laid out the industry's position: The evidence doesn't show tobacco smoke causes lung cancer in non-smokers. Two years earlier, both the U.S. surgeon general and the National Research Council had concluded that passive smoking does cause lung cancer. The tobacco industry didn't accept the conclusions of either report. Chilcote went so far as to suggest the phrasing the EPA ought to use. He warned against the terms ``passive smoking'' and ``involuntary smoking.'' They ``could cause confusion and lead to a mistaken view that exposure to ETS (environmental tobacco smoke) is in fact `involuntary smoking,''' Chilcote wrote. ``These terms should simply be avoided.'' The industry also argued that ventilation - not restriction of smoking - is the best way to clear the air. The EPA's position is that all indoor air pollutants, including cigarette smoke, are best removed by elimination of the source, not by ventilation. The EPA said so in letters to the Tobacco Institute and its lawyers. The industry repeated its assertions again and again for two years. By June 1989, William Rosenberg, the EPA's assistant administrator for air and radiation, had had enough. In a letter to a tobacco industry lawyer, he criticized the industry's insistence that the evidence linking passive smoking to cancer is ``controversial.'' ``The fact of the matter is, we find the Surgeon General and the National Research Council reports to be highly credible,'' Rosenberg wrote. ``Frankly, the tobacco industry's argument ... would be more credible if it were not so similar to the tobacco industry's position on direct smoking, despite the estimated 50,000 studies linking smoking with disease in humans.'' The tempo of the exchange between the EPA and the industry picked up last June. A draft copy of the EPA report was leaked and then officially released to the press; unflinchingly, it concluded that second-hand smoke is a known cause of lung cancer. The industry stepped up its lobbying. When the EPA appointed the panel of scientific experts that would meet in Arlington, the industry worked ard for the dismissal of Dr. David Burns, the senior editor of the surgeon general's report on passive smoking. The effort succeeded, but not for long. When word of his dismissal got out, Burns was reappointed. U.S. Rep. Thomas Bliley of Richmond, Va. - where Philip Morris is the largest private employer - took up the industry cause. He wrote to the EPA to say that the reappointment of Burns raises ``serious questions about the overall integrity of the selection process.'' The charge was that Burns was an activist, and therefore couldn't be impartial. Burns denied the charge, and many other scientists said he was one of the nation's leading authorities on the subject of passive smoking. Subsequent news reports revealed that six of the 16 scientists on the panel had ties to a tobacco industry research organization. One of the six was also negotiating for a $1.2 million research grant from Philip Morris while serving on the EPA panel. A seventh was recommended by the tobacco industry. The loudest outcry over those revelations didn't come from anti-smoking activists. It came from Bliley, the industry ally. The selection process ``has become so deeply enmeshed in political and media controversy that an objective review by the present panel is no longer possible,'' he wrote on Nov. 23. He urged the EPA to select a new expert panel - a move that would have delayed completion of the final EPA report. The entire process has drawn criticism from all sides. ``It's not the first time the industry has tried to influence science,'' said Dr. Alan Blum, the founder of Doctors Ought to Care, an anti-smoking group. He said he was puzzled by the public's apparent lack of concern. ``If the toxic waste people tried to do something like this, they would be blasted by everyone in the country. When the tobacco industry does it, we look at it as business as usual.'' Dawson of the Tobacco Institute blamed the disruption of the scientific process on anti-smoking advocates. ``There has been a lot of involvement by the anti-smoking community that we don't think should be there,'' she said. ``If you're going to pursue science, it ought to be without advocacy.'' ``We don't have lobbyists everywhere,'' protested Carol, at Americans for Nonsmokers' Rights. ``We have not felt that it was our business to tell the EPA what the science is.''

DOC.HEAD: Gang Bloodshed Pushes Killings to Record High
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: Not long after a good friend died fighting members of a rival gang, the nightmares began for Nightowl. The gang member, who says he fears police reprisal if he gives his real name, dreams that he is bound hand and foot. The man who killed his friend Chopper six months ago points a gun at him and fires. ``I can see him and I'm scared and I'm full of hate,'' Nightowl says. ``Then I wake up and I think, `I can't go down to the neighborhood because if I do, I'm going to die.' But you know, I go down anyway.'' Nightowl, his street name, is dressed in typical gang fashion: white T-shirt and oversized pants. His hair is close-cropped except at the nape of the neck, where it is tied in a small ponytail. The 19-year-old is a member of the Clarence Street Locos. Three Locos have been killed so far this year in the gang's war with the rival East LA Dukes. And the Locos say there's no truce in sight. ``It's never going to stop. Too many have died already,'' said a member of The Mafia Connection, an ally of the Locos. Bloody warfare among black and Hispanic street gangs has made 1990 a record year for gang-related homicides in the nation's second-largest city. Gang killings are up a staggering 53 percent in suburban areas patrolled by Los Angeles County Sheriff's deputies. The gang death count was at 160 as of Nov. 30, compared to 104 during the same period in 1989 and 116 gang murders for all of 1989. In the city of Los Angeles, there was a 12.4 percent jump in gang killings as of Nov. 30, with 315 dead. In 1989, 276 people were killed in gang-related incidents during that period, with a total of 303 gang homicides committed for all of 1989. Cmdr. William Booth said the numbers are deceptive because police today can better identify gang members, and investigators are more likely to call a murder gang-related than they were in the past. Even so, gang violence is increasing, he said. ``They have the weapons and they have the mobility. Plus, they simply have little reverence for human life, somebody else's life,'' Booth said. ``It's almost an animal kind of syndrome that prevails with the gang mentality.'' The stories behind the statistics illustrate the heartbreak and terror of gang violence: - A 5-year-old South Los Angeles girl was killed by a stray bullet as she joined friends to sing ``Happy Birthday'' at a party. - In eastern Los Angeles County, Albert Domingo Simenia, 36, was fatally stabbed while battling eight gang members in his front yard. - In suburban La Puente, worried school officials canceled a high school football game following 16 gang-related shootings in two weeks. - Fourteen people, including two toddlers, were wounded in a Nov. 30 drive-by attack during a family party in Valinda. The carnage has overshadowed the success of an anti-gang pilot program in a South Los Angeles area controlled by the Crips and Bloods, two predominantly black gangs. ``The violence is not even personal,'' said the Rev. Gregory Boyle, a Roman Catholic priest who has buried 10 gang members this year from his East Los Angeles parish. ``The war we're having right now, there are even brothers, flesh and blood brothers, on different sides.'' Police most often blame the increased violence on easy-to-get weapons and the release of hundreds of older Latino gang members imprisoned since the mid-1980s. Youth workers, however, say an influx of Central American immigrants has changed the nature of Hispanic gangs. Traditional neighborhood gangs that fought over neighborhood boundaries are giving way to more pragmatic groups trafficking in drugs and prostitution, said Steve Valdivia, director of Community Youth Gang Services. ``In the Latino community, the warriors have changed, but the war goes on,'' Valdivia said. ``It has a direct correlation with the political and economic upheaval in other countries. A lot of them come over with a violent history. The law enforcement here is no match for what they saw over there. Over there the police cut off an arm or slit your throat. Here, they put you in jail and feed you well,'' he said. But others argue that police have been too heavy-handed in dealing with gangs. As the violence increases, so has the criticism of the rough shakedowns and neighborhood sweeps that have been law enforcement's primary tool. Police themselves are saying that social programs are needed to turn youths away from gangs. ``We're arresting more people, we're prosecuting more people,'' said Sheriff Sherman Block. ``The problem is the law enforcement workload continues to grow because of failures in other institutions. We're talking about school dropout rates, alternative programs that will offer the same kind of need satisfaction that the gangs offer.'' Of the estimated 100,000 gang members in Los Angeles County, 5 percent to 8 percent are ``hope-to-die killer-criminals'' who should be in jail, Valdivia said. The rest, he said, probably can be turned away from gangs if they realize there is an alternative. ``The same things work in any community. Those are prevention, mobilization, community action and law enforcement. Opportunity is a nice thing to throw in also,'' he said. ``You'd be surprised how people behave when you treat them as human beings.'' Valdivia said a one-two punch of tough law enforcement and social programs reduced violence in two South Los Angeles neighborhoods which, until last year, had been the nation's worst for gang violence. While police confronted gang members in the streets, Youth Gang Services organized basketball and softball leagues and offered classes to teach young people how to prepare for job interviews. Part-time jobs were offered through the Department of Public Works. As a result, the Southeast Precinct reported just 17 gang-related homicides during the first eight months of 1990, compared to 39 the previous year. In the 77th Precinct, gang-related killings dropped from 42 to 27, according to police statistics. ``Folks will tell you there's a different feeling,'' said Charles Norman, Youth Services director in the Southeast Precinct. ``If we can do this, the negative element is just going to move on.'' Norman said some youths joined gangs to avoid becoming their prey. ``Take away the jungle atmosphere, most kids won't join a gang. They don't need it,'' he said. But for those already in a gang, loyalties run deep. Nightowl said police crackdowns just make them deeper. He said authorities would stand a better chance of staunching the bloodshed by providing educational opportunities and jobs. Like most of the Locos, Nightowl is a high school dropout. Steady jobs are hard to find. The teen-ager, whose father also was a gang member, soon will become a father himself. The cycle, he said, is tough to break. ``You know, what scares me most is the thought that my little kid is going to grow up and be a gang member,'' he said. ``It scares the hell out of me. But, you know, what can you do about it?''

DOC.HEAD: Priest Devotes Ministry To Battling Gangs
With BC-Gang Violence, b0529
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: In a neighborhood numbed by murderous gang warfare, the Rev. Gregory Boyle battles the violence with what he considers the voice of reason and the love of God. Since arriving at the Dolores Mission five years ago, Boyle has persuaded mothers to take guns away from their gang-member sons and coaxed dozens of gang members to attend the mission's alternative high school. But in gaining the trust of young gangsters, Boyle has roused the suspicion of police, who say his open-arms approach gives the gangs legitimacy they don't deserve. Boyle, in turn, has become a sharp critic of anti-gang strategies that rely on force and intimidation. ``The image for me always is symptom vs. problem,'' said Boyle. ``The police don't have a clue to what the problem is, so what hope do we have that they will be part of the solution? The problem is dysfunctional families and poverty and boredom and jobs. You address that and the gang mess will dry up.'' A Los Angeles native, Boyle, 36, was ordained to the Jesuit order in 1984 after graduating from the Weston School of Theology in Boston. He spent the next year working in an impoverished village in the Bolivian highlands, where he was converted to religious activism. When Boyle arrived at Dolores, he began searching for a solution to the bloody warfare waged by 11 gangs that operate in the parish. Soon he decided he could accomplish more by working with the gangs instead of against them. It is a strategy police dislike. Capt. Bob Medina, commander of the Los Angeles Police Department's Hollenbeck Division, said Boyle has undermined police efforts to convince young people that gang membership in itself is bad. ``He permits them to congregate over there, to wear their colors. I think that's contrary to what we're trying to do,'' Medina said. ``We're trying to dissuade youngsters from joining gangs. The actions he has taken gives them some credibility and makes them proud to be in gangs.'' Boyle turned Dolores Mission, a parish church and school about two miles east of downtown Los Angeles, into a sort of no-man's land where gang members are welcome to congregate provided they leave weapons, drugs and liquor outside. Boyle acknowleded his strategy hasn't stopped the killing. So far this year, he has buried 10 gang members and attended services for even more. But he points out that more than a decade of aggressive police crackdowns has failed to stem a steady increase in violence. During 1990, gang killings have increased more than 30 percent in the Hollenbeck Division, which includes Boyle's parish, according to police statistics. Overall gang-related violence in the area is up more than 50 percent. Boyle blames the carnage on poverty and despair. In his parish, a mostly Hispanic area of public housing projects and aging wood-frame houses, jobs are scarce and teens frequently drop out of high school long before graduation. ``It's all despair, so threats of any kind, all those things that would work in someone who cared, it doesn't cut it for kids who don't have a sense of hope for a better future,'' Boyle said. Earlier this year, Medina asked Boyle's superiors in San Francisco to transfer the priest out of East Los Angeles. Church officials declined, Medina said. Since then, Archbishop Roger Mahony in Los Angeles has reaffirmed his support for Boyle's campaign. Boyle said that so far, he has been unable to achieve one of his major goals - to arrange a lasting cease-fire among warring gangs. But at times, his approach pays off. Last summer, Boyle found temporary jobs for about 40 gang members. So long as they were working, they refrained from ``gang-bangings,'' or launching attacks on rival bands, he said. Several gang members interviewed in the mission's small recreation room said there was less temptation to fight when they were employed. ``When you get a job you change because you're making money. You can go places. You don't have to stay around here,'' said one gang member who refused to give his name. ``You don't have to steal, you don't have to sell dope. ... You got a job, it does change a lot of people.'' Boyle said he believes his approach - despising the sin but not the sinner - will work in the long run. But that is not why he employs it. ``The stand this church has to gang members is what Jesus would do, that it's morally correct and based on the gospel,'' he said. ``To work with them and find jobs for them and lovingly accept them is what Jesus would do. Whether any of that works is not my concern. I think it works, but that's not the point.''

DOC.HEAD: AGENCIES AND RADIO OUT
From AP Newsfeatures
DOC.NOTE: (APN SUNDAY ILLUSTRATIONS: Mailed print subscribers get 3 b&w photos. ColorFoto subscribers get 2 35mm slides.)
DOC.TEXT: Babies sell. Like pretty girls, they are used to peddle everything from suntan oil to automobile tires in TV commercials. But capturing those few seconds of charm can be a nightmare for the directors and cameramen. Here's a peep behind the scenes at a shooting. ---

The meter is running, clicking off thousands of dollars an hour in expenses. Camera crews and lighting technicians dawdle; the stand-ins, the mothers, the baby handler, the attending nurse are transfixed. The advertising man paces. The director's anxious eyes flit from his watch to the non-developing scenario before him. Center stage is the star. A baby. ``They are probably the most difficult commercials I've ever shot,'' says Mike Rogers, senior vice president to the creative director for DDB-Needham. He handles tire commercials. Nonetheless, babies are great for the advertising business. No one can say how many commercials babies make, or what percentage of the business infants command, but they sell. From the time the puppy tried to pull a tyke's bathing suit down in the ads for suntan oil to today's tiny tots with adult voices talking about fast-food restaurants, they are a sure vehicle for merchandising. John Hicks has a company called Baby Wranglers that casts babies. ``Maybe it's just the innocence,'' he says. ``There's a vulnerability and there's an exuberance. I don't want to get too philosophical about it, but I do think we're living in a pretty jaded world and when we see something like that, it attracts you.'' It may attract the viewer, but it is a major headache for the adults who do the filming. ``You're helpless,'' Rogers says. ``You go through a lot of nail-biting and hair-pulling because there is absolutely nothing you can do. You can do everything possible to create an environment and cast the right baby. But if that baby isn't feeling well or is a little bit cranky, you're out of luck.'' Never mind that there are seven stand-in babies waiting in the wings. A baby might be cast in the morning and is fine in the morning. But when it comes to shooting the scene, it is afternoon, and maybe that baby is not an afternoon baby. ``You have a baby you want to use, and he'll come to the set that morning with a rash,'' Rogers frets. ``Or at some point in a production schedule, you'll say bring that baby in and you'll find out all of a sudden she has a cut lip because she was playing with a toy.'' One commercial for Michelin tires started with a hand drawn pinup of a big-eared baby in a tire and a line: ``So much is riding on your tires.'' The campaign has been running six years now (much longer than normal), gone through some 40 babies, and still garners awards at the same rate as it did the first year (more than 30 in all). There's great money in it for the babies, too, if they hit, get on air, last a while. Otherwise, they make the Screen Actors Guild minimum of about $265 a day, which barely pays for the gas and the wear-and-tear on mother. If the commercial goes through the cycle, then the baby stands to make $6,000 to $10,000. There are instances of babies making much more. Kathy Jennings, Hicks' partner, cites the case of a baby who worked maybe five minutes and made $40,000. Then there was another case of a baby who was chosen to be the spokesbaby for a certain product. The baby was put on a retainer. ``Nobody took into consideration that babies change both physically and temperamentally,'' Jennings says. ``So by the time they went to film a second commercial, not only didn't the baby look the same, the baby wasn't temperamentally suited.'' They tried a second baby and then dumped the commercial. But the first baby worked two days and made $60,000. Hicks is a whirlwind of action during the casting call, what actors call the cattle call, running out of the audition room to give a baby back to mother, running back with another, putting the baby on the mat with a bunch of toys, playing peekaboo, making strange noises, blowing bubbles.

DOC.HEAD: AGENCIES AND RADIO OUT
NEW YORK: blowing bubbles.
DOC.TEXT: He may seem quite mad, but he is carefully assessing this baby, measuring attention span, independence, good humor, energy level. He will see 150 babies a day, cut the lot to some 30. Three will eventually be chosen, the star and two stand-ins. He meets one mother in the waiting room. She hands the baby over to him and the baby cries. He hands the baby back, says the baby is lovely, but a little nervous today. The mother cries. ``She knows it's over and she wanted another try,'' Hicks says. ``I was trying to be real nice, and you have to try to explain that if I brought the baby into the audition room, I'd only be appeasing them. I know they have unrealistic expectations. They drove a long way and I feel bad for them.'' ``One of the toughest things we have to do is to hand a baby over to an actor or an actress,'' Hicks adds. ``In an audition, all I have to do is get a baby to perform and they can do some pretty amazing things. But when I have to hand that baby to an actor or an actress, I've lost control and it's unnerving.'' An actor may be able to fool the creative execs, but he can't fool the baby. ``The baby can tell by the touch. It's instinctual and the kid will scream. It's the best alarm system for bad acting you'll ever find.'' Hicks remembers one commercial involving three babies in costume, one of whom kept falling asleep. Then someone got the bright idea of putting a pair of sunglasses on the dozing child and it actually added to the commercial's charm. ``One of the toughest commercials we did was with a tire covered with a blanket,'' Rogers says. They wanted a baby to walk up to the covered tire, stand there a couple of seconds, and then whip off the blanket. And they wanted to shoot it in one take. ``When you want a baby to do something that's what they won't do,'' Rogers says. ``We couldn't get a baby to do it. They'd walk in, take a few steps, then crawl, and crawl right past the tire.'' Finally, on one of the last shots of the day, one of the babies did it perfectly. One commercial will linger in Mike Rogers' memory forever. The commercial was to feature a baby in a tire and a dog sitting next to him. The dog was to get up, walk offstage and return with a puppy held by the scruff of his neck. The dog would deposit the puppy in the tire next to the baby. But the crew worried over the safety of the baby. ``You can't control the little puppy, and we were all concerned it would bite the baby,'' Rogers says. So they put up a partition, which the camera could not see, between the baby and the puppy. The dog dutifully dropped the puppy into its compartment in the tire. Then, Rogers says, the unexpected: ``The baby reached over, picked it up and started to bite the puppy.''

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
In the Groove: Record Reviews
DOC.TEXT:
``Recycler'' (Warner Bros.) - ZZ Top
Billy Gibbons, Dusty Hill and Frank Beard still are mining the old boogie rock to which they first staked their claim to stardom more than 10 years ago. And it still works. The style wears as well as a pair of boots that never seem too tired for another stomp around the dance floor. The Texas trio owe their durability partly to their choice of classic, time-tested rhythms, but just as much to their ability to keep their locomotive-like sound fully stoked and running at full tilt. There are no surprises on ``Recycler,'' just another heaping helping of what ZZ Top fans have come to expect from the biggest little band in Texas. - By David Dishneau, Associated Press Writer.
---

``Ragged Glory'' (Reprise) - Neil Young and Crazy Horse
Neil Young continues to change musical personae more often than most guitarists change strings. Young's 25-album catalog includes country, rockabilly, synth-pop and some of the most beautiful ballads of his generation. But ``Ragged Glory,'' as the title would suggest, is an hour of rock 'n' roll as only Young can play it. Paired with Crazy Horse, a three-piece band that has intermittently backed him since 1969, Young delivers a raw, scorching set dominated by guitar solos. He draws from an immense vocabulary of riffs built up over two decades. The fretboard workout includes crunching chords, ringing melodies, bent notes and feedback. Occasionally, the energy flags when a break runs a little long - four of the 10 songs clock in at more than seven minutes. But Young's playing never sounds methodical. The garage-band sound is matched with lyrics that have this child of the '60s sounding nostalgic. ``There's a mansion on the hill,'' Young sings. ``Psychedelic music fills the air. Peace and love live there still. There's a mansion on the hill.'' Even when waxing sentimental, Young sings with the energy of a teen-ager. His casual relationship with the proper key is Dylanesque, and he doesn't think twice about roaming an octave above his range. ``Ragged Glory'' is a stark contrast to Young's marvelous 1989 album, ``Freedom,'' which contains angry, more polished music. But if you need a guitar fix, this Neil's for you. - By Steven Wine, Associated Press Writer

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Star Watch: From `sex, lies and videotape' to `Green Card'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: `Green Card' will open wide on Jan. 11.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: From Tarzan's mate to Gerard Depardieu's leading lady - that's the amazing range of Andie MacDowell's fast-rising movie career. The South Carolinian made her film debut in 1984 opposite Christopher Lambert in ``Greystoke: The Legend of Tarzan, Lord of the Jungle.'' The movie didn't do much for either performer, and MacDowell's career languished until last year's ``sex, lies and videotape.'' The film brought prestigious offers, including one from Peter Weir (``Witness,'' ``Dead Poets Society'') to co-star opposite Depardieu in ``Green Card.'' Touchstone Pictures released ``Green Card'' in limited engagements before year's end in time for Academy Award consideration, and the movie will open nationally Jan. 11. Weir wrote, directed and produced the story of a Frenchman (Depardieu) who lacks a green card to take a job in the United States. The solution: get married to an American. MacDowell needs to be married in order to rent the ``perfect apartment'' in New York. Voila! MacDowell, a rare beauty whose screen presence belies a basic shyness, admits she was scared to death at her first meeting with Weir. ``I wanted to do this film so badly, and I wanted to make the proper impression. Any time you want to make the proper impression, you usually don't,'' she said with a laugh. ``I left that meeting going over every word that I had uttered, every movement that I had made. I guess it worked. I got the job.'' Her first meeting with Depardieu was easier: ``Gerard said in an interview that I was nervous, and I was. I was more nervous meeting with Peter than with Gerard. He's very charming, you know, and you can see immediately how easy and comfortable he is with himself.'' About the language problem: ``I can get by in French. I would say that Gerard speaks better English than I speak French. We did all right. A lot of times he would speak French to me, because I can understand it. Peter speaks perfect French.'' Andie MacDowell was born in the small mill town of Gaffney, S.C., and grew up on both sides of the border between the Carolinas. The urge to act came early. ``Even as a child I loved to entertain. I loved to make people laugh. I used to put on shows in my garage. I danced in front of the TV - `Look at me! Look at me!' A little bit of a ham, I guess. I did theater when I was in college,'' she said. ``My mother, who is no longer alive, was very happy that I wanted to act, and she gave me great confidence. She sustained me. My father, I think at the beginning was a bit frightened, only because of the possibility of danger that I was going to the big city. He had plans for his daughter: he wanted me to be a nurse, get my education, marry a doctor and have children. Now he seems very proud that I'm happy.'' MacDowell did go to the big city, where she studied in a repertory theater. Playing Jane to Lambert's Tarzan seemed like a star-making turn, but it wasn't. Her only memorable role afterward was an unobtainable love in the yuppie melodrama ``St. Elmo's Fire.'' Then came ``sex, lies and videotape,'' in which she played the frustrated wife of a philandering husband. ``I would say it was the beginning of my career,'' she commented. ``I didn't know how it would turn out. It was such a low-budget film with a new director (Stephen Soderbergh). When I met him, I had complete trust in him. ``But you just don't know. It might get made and never distributed. That was my fear. I thought I would have something on tape to show casting directors what I was capable of. I knew that I finally had a role that I could do very well. ``I had confidence in myself as far as the role. I didn't think that anybody knew her as well as I knew her. It touched me in a very deep place.'' She feared that people might be narrow-minded about the film's explicit talk. Not until ``sex, lies'' won first prize at the Park City film festival did she think that it might be distributed after all. Then it won big at Cannes, and she thought, ``Well, it really will get distributed!'' MacDowell lives with her husband, Paul Qualley, and their two children in a farmhouse outside New York City. ``I wanted to move further into the country and live on a farm,'' she said, ``but this career has sort of taken over my life. This year I lived in Budapest and Rome and London and New York. I did three films. ``I don't think I plan to do three films next year. After so many years of wanting to do good work, to all of a sudden have the opportunity to work on three such interesting and different projects, it was too tempting to pass up. I hope I don't do that again.''

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
The Artists: Little Museum in Old Brewery
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The Lone Star Brewery folks surely never would have imagined it. Their beer factory, the biggest in Texas when it opened more than a century ago, is a cozy museum these days, commanding the attention of art experts worldwide. Just a decade old, the San Antonio Museum of Art is creating a noticeable niche for itself with a collection of Greek and Roman antiquities, a burgeoning Egyptian art display and a big Mexican visiting art show. ``We've received very high praise from our colleagues, both here and abroad,'' said Gerry Scott, the museum's ancient art curator. ``People came through and said, `My goodness, look what you have here in San Antonio.''' The current cheers are for the museum's Ewing Halsell Wing for ancient art, unveiled in November with much fanfare and a symposium by appreciative experts. Among those attending were former San Antonio antiquities curator, Carlos Picon, now with the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York; Cornelius Vermeule of the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston; Marion True of the J. Paul Getty Museum in California; and Dietrich Wildung, director of the Egyptian Museum in Berlin. The new wing features the Arnold and Marie Smith Schwartz Gallery for ancient glass, the Estelle Blackburn Gallery of Greek and Roman decorative arts and the Gilbert Denman Gallery for ancient sculpture. Though some pieces are on loan, most come from an extensive 1986 donation by Denman and the museum's acquisition of the Stark-Willson antiquities collection. A highlight of the antiquities collection is an eight-foot marble sculpture of the Roman emperor and philosopher Marcus Aurelius dating to 140 A.D. Excavated in 1771, it reveals the trend of that time - replacing pieces missing from the original. The ``Sleeping Ariadne,'' a Roman sculpture copying a Greek original dating from the 2nd century A.D., once was in a private collection in England. Its history is traceable to the 1600s. The Roman ``Deer Hunter'' sarcophagus, a marble case for burying the dead, dates from the 2nd century and features intricate carvings. A sculpture not on display also has generated news. Connoisseur magazine reported this fall that a Roman sculpture of a woman was smuggled out of Turkey, along with a handful of other art objects, and allegedly ended up at the San Antonio Museum of Art. Museum officials contend the article was ``sensational'' and insist no evidence has been found that the museum's 8-foot statue was illegally brought into the country. The museum is cooperating with the U.S. Customs Service and the U.S. attorney's office in an investigation, Scott said. The statue, lent by an anonymous donor, was noticeably absent when the antiquities exhibit opened. ``We didn't want to have a situation where people were coming in simply to see that sculpture and missing the other 96 pieces,'' Scott said. He added that its size would have made it more difficult to remove and return to the owner and said its period in art history already was represented in the exhibit. The Denman Gallery pieces range from the 6th century B.C. to the 3rd century A.D., while the Blackburn Gallery's pottery and vases demonstrate the development of decorative arts in the Classical Period from 2000 B.C. to 300 B.C. The Schwartz Gallery, described as one of the top six nationwide devoted to ancient glass, shows the development of glass from early stages in the Near East through later Roman and Islamic periods. While the antiquities collection has been praised for its range, the museum isn't claiming to rival the ``encyclopedic collections'' of the Boston Museum of Fine Arts or New York's Metropolitan Museum of Art. ``Boston and the Metropolitan both opened their doors in 1870, so they had plenty of years of collecting on us,'' Scott said, adding that the advantage of the San Antonio collection is its ``human scale.'' The antiquities collection isn't all that's publicizing the museum, which previously was best known for its folk art collection. It is one of three nationwide playing host to ``Mexico: Splendors of Thirty Centuries.'' The exhibit will be here four months between stops in New York and Los Angeles and will be greeted in San Antonio by Mexican President Carlos Salinas de Gortari the week of its April 4 opening. The exhibit will occupy 25,000 square feet, and construction workers are busy renovating another building of the old brewery to accommodate it. Two galleries of Egyptian art adjoining the new Halsell Wing also will close temporarily to make room for the Mexican show. Scott said the museum's antiquities collection is what attracted him to San Antonio this year after earning his doctorate at Yale University, working in two Yale art museums and working at a development company on grant writing. As an Egyptologist, Scott said, he was thrilled with the challenge of helping to build an Egyptian art collection. ``I believe that the museum itself, while it's made tremendous progress in the last 10 years, is poised to make some tremendous leaps forward,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Music Makers: Arlo Guthrie Keeps Music, Humor Flowing
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The secret is out and remember that you heard it here first: Arlo Guthrie never really wanted to be a folk singer. Forget for a moment that he's the son of Woody Guthrie, who wrote more than 1,000 songs, or that he's written a sizable number of memorable tunes himself. Forget all those great interpretations of ``Goodnight Irene,'' ``Amazing Grace,'' ``Stealin''' and ``This Land Is Your Land'' that you've heard him do over the years. Don't even think about ``Alice's Restaurant,'' that epic tale of youthful rebellion and anti-war protest. What Arlo Guthrie really wanted to be was a newspaper reporter. ``Yeah, there must be a repressed reporter in one of my hidden personalities because I love to write,'' laughs Guthrie, whose musical career has seen him evolve from the '60s-kid protest singer with a sense of humor to one of the pre-eminent voices in American folk music. But he says, ``I didn't become a folk singer because I wanted to be. I ended up doing this because I didn't know how to do anything else. ``And that hasn't changed much,'' he adds with that quick, good-natured laugh that his fans have heard so often over the years. It's the one that sometimes surfaces right on stage, in the middle of a song, when something strikes him so funny that he has to stop and tell everyone about it. But now the funny stories, the wry asides, the general observations on the oddities of life are as apt to go down on paper as over a microphone in a concert hall. The ones that are written go into Guthrie's newsletter, The Rolling Blunder Review, an espistle written in a style that evokes rollicking images of the kind of old-time journalism chronicled in such movies as ``The Front Page.'' But the newsletter never started out to be a newsletter. ``It sort of came about by accident,'' Guthrie says. In the mid-'70s he began collecting addresses of people who might want a schedule of his shows, but he never really got around to sending them one. ``People started asking us, `When are you going to send us something?' They'd say, `I signed up 14 times and I never got anything,''' he recalled. So with a great sense of guilt, The Rolling Blunder Review was born. Guthrie and his wife, Jackie, typed it on a single sheet of paper, made copies and mailed it from their home in Washington, Mass. Early issues contained only the long-sought schedule and a few funny comments on ``Alice's Restaurant'' and other songs. But as word spread, the newsletter grew. Five years later, it's an eight-page quarterly, containing stories, letters to the editor and information on how to buy Guthrie's albums, T-shirts and other merchandise. There's even a cooking column by Alice Brock. (``You remember Alice. There's a song about Alice.'') Some 60,000 to 70,000 people pay $3 a year for it, although it goes free to people in hospitals and prisons. Among the stories in recent issues are reports on concerts to benefit the environment and in support of student protests in China and elsewhere. But somehow, almost everything, no matter how serious, comes out funny. Sort of like an Arlo Guthrie concert. He notes that one role of a folk singer is to comment on political events of the day as his father, Pete Seeger, Joan Baez and so many others have done. ``But it's not the only job, and it may not even be the most important job,'' he said. ``The most important thing, for me personally, is maintaining a sense of humor in an often-humorless world.'' For Guthrie, the laughs have been frequent. Only he, for example, could show us (in ``Alice's Restaurant'') how to use a litterbug arrest as a reason to stay out of the Army during the Vietnam War. Only he has dared speculate (in ``The Pause of Mr Claus'') that Santa Claus might enter houses late at night because he's a dope fiend. Or that a delightful folk ditty about the joys of tilling the Earth (``The Garden Song'') should be played backward in search of evil messages. The laughs have been so frequent that they've allowed some to overlook the musical talent. Guthrie is more than proficient on guitar, piano, harmonica and banjo, as well as a singer of some range and a writer whose best songs evoke strong images of joy and sometimes sorrow. ``Alice's Restaurant'' started it all in 1967, making him an overnight star at age 20. ``Who could have ever imagined it,'' he says of the way the youth culture embraced his 18-minute, guitar-accompanied monologue on how he used a Thanksgiving Day arrest to stay out of the Army. The song also helped him escape early comparisons with a legendary father. And although Guthrie has almost always included a Woody Guthrie song or two in his concert repertoire, he downplays the father-son connection. ``For whatever cosmic reasons - and who really understands those things - I ended up similar to my dad in some ways,'' he says. ``But we're vastly different in other ways.'' But the connection also brings up another inevitable question. Woody Guthrie died in 1967 of the debilitating neurological disorder Huntington's Chorea. It has a 50-50 chance of being passed from parent to child, it strikes in middle age, and Arlo Guthrie is 43. But he dismisses such inquiries good-naturedly. ``I'm not dead yet,'' he says. ``Does that answer your question?'' He is also not through working yet, continuing to tour regularly and making plans to record again after several years without a new album. ``I've written some new songs,'' he says. ``I've got enough for a totally new record.'' He's also thinking about an animated version for children of ``Alice's Restaurant,'' which was made into a movie in 1969. ``It would focus more on the Thanksgiving part and less on the littering and draft parts,'' he says. He notes that the idea of dumping ``a half a ton of garbage'' by the side of the road isn't as popular as it once was, even if the dump was closed on Thanksgiving and you'd ``never heard of a dump closed on Thanksgiving before.'' ``Littering isn't such a good idea anymore,'' he says a bit sheepishly. But then he adds with that quick laugh: ``I sure had a lot of fun on that day though.'
