DOC.HEAD: ARLINGTON, Va.: science is.'
DOC.TEXT: Dawson complained that theEPA didn't appoint six scientists the Tobacco Institute had proposed for the expert panel. ``I think a strong argument can be made that the deck is stacked against us,'' she said. But Richard Daynard, an attorney and chairman of the Tobacco Products Liability Project in Boston, said he didn't understand why the tobacco industry had been made a party to the deliberations. ``Nobody's talking in these proceedings about regulating the tobacco industry,'' he said. ``They're talking about regulating individual behavior. They basically have no business being in there at all, and instead they've been given a preferential window into the private deliberations of the EPA.'' EPA officials denied the industry was given special access. And they gamely proceeded with the meeting of the expert panel in Arlington. The result was a stronger affirmation of the EPA's conclusions than the agency's staff expected. ``We are persuaded that the evidence exists ... for considering that ETS does cause lung cancer in non-smokers,'' said the panel's chairman, Morton Lippmann of New York University. The tobacco contigent was somber: ``The outcome has certainly not been entirely to our satisfaction,'' said Dawson. The panel must now prepare a written summary of its comments for the EPA staff, to serve as the underpinnings of a final version of the passive-smoking report. Agency scientists said it is now almost certain the final report will retain the conclusion that passive smoking causes lung cancer. But the tobacco industry isn't finished. ``I'm not willing to concede that this is over yet,'' said Dawson.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Prices Fall
DOC.TEXT: Bond prices fell in thin pre-holiday trading Monday on pessimism over heightened Middle East war talk. The Treasury's bellwether 30-year bond dropped 25-32 point, or $7.81 per $1,000 in face amount. Its yield, which rises when the price falls, rose to 8.35 percent from 8.29 percent late Friday. Market analysts said increasing war talk over the weekend from U.S. and Iraqi officials sent down the price of the key bond at the start of trading. Before concluding a visit to the gulf region, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said the ``clock is ticking'' toward war with Iraq. Cheney declined to say whether the United States has a timetable to attack Iraqi forces if Saddam Hussein ignores a U.N.-imposed Jan. 15 deadline to leave Kuwait. Meanwhile, Saddam, Iraq's president, said Tel Aviv will be Iraq's first target if war breaks out. It was the first time he had threatened to make the Jewish state his first target. War in the Middle East likely would push up the price of oil, an inflationary event that would erode the value of Treasury securities. ``It is nothing more than a continuation of the war jitters we saw (that) began to dominate trading last week,'' said William V. Sullivan, director of money market research at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Also, traders were selling to square their positions before the end of the year and to avoid losses should the situation in the Persian Gulf change on Christmas Day, when the nation's financial markets are closed. Sullivan said trading was extremely light in an abbreviated trading session. In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, short-term maturities fell 3-32 point to 9-32 point, intermediate maturities declined 11-16 point to 9-16 point and long-term issues were off by up to 27-32 point, the Telerate Inc. financial information service reported. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, was down 4.54 to 1,177.45. Yields on three-month Treasury bills were down to 6.72 percent as the discount fell 1 basis point to 6.53 percent. Yields on six-month bills rose to 6.93 percent as the discount increased rose 2 basis points to 6.62 percent. Yields on one-year bills rose to 6.98 percent as the discount gained 4 basis points to 6.55 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest on overnight loans between banks, was trading at 7 percent, down from 7\ percent late Friday. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 91 5-32, down [ point. The average yield to maturity rose to 7.48 percent from 7.47 percent late Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Dollars, Dollars Everywhere Amid Ruble Confusion
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar is rapidly becoming the currency of choice in the Soviet Union due to growing confusion over the value of the ruble during the country's struggle to become a market-driven economy. Rubles are worth nothing outside the Soviet Union because the government refuses to back them with hard currency, gold or silver. But inside the country tourists can walk up to a Moscow hotel currency booth and buy six rubles for one dollar, or 16 cents each. If they use a credit card, they get 1.8 rubles for that same dollar, the so-called commercial rate. On the black market, a dollar fetches about 20 rubles. ``Confusion reigns everywhere,'' said Andy Rafalat, deputy general director of Moscow's two Pizza Hut restaurants. More and more firms have been switching as many transactions as possible to hard currencies, the favorite being the U.S. dollar. Leaders of the huge Russian republic, who want to make the ruble the only legal currency in the country, have coined a word for the trend: ``dollarization.'' Barter deals - from PepsiCo's vodka-for-oil tankers deal to using the instantly recognizable red-and-white Marlboro cigarette package to flag a cab - are also becoming more popular. Until recently, foreign businesses had dealt in the official or ``hard'' ruble known in Russian as ``valuta.'' Their price tags and restaurant menus were printed in official rubles, but payable only in hard currency or credit cards at the official rate. This rate was effectively replaced in November with a new commercial exchange rate devaluing the ruble to 1.8 rubles to the dollar from 1.6 rubles. In his decree, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev indicated this rate was to cover all international commercial transactions by Soviet companies as well as joint ventures with foreign firms and foreign residents in the Soviet Union. The official rate was retained only for international currency comparisons and to protect Third World countries whose debts are in rubles. Finland, the Soviet Union's closest Western trading partner, was so confused that its central bank stopped clearing ruble transactions for nearly one week. In Moscow, the Swiss-Soviet joint venture Sadko kept its staff on overtime one night to change all its price tags. Ruble prices were tripled, but since the new ruble was worth only one-third of the old one, the hard currency price remained the same. Pizza Hut immediately started writing its credit card bills in U.S. dollars to avoid any risk of customers being charged the higher exchange rate by banks ignoring the new rules. Explanatory notes have been stapled to all hard currency menus and Rafalat said the company is considering reprinting them in dollars instead of rubles next month to make them easier to understand. ``We were quite happy to use the hard ruble rate, but only if there's an acceptable, clear definition for our business use, which at this moment hasn't been the case,'' he said in an interview. ``The only 100 percent clear road I can see is by quoting prices in another currency. As we receive most of our hard currency in dollars, dollars seem to be the most obvious thing to quote.'' Stockmann, a Finnish firm with grocery and department stores in Moscow, kept its price tags in the old official rubles and posted a notice on its front door advising customers. But on Jan. 1 it will close its two Moscow outlets to switch all prices and credit card transactions to dollars. ``In this confusing situation, we find it better to change the prices directly to dollars,'' store manager Ilkka Arvola said. ``These continuous questions and explanations between us and our customers ... is completely unnecessary and customers do not like this uneasy feeling. Neither do I,'' he said. ``Customers sort of think we might be cheating them somehow, which we're not.'' Switching to dollars should also prevent disruptions the next time the ruble rate is changed, he said. Western diplomats and businessmen say the new rate is a tentative step toward making the ruble convertible, as it inches the Soviet currency closer to its real value. The Soviet government has given no firm indication when or how it plans to make the ruble convertible.

DOC.HEAD: With Graphic
Backlash Puts Brakes On Marketers' Green Machine
DOC.TEXT: Rarely has something so green made marketers so blue. In the past year, manufacturers have crammed supermarket shelves with everything from ``degradable'' plastic bags to ``ozone-friendly'' hair sprays in hopes of cashing in on the growing concern about the environment. But the so-called Green Revolution, one of the most powerful marketing machines since oat bran hit the dietary scene, is grinding its gears. Lawsuits, legislative proposals and consumer boycotts have led many companies to stop claiming broad environmental benefits for their products. ``The major manufacturers have backpedaled because they are leery of getting caught in making claims that through no fault of their own they can't substantiate,'' said Robert McMath, a consumer products expert and director of the New Products Showcase and Learning Center in Ithaca, N.Y. Mobil Chemical Corp. said last spring it would refrain from promoting its Hefty plastic bags as ``photo-degradable'' after consumer and government groups complained the bags wouldn't degrade anytime soon inside the darkened recesses of landfills, where most trash ends up. Seven states subsequently sued Mobil this summer, saying the company hasn't removed all of the existing products that still contain those criticized claims. ``What's happened is that the Hefty incident has really made manufacturers go back to square one,'' said Simon Williams, president of Michael Peters Design, a New York consultant firm that specializes in earth-friendly packaging. Retreats from biodegradable claims have since become widespread. Following Mobil's announcement last spring, First Brands Corp., of Danbury, Conn., and Webster Industries Inc., of Peabody, Mass., said they would also refrain from degradability claims for their Glad and Good Sense plastic bags. American Enviro Products Inc., of Placentia, Calif., agreed to stop promoting its Bunnies disposable diapers as biodegradable after attorneys general in 10 states threatened to sue. More recently, Willamette Industries Inc., of Portland, Ore., one of the nation's largest paper bag manufacturers, eliminated the words ``biodegradable'' and ``recyclable'' from the bottom of its paper bags distributed at supermarket checkout counters in 17 Western states. Green Cross Certification Co., an independent certification firm hired by Willamette, said most consumers will not recycle the product and that the bags will take years to degrade in most landfills. Willamette still hypes the bags' ``recycled'' content, but Green Cross has verified it is composed of a minimum of 40 percent recycled consumer paper. Seventh Generation, a Burlington, Vt.-based mail order firm specializing in earth-friendly products, announced a new policy regarding so-called degradable plastic bags in last spring's catalog: ``We suspended sale of these bags because we are no longer confident they are beneficial to the environment.'' ``Large manufacturers feel somewhat caught between the need to do something and the fear of figuring out the right thing to do while avoiding adverse implications for their current product line,'' said Jeffrey Hollender, chairman and chief executive officer of Seventh Generation. To be fair, the green flood has hardly subsided - the number of new products hyping their ecological soundness nearly tripled this year to 751, according to Marketing Intelligence Service Ltd., a research firm in Naples, N.Y. But product consultants say they expect fewer new claims next year, and they expect more of them to be of the provable kind. Critics say their next area of attack are supposedly earth-friendly aerosols whose ozone-destroying chlorofluorocarbons have been replaced by other suspect chemicals. The biggest new growth area are household products, ranging from paints to cleaners. ``We've got to make sure consumers are not going to feel that every ad and every bit of labeling is to be disregarded because it is false and deceptive,'' said New York State Attorney General Robert Abrams in a telephone interview en route from his Albany office. Indeed, state officials praised a recent move by Proctor & Gamble Co. to offer waste-efficient ``refillable'' containers for its Downy fabric softener. Early this month at hearings in San Diego, a group of state attorneys general proposed nationwide minimum standards for environmental claims consistent with national and state legislation currently in draft form. They also called for reduced use of general, hard-to-document terms like ``environmentally friendly.'' Instead, manufacturers are urged to be as detailed as possible when describing claims like ``recycled content,'' telling precisely what percentage of the content is recycled. States including New York, Connecticut, Iowa, Minnesota and Texas are pressing for legislation that would bar manufacturers from using ``degradable'' on packages before more research is available on just how long it takes these products to decompose. A New York bill failed to win approval this session. ``For the first year there was no guidance,'' said Linda Brown, a spokeswoman at Green Cross, which is based in Oakland, Calif. ``Now companies are taking a closer look to see if any of these claims are falling into gray zones.''

DOC.HEAD: FCC Approves Spinoff of WWOR As Part of MCA Sale to Matsushita
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Communications Commission said Monday it had approved the transfer of a New York-area television station from MCA Inc. to MCA shareholders, removing a barrier to the sale of MCA to Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. of Japan. Under federal law, Matsushita as a foreign corporation is barred from owning MCA's WWOR-TV, based in Secaucus, N.J. The station will be spun off to MCA shareholders in the form of a separate company. Under the FCC's decision, entertainment giant MCA will be allowed to complete the divestiture on condition that three MCA officials resign their positions either with MCA or its subsidiary MCA Broadcasting Inc. and WWOR. MCA officials were not available for comment because the company was closed for the Christmas holiday, said a guard at MCA's headquarters in Universal City, Calif. Matsushita, a huge conglomerate known in the United States for its names Panasonic, Technics and Quasar brands, agreed last month to acquie MCA, parent of Universal Studios, for $6.6 billion, the largest purchase of a U.S. company by one in Japan. In addition to its motion picture business, MCA also owns book publishing and music publishing assets, retail and mail order businesses, food and lodging concessions at Yosemite National Park, 49 percent of Cineplex Odeon theaters and 50 percent of the USA cable TV network. To deflect criticism of foreign ownership of an interest in Yosemite, Matsushita has said that MCA's Curry Co. subsidiary, which operates restaurants, hotels and other services in the national park, will be sold within a year. Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan has said the federal government itself may want to acquire the services.

DOC.HEAD: Wheat Futures Rise on Exports, Weather Fears
DOC.TEXT: Wheat futures prices rose moderately Monday on the Chicago Board of Trade in a late rally linked to new export sales and fears of weather damage to the winter wheat crop. Oat futures also advanced while corn and soybean futures ended mostly lower on light volume in a shortened Christmas Eve trading session. Most cattle futures rose and pork futures finished mostly lower in a shortened session on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Other U.S. commodity markets were closed. Wheat futures settled 1} cents to 5 cents higher with the contract for delivery in March at $2.64\ a bushel; corn was 1\ cents lower to { cent higher with March at $2.33\ a bushel; oats were { cent to 1\ cents higher with March at $1.12{ a bushel; soybeans were 1} cents lower to 1\ cents higher with January at $5.62\ a bushel. Wheat futures drew some support from news of government-subsidized sales of U.S. wheat to Colombia, Yemen and Sri Lanka, analysts said. The rally also reflected speculation about possible damage to the winter wheat crop after nearly a week of record-breaking frigid weather in the Great Plains, said Victor Lespinasse, an assistant vice president in the grain trading division of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. ``A lot of winter wheat areas don't have adequate snow coverage, which could increase winterkill if this weather continues - and it looks like it's going to for several days,'' he said. Corn and soybean prices were pressured by fears that political changes in the Soviet Union could lead to civil unrest, a military crackdown and a cutoff in U.S. food aid, he said. Cattle futures posted modest gains in light trading amid perceptions that beef consumption will increase with retail promotions after the holidays. Near-term pork futures ended lower on pre-holiday profit taking and ideas that hog marketings could rise sharply when the cold weather eases in the Midwest, analysts said. Live cattle settled .20 cent lower to .20 cent higher with February at 76.77 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .10 cent to .20 cent higher with January at 88.82 cents a pound; live hogs were .30 cent lower to .25 cent higher with February at 48.77 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .42 cent to .62 cent lower with February at 64.20 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Northwest Airlines Near Deal to Operate Pan Am Shuttle
With AM-TWA-Pan Am, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Northwest Airlines has arranged for a Portland, Ore., utility to buy the Pan Am Shuttle and allow Northwest to operate the shuttle with an option to buy, according to a published report Monday. Northwest would not comment on the report in The Wall Street Journal. The newspaper said PacifiCorp would buy the Boston-New York-Washington shuttle for about $150 million. ``We can't comment on that as to whether we are in negotiations or struck a deal,'' said Doug Miller, a spokesman for Northwest, the nation's fourth largest airline. ``There's no announcement to make and we don't have any comment on it.'' PacifiCorp and New York-based Pan Am also declined to comment. PacifiCorp is the third largest utility in the West, holding Pacific Power of Portland and Utah Power of Salt Lake City. A subsidiary, PacifiCorp Financial Services Inc., has $1.7 billion in assets and has interests in 50 aircraft. It reported a 1989 aviation finance portfolio of $244 million, spokeswoman Caroline Petrich said. PacifiCorp Finance Inc., a subsidiary of PacifiCorp Financial Services Inc., took preliminary steps nearly two years ago to acquire HAL Inc., the parent of Hawaiian Airlines. The deal never was completed. Marc Robins, an analyst who follows PacifiCorp for Capital Consultants Inc. of Portland, said he was unaware of the PacifiCorp-Northwest-Pan Am deal. But he said it sounded like a good opportunity for PacifiCorp Financial Services. The Portland company's interest likely would remain purely financial, he said. PacifiCorp executives probably are not interested in running an airline, Robins said. The Journal, quoting unidentified sources familiar with the arrangement, said union leaders were told this month that a sale was imminent but later were told it had been delayed. Leaders at three Pan Am unions could not be reached for comment. No one answered phones in their offices. Guy Cook, head of the largest union at Northwest, said he knew nothing about the reported deal. But he said such an acquisition could make sense for Northwest. ``I've heard a lot of rumors about an East Coast shuttle,'' said Cook, president of the International Association of Machinists District Lodge 143. ``I knew there was an interest and from a shuttle standpoint for Northwest there would be no problem.'' Cook said Northwest might be able to run the shuttle without adding a lot of workers because it already has bases in New York, Boston and Washington. He speculated that Pan Am could use the cash from a shuttle sale to stay afloat and clear the way for a proposed buyout by Trans World Airlines Inc. Henry ``Pete'' Dodge, chairman of the Northwest Airlines chapter of the Air Line Pilots Association, said he probably would have been informed by Northwest Chairman Al Checchi if such a deal for the shuttle were imminent. Dodge said he had no knowledge that a transaction was in the works, but said he would welcome such a move. ``It doesn't totally surprise me,'' Dodge said. ``Anything to help strengthen our domestic market certainly can't hurt.'' Checchi, who led a $3.65 billion buyout of Northwest last year, repeatedly has said he wants to expand his airline through acquisitions. He had expressed interest in the former Eastern Airlines' Boston-New York-Washington shuttle before it was sold last year to Donald Trump for $365 million. Northwest has hubs in Detroit, Minneapolis-St. Paul and Memphis.

DOC.HEAD: Chicago Merc, Reuters Announce Globex Deal
DOC.TEXT: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange, the Chicago Board of Trade and Reuters Holdings PLC on Monday announced a tentative agreement on Globex, their proposed electronic futures and options trading system. The parties said they reached agreement on a letter of intent that ``resolves all substantive issues toward the completion of a 20-year contract.'' The letter of intent is subject to execution of a final agreement, approval by the parties' governing boards and ratification by the exchanges' members, according to a statement. The long-delayed system is scheduled for testing in Chicago, New York and London around the end of the first quarter, the parties said. Globex is envisioned as a worldwide, computerized system for trading the financial futures and options products of various exchanges when their trading floors are closed. Reuters would supply the computer terminals and the technology. The New York Mercantile Exchange, the Sydney Futures Exchange of Australia and the French futures exchange known as MATIF have agreed to offer products for trading on Globex alongside selected products from the Merc and the Board of Trade. The Merc and London-based Reuters had announced plans for Globex in September 1987 and originally hoped to have the system in operation by the spring of 1989. The project was delayed by international regulatory hurdles and negotiations with the Board of Trade, which agreed to join the project last May after abandoning an attempt to create a competing system.

DOC.HEAD: Tobacco Company Says It Won't Appeal New Jersey Cigarette Suit Decision
DOC.TEXT: Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corp. will not appeal a New Jersey Supreme Court decision that health warnings on cigarette packs do not protect tobacco companies from liability suits, the firm said Monday. In a statement, Louisville, Ky.-based Brown & Williamson said it is confident it would win if any liability cases are presented and would not ask the U.S. Supreme Court to review the New Jersey decision. The New Jersey ruling flew in the face of a series of federal decisions that gave tobacco companies immunity from smoker-death lawsuits after 1966, when Congress ordered the labels placed on cigarette packs. The ruling stemmed from a lawsuit filed by Claire Dewey of Wyckoff in 1982. Her husband, Wilfred Dewey, had died a year before on his 50th birthday from lung cancer after smoking for more than 40 years. The court decision said Mrs. Dewey had the right to sue. In its statement, Brown & Williamson said it is ``confident that, if there is a trial on the merits of the Dewey case, the company will prevail.'' The company said the New Jersey case is ``clearly contrary to all previous and subsequent federal court of appeals and state Supreme Court determinations. Review of the New Jersey Supreme Court decision may either not be necessary or be more appropriate after the Dewey case is concluded at the trial stage.'' Telephone calls placed to the two other tobacco companies included in the Dewey suit - RJ Reynolds Tobacco Co. and American Brands - were not answered Monday. Marc Edell, the attorney who represents Mrs. Dewey, was out of town and not available for comment Monday, his office said.

The Christmas shopping season turned out to be a disappointment for many retailers as holiday gift-giving took a back seat this year to consumers' worries about the economy and the Middle East. Early estimates from high-profile retailing companies around the country showed Christmas sales were flat to slightly higher than last season. At Wal-Mart Stores Inc., a spokeswoman said the company was pleased with its results, but the retailer found it hard to draw hesitant consumers into its stores. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Pan Am Corp. and Trans World Airlines Inc. continued negotiating over whether TWA would lend Pan Am enough money to keep it operating until the struggling carriers can merge. TWA spokesman Don Morrison said talks on the loan ran through the weekend and into Monday. --- MINNEAPOLIS (AP) - Northwest Airlines has arranged for a Portland, Ore., utility to buy the Pan Am Shuttle and allow Northwest to operate the shuttle with an option to buy, according to a published report. Northwest would not comment on the report in The Wall Street Journal Monday. The newspaper said PacifiCorp would buy the Boston-New York-Washington shuttle for about $150 million. --- FRESNO, Calif. (AP) - Freezing temperatures have devastated California's navel orange crop, the source of most of the nation's fresh oranges each winter. Dave Carman of the National Weather Service called the weather probably the second-coldest freeze of the century. Temperatures throughout the San Joaquin Valley citrus region dipped below 20 degrees from Friday night through Sunday night. Navel oranges begin to show damage if the temperature falls to 25 or 26 degrees and stays at that level or below for at least four hours, said Cliff Holland of California Citrus Mutual, a grower organization. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. is paying two traders more than $1 million a year and other top executives hundreds of thousands of dollars during the firm's costly bankruptcy proceedings. Drexel confirmed Monday that 29 senior executives and traders are receiving more than $250,000 a year each. But the firm said the salaries were set early in the case, are necessary to manage its business and are on a par with compensation elsewhere on Wall Street. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - As a gathering recession compels many Americans to curtail their purchases, some of the country's tonier establishments are noticing a surge in spending among upper-crust shoppers eager to beat the new luxury tax. The trend is most noticeable in the automobile industry, where new levies will drive up the price of some cars by thousands of dollars. Neiman Marcus spokeswoman Pat Zajac says that sales managers at the company's 24 upscale department stores report increased purchases of expensive furs and jewelry - both of which will be subject to the new tax. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The Federal Communications Commission said it has approved the transfer of a New York-area television station from MCA Inc. to MCA shareholders, removing a barrier to the sale of MCA to Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. of Japan. Under federal law, Matsushita as a foreign corporation is barred from owning MCA's WWOR-TV, based in Secaucus, N.J. The station will be spun off to MCA shareholders in the form of a separate company. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The Bush administration put Thailand on notice that it will consider imposing retaliatory tariffs unless the country takes steps to improve the protection of American copyrights. U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills announced that she had begun an investigation into Thailand's copyright enforcement practices. --- EAST AURORA, N.Y. (AP) - Karl H. Hinke, a longtime banking executive who created the MasterCard credit card, has died at age 84. Hinke, the former chairman of the Interbank Card Association and a retired executive of Marine Midland Bank, where he worked for 55 years, died Saturday at his home in East Aurora, outside Buffalo.

Stock prices declined moderately Monday in listless Christmas eve trading. Activity was sparse throughout the session, which closed for the impending holiday at 2 p.m. EST, two hours earlier than usual. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 12.37 points to 2,621.29. Bond prices were down amid hightened Middle East war talk. In London crude oil futures prices rose about $1 a barrel on the International Petroleum Exchange. The New York Mercantile Exchange was closed for the holidays. Wheat and oat futures rose on the Chicago Board of Trade while corn and soybean futures ended mostly lower in the shortened trading session.
